7 Ways to Use Mobile Banking Safely - Fight Fraud 7 Ways to Use Mobile Banking Safely - Fight Fraudsters who are trying to take our money in every way. There are many different methods, and in the current cashless society, everyone prefers to use Mobile Banking, which is easy to transfer, convenient, and fast. However, if you are not careful, you can easily become a victim of fraud and lose all your money. The Thai Bankers' Association recommends 7 ways to use mobile banking safely - to fight fraud: 1. Download apps from trusted sources, such as the Apple Store, Google Play Store, and keep your operating system and mobile banking apps updated to the latest version. 2. Log out every time after using the app. 3. Perform transactions yourself. 4. Do not give your mobile phone or important information to untrustworthy people to help you make transactions. Also, advise and guide the elderly in your home to use Mobile Banking correctly and safely. 5. Do not modify your mobile operating system, such as Jailbreak or Root. 6. Do not click on links from SMS or other communication channels such as Line, Messenger. If in doubt, contact the source, such as the bank you are using. 7. Do not use public Wi-Fi when conducting financial transactions. 8. Set a strong password and change it regularly, such as every 3 months.

Warning! Scammers have a new trick to steal bank app access codes. Warning! Scammers have a new trick to steal bank app access codes. The Thai Bankers' Association is warning the public about a new scam targeting people's money. This time, scammers impersonate various agencies and organizations by contacting people through LINE and using various deceptive tactics. For example, they might pretend to be police officers, forcing victims to turn on their cameras for recording, claiming it's for evidence. Or they might claim they will transfer money back to the victim and ask for personal information for verification. Next, the scammers will trick the victim into a video call and then trick them into sharing their screen. They then instruct the victim to dial "131 followed by their bank app access code# and then press call," or some other number sequence that won't actually connect a call. This allows the scammer to see the code entered on the screen and use it to access the victim's banking app and steal their money. The Thai Bankers' Association advises everyone to be vigilant and cautious, and not to fall for scammers who create situations to initiate video calls. Never give any personal information, including access codes, to anyone. If you encounter online fraud, contact the AOC Center at 1441 for consultation, reporting, or assistance with online threats, 24 hours a day.

5 Ways to Deal with Scammers Tricking You into Installing Money-Draining Apps 5 Ways to Deal with Scammers Tricking You into Installing Money-Draining Apps Currently, many victims are being deceived by scammers who call and pretend to be "government officials or bank officers." They ask you to add them as a friend on a fake Line account of that agency and then trick you into clicking a link to their website. This leads to downloading and installing a money-draining application, allowing the scammers to remotely control the victim's mobile device. The "Thai Bankers' Association" therefore shares the following prevention and coping methods: Do not believe scammers who call and claim to be officials. To verify, hang up and try calling back immediately. If you cannot reach them or there is no answer, be suspicious that it is a scammer. Do not click on links from various communication channels such as SMS, LINE, Messenger, or others. Do not accept friend requests from unknown individuals on social media. Do not install apps from websites, links, or QR codes. If you want to install an app, open Google Play or the App Store to search for the app and install it yourself. Do not scan your face unless it is the bank's app.

"Guidelines for Dealing with Online Fraud" "Guidelines for Dealing with Online Fraud" Guidelines for Dealing with Online Fraud: Do not believe or easily fall for the tricks of scammers. Do not disclose financial information. Keep it confidential. Do not provide financial information, personal information, and Online Transaction (OTP) information received via SMS to others. Do not be deceived. Banks and government agencies do not have a policy of transferring money out of accounts for verification. Precautions: Be wary of phone numbers/emails/SMS/Line messages claiming to be from banks or government agencies, such as the Land Department, the Anti-Money Laundering Office, the Police, the Comptroller General's Department, the Revenue Department, the Electricity Authority, the Metropolitan Waterworks Authority, the Social Security Office, etc. They often ask you to add them as a friend and then trick you into clicking dangerous links or fake QR codes, leading you into a trap. Beware of installing dangerous apps outside the official store. These types of apps often impersonate various organizations or government agencies, but in reality, they are apps that infiltrate and steal money from victims' accounts. Customer Actions: If you become a victim of a call center gang, immediately report it to the AOC Center 1441, 24 hours a day.

"Bank Procedures When Customers Realize They Have Been Scammed" The Thai Bankers' Association has created an infographic, "Bank Procedures in Case of Customer Being Scammed," to publicize and raise public awareness, so that people are aware of and prepared to prevent scams, as follows: • The victim immediately notifies the Call Center or branch of the bank where they hold an account. Upon notification from the victim, the bank will immediately temporarily suspend the transaction. The bank will then notify the receiving bank to investigate and immediately temporarily suspend the transaction for 72 hours. The bank where the victim holds an account will issue a Bank Case ID for the victim to use to file a complaint with an investigator at any convenient police station. • The investigator will accept the complaint and then notify the bank to extend the transaction suspension period to 7 days, pending investigation and issuance of a warrant.

Analysis Report: Phishing campaign targeting telecommunications and postal service users worldwide The Telecommunications Computer Emergency Response Team (TTC-CERT) has been tracking and analyzing a large-scale phishing campaign conducted through SMS phishing (Smishing), phishing emails, and fraudulent websites aimed at stealing personal and/or financial information from postal and telecommunications service users worldwide. The campaign, which began in May 2023, utilizes over 300 fraudulent domains impersonating more than 50 postal service companies, telecommunications companies, and other organizations globally. Based on the observed fraudulent domain names, TTC-CERT has a high level of confidence that this group of criminals is targeting individuals worldwide, not specifically targeting Thai people or any single organization. The phishing infrastructure is complex, consisting of web applications impersonating postal and telecommunications companies to lure users and steal sensitive information. This report analyzes the infrastructure and related fraudulent domain information. TTC-CERT has prepared this analysis report and identified "Indicators of Compromise (IOCs)" to alert and inform organizations and the general public. This information can be used to conduct self-risk assessments and take appropriate action to secure information systems and organizational networks. However, if a TTC-CERT member organization is connected to the TTC-CERT MISP system, the Indicators of Compromise (IOCs) from this report will be automatically sent to your organization's MISP.

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1bOPqpPxViJFdZSFN5ds0oDqWvbhQtjHT3Jrbx8kKbyA/edit?tab=t.0

Notification - Analysis Report on a Significant Increase in SMS Phishing (Smishing) Using a Delivery Service Theme The TTC-CERT has issued an important notification and analysis report regarding SMS phishing (Smishing) targeting customers of Thailand Post. Since January 2024, the TTC-CERT has observed an increase in Smishing attacks impersonating Thailand Post's delivery service. These scams utilize SMS messages to trick unsuspecting individuals into revealing sensitive information, potentially leading to financial loss and identity theft. The TTC-CERT has conducted a detailed analysis of the infrastructure used by these perpetrators, discovering 192 attack-related domains registered since January 2024. All 192 domains point to the IP address 156[.]251[.]25[.]151. Based on the discovered domain names, the TTC-CERT has a high level of confidence that this group of criminals is targeting individuals using delivery services worldwide, not just those in Thailand. The TTC-CERT has prepared this analysis report and identified "Indicators of Compromise (IOCs)" to alert and inform organizations and the general public. This information can be used to assess risks and take appropriate action to secure information systems and organizational networks. Furthermore, if your organization is connected to the TTC-CERT's MISP system, the Indicators of Compromise (IOCs) from this report will be automatically sent to your organization's MISP.

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1m8SOHm7o5Dtx4vlzYou3fFrx5NLyaAE2cu6Awggks9E/edit?tab=t.0

Vulnerability Alert: Misconfiguration in Active Directory Certificate Services (AD CS) The Telecommunications Computer Emergency Response Coordination Center (TTC-CERT) received information from a Red Teaming Program conducted at an organization in the telecommunications sector. This organization wishes to share beneficial information with other organizations in the same sector. TTC-CERT has therefore compiled this advisory regarding critical vulnerabilities in Active Directory Certificate Services (AD CS). These vulnerabilities are documented in the SpectreOps whitepaper "Certified Pre-Owned: Exploiting AD CS for Domain Escalation." They may allow malicious actors to perform privilege escalation within the victim's domain without authorization. This could lead to unauthorized access, data theft, and/or disruption of critical systems.

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1HXgODfDkdOcv26Ze8vGg2s_j1IGp791ZxyJqf606Vro/edit?tab=t.0

Domain Name Scam Disclosure: A Case Study of Scammers Using Deceptive Tactics to Trick Organizations into Transferring Money for .CN Domain Name Registrations The TTC-CERT Center has detected cases of scammers using deceptive tactics to trick organizations into transferring money for .CN domain name registrations. This is a domain name scam carried out by international fraudsters and is a significant threat to businesses in Thailand and worldwide. This article by the TTC-CERT Center delves into the methods of domain name scams, focusing on incidents between November 2023 and January 2024 involving an individual identifying himself as "Paul Liu," a service and operations manager of China Registry. He attempted to use various tricks to deceive the TTC-CERT Center into registering top-level domain names used in China. He sent emails to the TTC-CERT Center attempting to lure them into registering various domain extensions: .cn, .com.cn, .net.cn, and .org.cn. By feigning victimhood, the TTC-CERT Center uncovered the modus operandi of this international fraud group and further analyzed the infrastructure that the group might use to deceive organizations both domestically and internationally. These findings highlight the importance of vigilance in prevention and awareness of such fraudulent behavior. During email correspondence, the TTC-CERT Center embedded scripts within the emails to verify the scammer's source IP address, which was traced to ASN4134 China Telecom Backbone, located in China.

Malware Analysis Report AMAR-231199-1.v1 - BangkokShell Analysis of the suspicious file by the TTC-CERT center found that the attackers created a Windows Service named myautotimeservice in advance to run a Portable Executable (PE) file. This PE file then loads a malicious Dynamic-link Library (DLL) file named LTDIS13n.dll using a technique called DLL Side-loading. The LTDIS13n.dll file is a Loader-type malware that contains an embedded Obfuscated Payload. This payload is later Deobfuscated into a malicious Shellcode file. This Shellcode is then injected into main memory (Memory) and operates within it without creating any files on the Filesystem. The Shellcode detected in this instance is a Remote Access Trojan (RAT) and uses Stackstrings to embed two URLs used as Command and Control (C2) servers. Of particular interest is that the domain and subdomain names of the C2 closely resemble the domain and subdomain names actively used within the internal network (Internal Network) of the targeted security agency. Once the Shellcode starts running, it connects to the C2 via HTTPS on port 443 to receive commands to execute on the target computer. The command data is obfuscated using the XOR algorithm.

Notification - Analysis Report: Further Tracking of Command and Control (C2) Infrastructure and Operations Used in Mustang Panda Attacks The TTC-CERT Center has noted a report from Unit 42, which identified three cyber attack campaigns by the Mustang Panda group in August 2023, targeting various entities in the South Pacific, including the Philippine government. In these campaigns, the attackers embedded malware within commonly used software by loading malicious files through software named Solid PDF Creator and SmadavProtect (an Indonesian antivirus solution). These operations, linked to Mustang Panda, demonstrate the objective of continuous cyber espionage. The report indicates that the attackers successfully infiltrated Philippine government agencies. Mustang Panda's latest cyber espionage attacks have revealed sophisticated methods of infiltrating computer networks of government agencies and various organizations. While Mustang Panda's campaigns have been widely discussed, a thorough examination of their cyber operations and Command and Control (C2) infrastructure characteristics has informed TTC-CERT about the attackers' methods and revealed a Command and Control (C2) server infrastructure (potentially for use in future attacks) linked to the C2 infrastructure identified in the Unit 42 report.

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1ouK12-SxkDGT-qD9EEA_5RKY0JSpvYpJGeImfe6jUQk/edit?tab=t.0

New attack methods of the MuddyWater APT group during the Israel-Hamas war and detection methods. The TTC-CERT Center found a report on new attack methods of the MuddyWater APT group. It is a DeepInstinct article titled "MuddyWater eN-Able spear-phishing with new TTPs." The MuddyWater group is one of the groups that the TTC-CERT Center is monitoring. In the past, MuddyWater has targeted and attacked organizations in the Thai telecommunications sector no less than 3 times. The details of the Indicators of Compromise (IOCs) in the said article have already been sent by the TTC-CERT Center to your organization via MISP on November 3, 2023, under the MISP Event title "MuddyWater eN-Able spear-phishing with new TTPs." However, from past experience, the TTC-CERT Center has found that the IOCs that are Hash values of attacks by the MuddyWater group specified in various reports are not effective enough in detecting attacks. This is because the Configuration files of the Remote Access Software used by the attackers are often configured to the name of the target organization. This results in the Hash value of the files used by the MuddyWater group in the attack changing according to the properties of the Hash value. For example, the files used to attack Operator A will have a different Hash value than the files used to attack Operator B.

Notification - Analysis Report of Attack Pattern Development Trends Using Fake Updates to Spread Malware Over the past month, the TTC-CERT center has continued to observe several malware campaigns using URLs leading to compromised websites with HTML injection or malicious JavaScript to display fake update notifications. Initial investigation reveals that the domains or websites involved in these attacks are legitimate. However, malicious actors have employed various methods to screen targets and route malicious traffic through these compromised domains or websites. For example, SocGholish is a loader-type malware that exploits vulnerabilities in websites and performs multiple environment checks on target computers to determine if they are worthwhile targets. These checks consider geographic location, operating system, IP address, browser, and other variables. If a target is deemed valuable, the victim's traffic is redirected to a landing page displaying a fake browser update notification such as "You are using an older version of Chrome," as detailed in Figure 1. If the victim clicks the "Update Chrome" button, the victim's computer will attempt to download a JavaScript file.

[TLP:GREEN] Alert - Additional Investigation Report on Attacks in the BangkokShell Campaign The TTC-CERT has investigated several suspicious files received from a security agency in Thailand and found that all files are related to the BangkokShell cyber attack campaign. TTC-CERT previously published information about this campaign in June 2023 in a report titled "Alert - Report on the Discovery of the BangkokShell Campaign Specifically Targeting Organizations in Thailand" (https://drive.google.com/file/d/14OdsocsRVK6osG3TLxyGSB0fJZaaS2fK/view). The results of this analysis indicate that the malware files were compiled before the malware files found in the report "Alert - Report on the Discovery of the BangkokShell Campaign Specifically Targeting Organizations in Thailand." However, there are differences in Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures (TTPs), which indicate that the attackers' operations have been ongoing and that they are continuously improving and developing their malware and seeking tools to achieve their objectives. This report will describe the overall functionality of the malware files found, analyze the changes that have occurred, and understand the reasons behind these changes. TTC-CERT has prepared this alert report and identified "Indicators of Compromise (IOCs)" to inform organizations and the general public. This information can be used to assess risks and take appropriate actions to secure information systems and networks. If your organization is connected to the TTC-CERT MISP system, the Indicators of Compromise (IOCs) from this report will be sent to your MISP instance.

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1B_OPJ02FsG-lfHbfEJER0eub1NOgtxdHSVuhLcgVG3U/edit?tab=t.0

Malware Analysis Report AMAR-231099-1.v1 - BangkokShell Sophisticated malware was used to achieve cyber espionage objectives. TTC-CERT previously analyzed malware related to the BangkokShell campaign in "Malware Analysis Report AMAR-230499-1.v2 - BangkokShell," which readers can find on the TTC-CERT website.² Upon examining the suspicious files, TTC-CERT found that the Loader and Payload files were created in February 2021 (Compile Date). The malware files found in Malware Analysis Report AMAR-230499-1.v2 - BangkokShell (https://drive.google.com/file/d/1o2uSDksXRG8RPTn7HW4jNCvuoPQMccxj/view) were created in December 2021. Based on this information, it can be estimated that the suspicious files used in this attack are an earlier version of the malware previously detected in Malware Analysis Report AMAR-230499-1.v2 - BangkokShell. However, the Compile Date found in this instance could have been modified by the attackers. In this attack, the process began with the use of DLL Side-loading to load a Dynamic Link Library (DLL) file named Lightshot.dll, which is a Loader-type malware. This Loader then deobfuscates the malware configuration embedded within the DLL file. It then loads a file named Arials.ttf from the filesystem into memory. This file is the obfuscated RahadRAT malware, which is subsequently deobfuscated using the XOR Cipher algorithm and executed in memory using the Reflective Code Loading technique.

Notification - Analysis report of a detected phishing page that changes according to the victim's email address, which was used in an attack against an organization in Thailand. This attack method was used against an organization in Thailand in early October 2023. The content of the phishing email lures victims into believing their user account will be closed due to an unresolved error with the organization's application. The email instructs victims to click a link labeled "RESOLVE ISSUE NOW" to keep their user account active. The phishing page linked in the email is designed to steal the victim's user account and password. Notification - Analysis Report on Current Infostealer Attack Trend Development. The TTC-CERT Center has found that attackers are still using Infostealer or Information-stealing malware to install on victims' computers and/or mobile devices. It is designed to search for and steal sensitive or important victim information. The stolen information can be sent to the attacker in several ways, depending on how the attacker designed the Infostealer, such as via email, Telegram, Web Protocol, or accessed through the Infostealer's Web Portal. Attackers often target credentials for online financial transaction accounts, social media websites, email, or File Transfer Protocol (FTP) accounts.

Notification - Analysis Report on Mustang Panda Changing Attack Patterns and Methods Used Against Myanmar This report concerns the discovery of RAR files related to the attacker group known as “Mustang Panda” (also known as Bronze President, HoneyMyte, RedDelta, Red Lich, Earth Preta, PKPLUG, and TA416). Cybersecurity researchers claim this group operates from a Chinese-speaking Asian country and is supported by a Chinese-speaking government. They are believed to have been operating since 2012, targeting various organizations worldwide, including government agencies, think tanks, and NGOs, particularly in Southeast Asia, the United States, and Europe. The latest attack pattern report by TTC-CERT suggests this group continues to prioritize stealing critical information from government agencies in Southeast Asia.

Notification - Analysis report on the discovery of Infostealer specifically targeting Thai users. The Telecommunications Computer Emergency Response Team Coordination Center (TTC-CERT) has been closely monitoring and tracking malware used in attacks against Thai citizens. During routine open-source intelligence (OSINT) research on the internet, the TTC-CERT discovered the website hxxps://sites.google.com/view/documentfb being used to distribute files containing Infostealer malware. The website is written in Thai and entices users to download files from links within the site. The TTC-CERT believes the attackers created this website specifically to target Thai users. The Infostealer malware used in this attack is capable of stealing data from web browsers, such as passwords, cookies, and browsing history. It can also steal sessions from various applications, including Discord, Telegram, Instagram, Twitter, Reddit, and Tiktok. Furthermore, the malware can steal information related to the victim's crypto wallet and collect basic information about the target computer, such as computer name, operating system version, and RAM size. This data is then exfiltrated via Discord Webhook and the attacker's Command and Control (C2) server. Details of the overall infection chain are illustrated in Figure 1.

Analysis report on the changing Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures (TTPs) of threat actors targeting Thai Android OS mobile phone users. The TTC-CERT has observed changes in the TTPs of threat actors targeting Thai Android OS mobile phone users. They trick victims into downloading and installing an Android Remote Access Trojan (RAT) to steal money from their mobile banking applications. For almost a year, this group has continuously targeted Thai Android OS users, employing the same techniques to trick victims into installing the Android RAT. They send SMS messages containing a URL which redirects victims to a webpage displaying a Line application QR code. This lures victims into adding a chat channel, allowing direct communication with the threat actors via the Line application. The threat actors then ask for the victim's name and phone number, subsequently sending a URL for downloading the Android RAT through the Line chat. If the victim installs the application, the threat actors steal their transaction data and use it to steal money from their accounts by transferring funds to mule accounts.

https://drive.google.com/file/d/14OdsocsRVK6osG3TLxyGSB0fJZaaS2fK/view

Alert - Detection Report of the BangkokShell Campaign Specifically Targeting Organizations in Thailand The TTC-CERT has examined several suspicious files received from a Thai security agency and found that all files are part of a cyberattack specifically targeting Thailand. The attack utilizes sophisticated malware to achieve cyber espionage objectives. The TTC-CERT has named this campaign BangkokShell. Overall, the BangkokShell campaign leverages open-source projects to develop attack tools and employs various anti-detection measures such as Dynamic API Resolution, Indirect Calls, stackstrings, and multiple encryption types. The BangkokShell attack process begins with DLL Side-loading to load obfuscated shellcode into the process memory before deobfuscating it. It then uses Reflective Code Loading to load and execute the payload, a Remote Access Trojan (RAT), without leaving any traces on the filesystem. TTC-CERT refers to this payload as RahadRAT. Analysis reveals interesting self-protection mechanisms, including password authentication support and the use of the CRC-16/XMODEM algorithm to verify data exchanged between the malware and the Command and Control (C2) server. It supports 14 C2 commands designed to control and collect data from the target computer before obfuscating it with the RC4 (Rivest Cipher 4) algorithm and sending it to the C2.

https://drive.google.com/file/d/1duMUPRnScd4pA2esC6ObcCTe99Sw2r5j/view

Inside the zip file is a Microsoft Word file larger than 500 MB. This Word file contains malicious macros. If the victim opens the Word file and enables macros, the victim's computer is instructed to download a zip file from a URL embedded in the macro. This downloaded zip file contains an .dll file larger than 500 MB, which is the Emotet Epoch4 malware. Infection chains details...

Malware Analysis Report AMAR-230199-1.v1 - Fake_Pulse_Secure_CobaltStrike_Loader The TTC-CERT center received cyber threat intelligence indicating that between 2021 and 2022, threat actors targeted organizations in Thailand using a Portable Document Format (PDF) file named "Pulse secure Update announcement.pdf". This file impersonated an organization in the Thai telecommunications sector. The content, written in Thai, warned about a security vulnerability and advised victims to install software named "Pulse secure for 64-bit Windows" or "Pulse secure for 32-bit Windows". Pulse Connect Secure Update announcement The Cybersecurity Department has detected a vulnerability in the Pulse Connect Secure (PC) program. Please update the software immediately. Download the program according to your Windows OS version: Pulse secure for 64-bit Windows (Supports Windows 7, Windows 8 and Windows 10) Pulse secure for 32-bit Windows (Supports Windows XP) Cybersecurity Department The TTC-CERT center collected files related to this attack from open sources for analysis. It was found that the files linked within the PDF are Self-extracting archives (SFX). These archives drop four files onto the filesystem: libcurl.dll, gup.xml, Juniper.exe, and JuniperSetup.exe. The Juniper.exe (masqueraded gup.exe) and libcurl.dll (malicious) files are then used in a DLL Side-loading attack technique.

Magniber Ransomware Analysis Report uses a 5G theme to spread through fake Windows Updates. On January 13, 2023, the TC-CERT Center detected activity from attackers associated with Magniber Ransomware. In this campaign, the attackers targeted victims by sending phishing emails with malicious attachments, tricking victims into opening the attached iso file (a disk image file). This iso file contains malicious files. This time, the attackers used a 5G theme to spread Magniber Ransomware through a Microsoft Software Installer (msi) file, which mimics a Windows Update. The TC-CERT Center believes that the attackers used phishing emails with iso file attachments or typosquatting attacks, which exploit user errors when entering domain names in the browser address bar. This aims to attack a wide range of users. If victims are not careful and open the malicious file, their computers will be instructed to install the malware, resulting in important files being encrypted by Magniber Ransomware. The attackers then demand a ransom. The iso file that the TTC-CERT Center analyzed for this Magniber Ransomware attack campaign is: SHA-256: 4dcbcc070e7e3d0696c777b63e185406e3042de835b734fe7bb33Cc12e539bf6 In analyzing this campaign, the author found that the attackers carried out the attack according to this overall pattern.

Malware Analysis Report AMAR-221199-1.v1 - 2022_Bookworm_Malware The TTC-CERT center has analyzed a suspicious file received from a security agency in Thailand. Preliminary analysis (triage) found strong evidence that the file is Bookworm malware. Comparing the techniques, tactics, procedures (TTPs) of the suspicious file and payload with Bookworm malware showed a high degree of consistency. Bookworm malware was first discovered in 2015 by researchers at Palo Alto Networks. However, the suspicious file examined in this instance is a Bookworm malware variant with significantly altered TTPs. Furthermore, as of the date of this report (November 26, 2022), no antivirus product has been able to identify the suspicious file as Bookworm malware.

Preliminary Malware Analysis Report IMAR-220999-1.v1 - Agenda Golang Ransomware The TTC-CERT Center has analyzed a suspicious file received from the National Cyber Security Committee (NCSC). Preliminary information indicates that the file was found in the %Public% directory on a server hosting Active Directory (AD) and was attacked by ransomware. Static and Behavior Analysis revealed that the file is ransomware developed using the Golang language. TTC-CERT suspects the attackers chose Golang because its source code can be compiled into binaries for various operating systems like Windows, Linux, and macOS, saving development time. Furthermore, malware compiled with the Golang compiler can run on target machines with minimal reliance on operating system APIs, increasing the likelihood of successful attacks while leaving fewer traces compared to scripting languages like Python. This ransomware is configured to target specific victims and has various capabilities beyond encrypting files on the target machine. It can also encrypt files stored on network drives connected to the target computer and directs victims to pay the ransom through the attacker's website on the Tor network. Other capabilities identified through behavior analysis include the ability to accept parameters from Registry Keys, resulting in different behaviors based on the defined parameters. The malware can also delete Shadow Copies to prevent system or data recovery. Additionally, it can disable numerous Windows Services and Processes related to security, including the capability to attack via Network and Local Accounts with Administrator privileges.

https://drive.google.com/file/d/1Gn6ReZxBsNZzLPw5GbqyIXiMxI7mgz4G/view

Exploiting Shortened URLs and URL redirection to conceal phishing attacks. TTC-CERT has observed attacks targeting organizations in Thailand utilizing Shortened URL services and/or Open Redirect vulnerabilities on various websites for URL redirection to conceal phishing attacks. TTC-CERT assesses that the threat actors are likely testing phishing attacks using URL shortening and URL redirection simultaneously to plan further attack stages. This URL forwarding method is a common tactic abused by cybercriminals to create multi-layered phishing attacks. In this report, TTC-CERT has also conducted analysis to identify additional attacker infrastructure that could be used in attacks of this nature. Furthermore, TTC-CERT has updated the Indicators of Compromise (IOCs) for this attack and the attacker infrastructure that could be used in these attacks, so that member organizations can use this information to their advantage. However, if member organizations are connected to TTC-CERT's Malware Information Sharing Platform (MISP), this information will be automatically sent to your organization's MISP.

Preliminary Malware Analysis Report IMAR-220199-2.v1 - Public_Health_Sector_Incident_01 The TTC-CERT Center has examined malware files received from an official of the National Cyber Security Agency via email, which reported the detection of malware files on a server in a Public Health Sector agency. The TTC-CERT Center examined a total of 11 files. Of these, 4 were identified as legitimate files: PwmTower.exe and nw_elf.dll from TrendMicro, brcc32.exe which is the Borland Resource Compiler, and consent.exe from the Microsoft Windows operating system. There were 3 malware files of the Dynamic-Link Library (DLL) type: nw.dll, rw32core.dll, and Secur32.dll. These files are used in a DLL Side-Loading attack technique. The analysis found that all 3 DLL files (nw.dll, rw32core.dll, and Secur32.dll) have the same behavior: they are Decryptors and Loaders. Their purpose is to deobfuscate the payload embedded within the file using a hardcoded XOR key and then execute the payload. This operates as Fileless Malware, meaning these payload files are not written to the computer's storage but run only in memory. There are 3 deobfuscated payloads: nw_decrypted_payload.exe, 32core_decrypted_payload.exe, and Secur32_decrypted_payload.exe (or BeCtrl.exe).

APT32 or OceanLotus activity analysis report: changes in tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTP) The TC-CERT center has detected activity from the group APT32 or OceanLotus. This activity shows a change in the group's attack tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) from previous methods (the old method was reported in the preliminary malware analysis report IMAR-210432-1./1). This new attack method was first used in the first quarter of 2022 and continues to be used to the present (as of June 15, 2022). While analyzing the activities of APT32, the author found that APT32 operates as summarized below: According to a Netskope report, APT32 has been using Web Page Archive files (".mht" or ".mhtml") which embed malicious Word Documents (Maldocs). When these files are opened, they install a backdoor and establish a connection to a Command and Control (C2) server located on the Glitch website, a public web development collaboration platform. The malware has the capability to collect information from the infected computer and send it to the C2, such as network adapter information, user account data, file and folder information, and running process details.

Analysis Report of a Phishing Campaign Targeting Organizations in Thailand to Install Emotet Trojan on Victims' Computers The TTC-CERT center received a report from an organization that malicious actors sent phishing emails to employees within the organization to install the Emotet Trojan Epoch 5 onto victims' computers. In this attack, the malicious actors used typical Emotet attack methods by sending phishing emails, spoofing the sender's email address to appear as if it came from an actual employee of an organization in Thailand who works in a field that interacts with the targeted organization. It is suspected that the personal information used in the lure likely came from social media research. While analyzing this campaign, the author found that the malicious actors carried out the following steps: Emotet Unzip Phishing with zip file attachment (with password) d 336636.zip TXLS d 336636.xls Decode & Download hxxp://hathaabeach[.jcom/documents/xbZxXi/ hxxp://tekstiluzmangorusu[.]com/wp-admin/VThSCtERM5Hj/ hxxp://zhivir[.Jcom/wp/yrqupT1QwXuRdX3/ Execute regsvr32 exe Execute Emotet hhwe1.ocx or hhwe2.ocx or hhwe3.ocx The TC-CERT center assesses that there is a high probability that the malicious actors specifically targeted the victim organization, particularly those involved in cybersecurity, to install the Emotet Trojan Epoch 5 onto their computers.

Destructive Malware Attack Analysis Summary Report targeting various organizations in Ukraine over the past week. The TTC-CERT has observed cyber threat alerts stemming from the Russia-Ukraine conflict, particularly attacks using destructive malware targeting various organizations in Ukraine. It is suspected that the objective is to destroy computer systems and render them unusable. Cyberattacks with this objective against Ukrainian organizations are likely to increase and may unintentionally spread to organizations in other countries. Therefore, the TTC-CERT recommends that organizations seriously consider strengthening their cybersecurity posture, increase vigilance, enhance cyberattack prevention measures using information from this report, and prepare incident response plans to protect their information systems from cyberattacks. The TTC-CERT has compiled a list of Indicators of Compromise (IOCs) and Yara Rules for TTC-CERT members to use for their benefit. If your organization is connected to the TTC-CERT's Malware Information Sharing Platform (MISP), this information will be automatically sent to your organization's MISP.

Exploitation of Apache HTTP Server vulnerabilities originating from a Thai university network. TTC-CERT has detected exploitation attempts targeting Apache HTTP Server vulnerabilities (CVE-2021-42013 and CVE-2021-41773) originating from the network of a Thai university (202.28.2501.1118 and 202.28.250[.1122) between October 19, 2021, 17:03:22 (UTC) and October 23, 2021, 05:06:21 (UTC). There is credible evidence suggesting the attackers aimed to exploit these vulnerabilities to install cryptocurrency mining software. TTC-CERT has compiled a list of Indicators of Compromise (IOCs) and is regularly updating information related to these exploits. This information is available to readers and members for organizational use. If your organization is connected to TTC-CERT's MISP (Malware Information Sharing Platform), this data will be automatically sent to your organization's MISP instance. Vulnerabilities CVE-2021-42013 and CVE-2021-41773: Around October 4-7, 2021, the Apache Software Foundation released a security advisory regarding CVE-2021-42013 and CVE-2021-41773. These are Path Traversal vulnerabilities that could allow unauthenticated remote code execution on unpatched, affected versions of Apache HTTP Server. Following the security advisory, a significant increase in scans targeting these vulnerabilities was observed across the internet. TTC-CERT has collected data on these scans and exploitation attempts to study attacker behavior. This article analyzes the attacker's payload, the attack pattern, and summarizes the Indicators of Compromise (IOCs) to aid organizations in detection and prevention.

Malware Analysis Report IMAR-210499-3.v1 - Redosdru:Coinminer The TTC-CERT Center has examined the Executable file related to the malware file mentioned in the "AMAR-210499-1./1 - Redosdru" report. The file (iexplore.exe, SHA256: E76E513ED31C0013B2616C593855E1C1C8EF9314A017D4CCC536708BFCFA3B20) is a Trojan-type malware that functions as a Coinminer. Its purpose is to utilize the target computer's resources to mine the Monero cryptocurrency using the XMRig tool, which is an open-source tool for controlling resource usage. The results are then sent to a Mining Pool website. The analysis reveals that the attacker employed relatively unique techniques in developing this malware. This information can be used to develop an Adversary Profile. For example: - The attacker relies heavily on imitation naming techniques, mimicking the names of legitimate files and services of the Windows operating system, including Google domain names. - The technique of using the Ping command via cmd.exe to delay the execution flow. - The technique of uninstalling the program via Registry Key by specifying a CLSID value with high uniqueness. - Naming Exports Functions using highly unique words.

Malware Analysis Report AMAR-210499-1.v1 Malware Analysis Report - Redosdru TTC-CERT has detected a cyber attack originating from a Thai IP address targeting port 445. There were continuous attempts to upload a suspicious file to the target machine. We collected and analyzed the file and found it to be Trojan-Downloader malware in the form of a DLL file (.dll). When executed or injected into a process, it downloads a payload from a Command and Control server onto the target machine and then executes the payload. Analysis shows that the DLL file has characteristics that match the Redosdru malware family. TTC-CERT has created a Yara Rule to detect this malware, which members can use to immediately scan for suspicious files.

Preliminary Malware Analysis Report IMAR-210432-1.v1 Malware Analysis Report - OceanLotus - Hoa don tien no.zip TTC-CERT has investigated Threat Intelligence data and found activities of the APT32 (OceanLotus) group, believed to be a hacker group from a neighboring country targeting countries in Southeast Asia. We collected suspicious files from data sources and performed a preliminary analysis. We found that the attackers used techniques to disguise PE and DLL files to resemble legitimate Microsoft Office files. They signed these files with expired certificates and used DLL side-loading techniques to evade detection and execute multi-stage shellcode. They also communicate with a Command and Control server, which is a Dynamic DNS, via port 443 (TCP). If successful, the attackers may be able to install Cobalt Strike on the target machine to control it and carry out further operations.

International Cooperation: Welcomes EU Eastern Partnership Delegation for a Study Visit to its Headquarters The European Union Agency for Cybersecurity () opened its doors in Athens to cybersecurity representatives from Armenia, Azerbaijan, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. The study visit of the delegation to is a key part of the EU’s Cybersecurity East Project . Launched in 2019, the project intends to support Eastern partnership countries in developing their cyber capacities and legislative framework and promoting the compatibility and approximation of legal frameworks, best practices and cooperation. The representatives presented to the assessment of their current cyber threat landscape and gave an account of some of the specific cybersecurity and security challenges they faced. Further points of discussion covered approaches to cybercrime and cybersecurity and the general role and structures of within the EU’s cybersecurity set-up. The project is part of the E astern Partnership (EaP), a joint policy initiative designed to promote EU values, policies, best practices and interest in these neighbouring countries and ultimately strengthen the cooperation between the European Union (EU), the EU Member States and the Eastern countries involved. https://www.enisa.europa.eu/news/enisa-news/ranking-voting-online-risks-of-reputation-systems-in-new-report

Ranking & voting online; privacy risks of reputation systems analysed in new report Ranking & voting online; privacy risks of reputation systems in new Agency report. Reputation systems are a key success factor of many websites, e.g. eBay, or Amazon, ranking hotels, films, or music, enabling users and customers to vote on products. This gives consumers a better idea of the information, products and services being provided. However, by using reputation systems, citizens place themselves at additional risk. These privacy risks include: - exposing personal data - facilitating the targeting of advertising against themselves - risking price discrimination - website providers sharing the reputation data they provide - the level of trust placed in the reputation score exceeding the actual level of trust-worthiness - vendors and service providers monitoring reputation systems for poor reputation scores to identity and rectify potential customer issues - the linking of user identities across multiple sites through the use of advanced analytics. This study revealed a significant difference between the real-life implementation of reputation systems and current academic research. The reputation systems being deployed are primarily concerned with facilitating and promoting business transactions. The academic research into privacy and trust solutions for reputation systems does not appear to be considered, in order to embed the research in operational systems. Five core area of risks for users This study also identifies conclusions in five core areas regarding reputation systems’ risks for users of reputation systems and the trustworthiness of the resulting scores, customer communications regarding such systems, and the lack of clarity over the governing legislation; Mitigating security risks posed by reputation systems. Trustworthiness of reputation scores Consumer communications Applicable legislation Linkability For full report

New report on Cyber Crisis Cooperation and Management publishes today a new report on "Cyber Crisis Cooperation and Management". The report contains a comparative study on the cyber crisis management and the general crisis management. The purpose of the study is twofold: to compare the concepts from general crisis management systems with the corresponding systems related to cyber crisis management, and to conduct a conceptual analysis of the language and terminology within these two fields, covering for their structures, scope and actions. ’s Executive Director Professor Udo Helmbrecht has been appointed Chairman of AISEC In a unanimous vote, the Board of Trustees of Germany’s Fraunhofer Research Institution for Applied and Integrated Security (AISEC) has appointed Executive Director of Professor Udo Helmbrecht as their Chairman for a three year term. Professor Helmbrecht commented: “It is with great honour that I accept the Chair of the Board of Trustees at AISEC. It is my goal to achieve visibility and implementation for AISEC’s work while promoting research and development and forming strategic partnerships. I look forward to this new role which I am positive will be exciting and highly effective.” Background Information: Professor Udo Helmbrecht has been the Executive Director of since October 2009. At the end of 2010, he received the title of Honorary Professor at the Bundeswehr University in Munich. Fraunhofer AISEC , mainly focuses on applied research for the development of application-oriented security solutions and their custom integration in existing systems. Time to advise Europe on security Call for new Experts to the EU Agency ’s Permanent Stakeholders’ Group Do you feel you have the competence to be one of the Experts advising ? The European Network and Information Security Agency, i.e. the EU Agency , is launching the call for new members to its Permanent Stakeholders’ Group ( PSG ). The PSG advises the Executive Director in e.g. drawing up a proposal for the Agency’s work programme, and all issues related thereto. The PSG will be composed of thirty leading Experts in Network and Information Security. The PSG Members should represent relevant stakeholders, e.g: information and communication technologies industry, consumer and user organisations, as well as academic and research institutions. The selected applicants will be appointed ad personam as PSG Members. They do neither represent a country nor a company. Applicants should provide the Executive Director with the details of their professional experience and level of expertise, i.a. a summary of qualifications , a detailed CV in English in the European format http://europass.cedefop.europa.eu/ ; as well as a separate letter of motivation explaining how they intend to contribute to the mandate of the PSG . , see Art 8.) THE CALL WAS CLOSED ON 30 NOVEMBER 2009. The Executive Director will take the following criteria into consideration while assessing the applications: proven abilities in the fields relevant to the mandate of the PSG; capacity to contribute to issues that relate to the Agency’s tasks the ability to cover a wide range of expertise in information and communication technology industries. The mandate of the forthcoming PSG will run from February 2010 until July 2012. More details on the PSG.

NIS Cooperation group and knowledge building meetings concluded in Athens This week , the European Union Agency for Cybersecurity, hosted two NIS Cooperation Group (CG) meetings in Athens and two knowledge-building days for experts working at competent authorities under the NIS (Security of Network and Information Systems) Directive. The first group NIS Cooperation meeting, NIS CG Work Stream 5 is a working group of competent authorities for digital services under the NIS Directive, i.e. online marketplaces, online search engines, and cloud services. The second, NIS CG Work Stream 10 is a group of competent authorities for digital infrastructure under the NIS Directive, i.e. the internet exchanges, the domain name system, and the top-level domains. During this joint session, organised a small exercise to discuss cooperation and collaboration, cross-sector and cross-border, because both groups of experts are dealing with operators and enterprises with digital infrastructure across the EU, often operating across borders. Different breakout groups reported a number of challenges, mainly on the alignment and communication between the national authorities supervising operators and providers across the EU. will follow up on the results of this exercise in the coming months, together with the groups. also organised two knowledge-building days for experts working at competent authorities under the NIS Directive. At the start of the week, a network expert from RIPE NCC gave a seminar on internet infrastructure. At the end of the week, offered a full day seminar on cloud security. Background This work is done under 's Annual work program output O.2.2.2 "Supporting the NIS Cooperation Group". The publication of the NIS Cooperation group can be found on the European Commission's website. More information about the national authorities per sector, across the EU, can be found in the online NIS Directive tool.

hosts the Assembly of Agency Staff Committees (AASC) meeting On 7-8 May, hosted to the twice-yearly meeting of the Assembly of Agency Staff Committees (AASC). The Assembly, set up in 2001, brings together staff representatives from 23 EU Agencies and assimilated bodies. The Agencies tasks are as diverse as those of the Office for Harmonization in the Internal Market (Trade Marks and Designs) ‘OHIM’ in Alicante; the European Medicines Agency in London, the European Aviation Safety Agency in Cologne, etc. As a decentralized part of the EU administration, the Agencies focus on specific tasks, and have more than 4,000 European Union staff. Their staff representatives created AASC as a platform for information exchange and as an instrument to create common positions to be voiced vis-a-vis the central institutions in Brussels. Moreover, they ensure that the staff of the Agencies have their rightful place within the European Civil Service. The Secretary of the Assembly meeting, Mr Gregor Schneider of OHIM, commented: ‘The good ambiance in has inspired discussions and helped the participants to obtain different views and perspectives to better our activities and support to staff members in EU bodies all over Europe.’ The AASC meeting featured a guest speaker; Mr Professor Blanpain, who is a renowned labour law expert from the University of Leuven. Mr Blanpain analysed the employment models of the Agencies against the background of international labour law.

https://www.enisa.europa.eu/news/enisa-news/enisa-releases-online-nis-directive-tool-showing-per-sector-the-national-authorities-for-operators-of-essential-services-and-digital-service-providers

releases online NIS Directive tool showing per sector the national authorities for operators of essential services and digital service providers Today releases an interactive tool showing the relevant national laws and regulations, and per sector and subsector the national authorities supervising the NIS Directive. The NIS Directive tool is intended as a one-stop shop for experts from the industry linking to relevant work, national cybersecurity strategies, the CSIRT network, and the NIS Cooperation group website. This year all EU member states are implementing the NIS directive in their countries. The NIS Directive is the first piece of EU-wide cybersecurity legislation, proposed by the European Commission as part of the EU Cybersecurity strategy. EU directives give EU member states flexibility to take into account national circumstances, for example to re-use existing organizational structures or to integrate with existing national legislation. That also means that the authorities and laws are different from country to country and from sector to sector. Every country designates different supervisory authorities. For the industry and cybersecurity experts, it is important to know the relevant national authorities and laws under the NIS Directive in their subsector. This online tool takes you directly to the supervising authorities in each sector. The tool, being sector-specific, complements the European Commission's online map showing the transposition status per EU member state. will update this tool following the developments in the EU Member States.

Commissioner Mariya Gabriel visits The Commissioner, today, met with the Executive Director Professor Dr. Udo Helmbrecht and the staff for a discussion on the current and future role of the Agency in the cybersecurity of Europe. welcomed, for the first time, the visit of the Commissioner for Digital Economy and Society, Ms. Mariya Gabriel, in the Agency’s premises in Athens. The timing of the visit is particularly opportune in that the Commission published last week a new proposed Draft EU Cybersecurity Act for a permanent and stronger mandate for as well as a new EU cybersecurity strategy. The meeting provided an opportunity to meet the staff of and to discuss how the European Commission sees the future role of and the cybersecurity landscape in Europe. Other important issues discussed included a coordinated response between stakeholders to large scale cross border cyber incidents (the Blueprint), cyber exercises as well as cooperation and coordination of cyber activities between the Member States. Speaking at the meeting with the staff, Commissioner Mariya Gabriel said “I am very happy to see such a young, engaged and committed team working in to help secure the European cyberspace”. The Executive Director of , Professor Dr. Udo Helmbrecht said “we welcome the opportunity to discuss the proposal of the Commission on the new Cybersecurity Act for a reformed and stronger EU Cybersecurity Agency here in Greece and I would like to thank Commissioner Gabriel for her support. I look forward to the proposed Cybersecurity Act being debated in the Council and the EU Parliament in the next few months.”

https://www.enisa.europa.eu/news/enisa-news/cyber-europe-2012-2013-first-results-show-success

Cyber Europe 2012 – first results show success ’s initial findings from Europe’s biggest ever cyber security test show that the exercise was a success. Cyber Europe 2012 was a day-long simulated cyber attack on Europe’s critical information infrastructures. It was used to analyse how participating countries’ and private sector organisations would cooperate in the event of a real large-scale attack. ’s headline observations from the “hot wash” exercise review session held today (05/10/2012) are: There was frequent cooperation and information exchange between public and private sector organisations Public-Private cooperation structure differed per country Some countries responded by upscaling their national crisis cells/crisis plans/crisis structures Some countries suffered from real incidents besides the CE2012 exercise Familiarity with procedures is crucial for building a fast and effective response capability across Europe There is a need for close understanding between players and a need to be able to communicate quickly with key contacts in national authorities and the private sector The inclusion of private sector organisations as players was an excellent addition. Their input and experience helped build realistic scenarios and make exercise highly effective on the day. (Most Critical Information Infrastructure is owned by the private sector.)  Overall, there were approx. 60 banks and 60 ISPs taking part in the various countries. Simulations were highly realistic. Players were under pressure so as to assess how this would affect cooperation Conclusions from the exercise will be considered by the European Commission and Member States in drafting Europe’s Cyber Security Strategy plans to produce its Cyber Europe 2012 exercise report by the end of the year

Discussions touched upon many of the topics covered by the MoU between , CERT EU, EDA and EC3 and also allowed the two organisations to share lessons learned in the areas of cybersecurity exercises and training. Approaches to threat/risk analysis and evaluation of future technology challenges were also discussed. The EUMS is the source of the military expertise within the European External Action Service (EEAS). The role of the EUMS is to provide early warning, situation assessment, strategic planning, communications and information systems, concept development, training & education, and support of partnerships.

Full overview of cyber security auditing schemes has conducted a preliminary study on the auditing frameworks for cyber security measures, providing 7 recommendations/ remarks on the common characteristics of the schemes. In this report, presents an overview of existing auditing frameworks. These auditing frameworks are used in different setting and across different sectors (energy, finance etc), and are aiming at ensuring that providers comply with specific cyber security requirements.  This work is undertaken in the context of incident reporting and minimum security measures for the telecommunications sector. All  twelve schemes are described in detail, presenting the process, the roles and the features of each scheme also by providing comprehensive visuals. Outcome: The outcome of this report is a set of 7 recommendations and a single auditing model that captures the most common features, creating this way a preliminary meta-framework. This report can be a good reference point, since it offers a complete overview of international auditing schemes. For full report: Schemes for Auditing Security Measures

https://www.enisa.europa.eu/news/enisa-news/enisas-fifth-industry-event

’s fifth Industry Event allowed a fruitful discussion with the NIS industry community ’s fifth Industry Event engaged EU based small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), mid-cap companies and start-ups, and focused on business opportunities in cybersecurity and EU financial mechanisms. The event that took place on the 3 rd of October is the fifth since its inception in 2015. The scope was stimulating the development of the EU network and information security (NIS) industry. ’s Head of Core Operations, Dr Steve Purser explained: “The objective of this second 2017 event is to inform SMEs about trends in the policy environment and to discuss how to develop business cases that leverage these trends”. Attended by industry experts and following up on the Industry Event that took place in March 2017, it aimed at building an effective industry cybersecurity community by actively involving SMEs, Mid-Caps companies and start-ups as well as public and private security partners in the EU representing the NIS industry. The event aimed to: follow up on EU funding mechanisms and present previous work on the economics of cybersecurity, and secondly, introduce a pragmatic discussion on business opportunities of current and future EU regulation and policy framework related to cyber security (like GDPR, SME programs, among others) During the event, the speakers shared best practices and engaged in an open discussion with the audience in order to define a common position. Venture capital, accelerator programs (both public and private), as well as approaches on how to stimulate the cybersecurity market were amongst the main topics that were tackled. In addition, representatives presented the SME community with the Agency’s recent studies on the NIS market in the EU and put an emphasis on possible business opportunities. will continue in its efforts to deliver high-quality information and support to the stakeholders.

https://www.enisa.europa.eu/news/enisa-news/analysis-of-2018operation-black-tulip2019-certificate-authorities-lose-authority

Analysis of ‘Operation Black Tulip’: Certificate authorities lose authority The Agency releases its analysis of the Diginotar- ‘Operation Black Tulip’ case, where a digital certificate authority suffered a cyber-attack. In the attack, false certificates were created for hundreds of websites, including Google and Skype. Reports indicate that the cyber-attack started in mid-June, and that for two months, false certificates were used to eavesdrop on users in Iran. In its new analysis , the Agency identifies three major issues, and suggests remedies to these.

https://www.enisa.europa.eu/news/enisa-news/challenges-of-security-certification-in-emerging-ict-environments

Challenges of security certification in emerging ICT environments N/A issues today its report on the Challenges of security certification in emerging ICT environments . The report is targeted at EU Member States (MS), the Commission, certification bodies and the private sector, and provides a thorough description of the cyber security certification status concerning the most critical equipment in various critical business sectors. The study contains information on the certification of devices in five business sectors namely, electricity, healthcare, information and communication technology, railway and water transport. It describes the situation in the EU, and discusses the advantages and challenges towards a more harmonised certification practice. The key finding of the report, is that every sector has its own functional and security challenges, which makes the target of a common certification framework a challenge in itself. Based on desk research and expert validation, an analysis is done to study the existing frameworks and standards, and to identify certification drivers, best practices and candidate products for certification of the five selected sectors. Finally an aggregated table is provided, which shortly reflects the certification drivers, the market situation and the recommendation for certification for each identified device. For the full report For  interviews and press inquiries please contact press@.europa.eu , Tel. +30 2814 409576

https://www.enisa.europa.eu/news/enisa-news/fourth-internet-governance-forum-in-egypt

Fourth Internet Governance Forum in Egypt Dr. Steve Purser represented in two panel discussions at the Internet Governance Forum in Egypt. In the first panel, entitled ‘Balancing the need for security and the concerns for civil liberties’ he stressed the point that this issue will not be solved by regulation alone and that it is important to use a combination of techniques to achieve a sensible balance between security and civil liberties. In his concluding remarks, he noted that the panel had identified three types of activity that could sensibly contribute to achieving such a balance: Helping citizens to develop simple risk management techniques for the  electronic world (electronic common sense). Appropriate use of technology. Regulation. He also stressed the fact that context is extremely important when designing security solutions and that rules driven or check-list approaches are no substitute for clear thinking. In the second panel on the subject of net neutrality, Dr. Purser explained why security should be seen as a necessary condition for neutrality and went on to explain what is doing to support the Member States and the Commission in the area of Internet resilience. He noted that a key success factor in securing the Internet of the future will be the extent to which different communities are able to work together to achieve common goals and cited the European Public Private Partnership for Resilience (EP3R) as a practical example of efforts to form such a partnerships.

https://www.enisa.europa.eu/news/enisa-news/launch-of-european-cyber-security-month-logo

Launch of European Cyber Security Month logo Launch of European Cyber Security Month logo The Agency is launching the European Cyber Security Month (ECMS) logo , unveiling the project's visual identity to improve the visibility and recognition, which will make the ECSM easier to promote. This logo introduces a human factor, which is a key element  for successful cyber security. The European Security Month is also a sort of celebration: an event, a meeting of people gathered into a network. Elements of the logo; The shape is a synthetic representation of a person in profile - the user. This user is at the heart of the web, represented by the crisscrossing lines in the background. The circular shape around the head of the user suggest protection. The logo as a whole (typography included) can also be viewed as a key, further suggesting security. The four lines of the text being the grooves (tooth) of the key, while the negative head shape is the bow of the key. Colours: The colours recall the European Union flag colours. The logo will soon be available in all 23 official EU languages, and appear on all branding material that will be created for the European Cyber Security Month ECSM . Background and further ECSM material for involved stakeholders and Member States awareness raising organisation and bodies.

https://www.enisa.europa.eu/news/enisa-news/call-for-experts-for-transsec-transport-resilience-and-security-expert-group

Call for experts for TRANSSEC - Transport Resilience and Security Expert Group launches this call for participation to invite experts in security of different sections of the transport sector to participate in its expert group. has established this expert group to cover security and resilience of transport systems as they undergo a digital transformation built around a plethora of interconnected devices and systems that facilitate automation and intelligent decision-making. The threats and risks associated with the digital transformation of the transport sector are manifold and have a potential impact on citizens’ safety, health and privacy, in addition to the availability of the critical transport services themselves. TRANSSEC is an information exchange platform that brings together experts to ensure security and resilience of the Transport sector in Europe. It is the intent of for this group to produce specialised work streams focusing on specific sub-sectors of transport, namely Air, Rail and Water Transport with the possibility of eventually establishing one or more specialised individual Expert Groups. Experts of the TRANSSEC shall have technical background expertise and direct exposure on one or more of the following: Operators and infrastructure owners of Transports systems with an interest in cybersecurity in one or more of the following sub-sectors: air transport e.g. air carriers, airports, traffic management control operators etc. rail transport e.g. infrastructure managers, service facilities etc. water transport e.g. water transport companies, ports, vessel traffic services etc.; Manufacturers or integrators of transport systems with a focus on cybersecurity; Suppliers and developers of transport hardware and/or software with a focus on cybersecurity; Associations and not-for-profit organisations involved in transport security; Relevant authorities, academia, standardisation bodies and policy makers directly involved in the above topics. For details and registration, please visit: https://resilience..europa.eu/transport-security .

https://www.enisa.europa.eu/news/enisa-news/enisa-director-helmbrecht-will-have-breakfast-meeting-with-mep-eva-kaili

Director Helmbrecht will have breakfast meeting with MEP Eva Kaili A breakfast meeting will be held on 22 March 2018 at the European Parliament to discuss about cybersecurity in the digital market. The event is organised by Eva Kaili, Member of the European Parliament, in partnership with the EU Cybersecurity Agency . Mariya Gabriel, European Commissioner for Digital Economy and Society, and Despina Spanou, Director for Digital Society, Trust and Cybersecurity within DG Connect, will participate in the discussions, which will focus on upcoming challenges and opportunities concerning cybersecurity in the European Union. Prof. Dr. Udo Helmbrecht, Executive Director of : “Cybersecurity in general and the proposed Cybersecurity Act in particular are and will be cornerstones for the European digital economy and society. It is therefore very important to discuss challenges and solutions with all interested stakeholders.” Political, industry and public sector key players are also invited to discuss the future of cybersecurity in relation to the proposed Act. Besides an introduction of the Cyber Act and the existing and future policy framework, the dialogue will focus on the opportunities and challenges of certification, the Internet of Things, and the ongoing development of ‘supercomputers’ and quantum computing.

https://www.enisa.europa.eu/news/enisa-news/towards-the-1st-pan-european-ciip-exercise

Towards the 1st Pan European CIIP exercise Member States achieved another significant step forward towards conducting the first pan European Exercise on Critical Information Infrastructure Protection (CIIP) at the 2nd workshop in Brussels, on 11, March. The exercises will be testing the efficiency of communication links and procedures in case of incidents affecting Internet's operation. Member States achieved another significant step forward towards conducting the first pan European Exercise on Critical Information Infrastructure Protection (CIIP). In the second workshop organised in Brussels on 11th of March by , EU’s Joint Research Centre (JRC), and the European Commission, EU Member States reaffirmed their commitment to participate in the first pan European Exercise on CIIP in accordance with the Tallinn Ministerial Declaration. Member States unanimously approved the high level scenario of the first pan European Exercise. The exercise will test the efficiency of communication links and procedures between different Member States in case of incidents affecting Internet’s normal operation in several countries. The impact of the incident and the response needed will require the cooperation and communication between different countries. The participants will have in their disposal all currently available means for finding related contacts in different countries. During the next months the team of planners will work on the details of the exercise, including the detailed scenario, as well as the training and evaluation material. The actual exercise is planned to take place in early November 2010. Stay tuned - subscribe to RSS feeds of news items http://www..europa.eu/media/news-items/news-wires/RSS

https://www.enisa.europa.eu/news/enisa-news/industry-collaboration-event-matching-supply-and-demand-in-eu-cybersecurity

Industry collaboration event: Matching supply and demand in EU cybersecurity held the third industry event on Friday 21st October. The workshop, which took place in Brussels, looks at matching supply and demand in EU cybersecurity. The focus is two-fold: to identify cybersecurity challenges and requirements in two key sectors, electronic payments and eHealth, and to explore to what extent suppliers of cybersecurity products and services are able to respond in a commercially neutral environment. In particular, objectives of the workshop include to: understand the challenges and cyber security requirements of the eHealth and ePayments industries showcase state-of-the-art approaches in the two topics match EU cybersecurity challenges and requirements with opportunities and capabilities explore what industry can offer (without discussing individual products) draft a list of concrete actions - after a ‘matching exercise’ - and communicate these to the relevant authorities The industry group was created by in an effort to compliment with discussions on implementation strategies and methods related to the current active policy debate on NIS themes. The particular event, brings together representatives from the European Commission, public and private entities, health, banking and IT sectors.  The aim is to generate a better understanding of challenges and requirements in these industries for potential suppliers, and to inform the consumer industries on potential solutions to respective issues. The overall goal is to ensure that policy makers are aware of the degree of effort and cost necessary to implement policy ideas, and conversely that the EU industry, whether acting as consumers or suppliers of cybersecurity products and services, are able to get optimal benefit from these policies. takes a closer look in these two fields as the health sector, and in particular innovations related to e/m- Health, is increasingly considered as a critical infrastructure while the Payment Services Directive 2 (PSD2) is expected to  impact the security of payment services.

https://www.enisa.europa.eu/news/enisa-news/new-enisa-report-on-regulatory-and-non-regulatory-approaches-to-information-sharing

New Report on Regulatory and Non-regulatory Approaches to Information Sharing N/A publishes its report on “Cyber Security Information Sharing: An Overview of Regulatory and Non-regulatory Approaches”. identified three types of approaches to share information on cyber security incidents: 1) Traditional regulation 2) Alternative forms of regulation, such as self- and co-regulation 3) Other approaches to enable information sharing, such as information and education schemes. Some key findings are: The prevalence of traditional regulation, alternative forms of regulation (such as self- and co-regulation) and other approaches to enable information sharing on cyber incidents, varies from country to country The frequent use of alternative types of regulatory initiatives (co- and self-regulation) in the field of information sharing on cyber incidents Different regulatory and non-regulatory approaches bring different challenges with them Trust is a key element for the success of the information sharing on cyber incidents National and governmental CSIRTs play an important role in the field Background The study aims to present the regulatory and non-regulatory approaches of EU Member States as well as EEA and EFTA countries to share information on cyber incidents, the different sector regulation challenges of managing cyber security issues, and their key practices in addressing them. The primary target audience of this report are policy and law makers at EU and Member State level, the CSIRT community (in particular national and governmental CSIRTs), the law enforcement community and other operational communities. Full report available here : Cyber Security Information Sharing: An Overview of Regulatory and Non-regulatory Approaches For interviews and press enquiries please contact press@.europa.eu , Tel.+30 2814 409576

https://www.enisa.europa.eu/news/enisa-news/training-day-getting-ready-for-cyber-europe-2012

Training day: getting ready for Cyber Europe 2012 Today (26th of June 2012), cyber security experts from across Europe are meeting in Paris for an intense training day in preparation for Cyber Europe 2012 Cyber Europe 2012 is the 2 nd pan-European exercise on Critical Information Infrastructure Protection (CIIP). It builds on and ties together the extensive activities in the EU, at both national and European level, to improve the resilience of critical information infrastructures. The exercise will take place in the autumn. Exercises are an important mechanism to assess preparedness for cyber threats, natural disasters, and technology failures. They enable authorities to target specific weaknesses and increase cooperation among stakeholders. Exercises also identify interdependencies, stimulate continuity planning, and train and educate people. The Cyber Europe 2012 exercise scenario will be based on large-scale cyber incidents where critical information infrastructure is affected across Europe. Policy Context Supporting EU-wide cyber-security preparedness exercises is one of the actions foreseen by the Digital Agenda for Europe to enhance online trust and security - see IP/10/581, MEMO/10/199 and MEMO/10/200. It is also an important part of the efforts to enhance preparedness, security and resilience as laid out in the CIIP communication action plan - see COM(2009) 149 and COM(2011) 163. Organisers of Cyber Europe 2012 Cyber Europe 2012 is organised by the EU Member States and EFTA countries, and jointly supported by the European Network and Information Security Agency () and the EU’s Joint Research Centre (JRC).

Celebrating the European Data Protection Day: 28/01 European Data Protection Day, Saturday, 28th January, 2012. The European institutions and bodies and the Member States of the Council of Europe will, on Saturday, 28th January, celebrate the sixth European Data Protection Day. This date is chosen as a reminder of 28th January 1981, when the Council of Europe adopted Convention 108, the first legally binding international instrument related to data protection. To mark the day, the European Data Protection Supervisor ( EDPS ) has recorded a video message to focus on privacy and data protection as fundamental rights, and highlight the everyday processing of personal data and the risks. The video, with Mr Peter Hustinx (EDPS Supervisor) and Giovanni Buttarelli (EDPS Assistant Supervisor) is available here . Moreover, another EU-Agency, the EuroPol Cyber Crime Centre and Data Protection Office have produced a handy leaflet with tips to help you protect your data and prevent identity theft.
