Adversary-in-the-Middle: ARP Cache Poisoning is techniques, Adversaries may poison Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) caches to position themselves between the communication of two or more networked devices. This activity may be used to enable follow-on behaviors such as or . The ARP protocol is used to resolve IPv4 addresses to link layer addresses, such as a media access control (MAC) address. Devices in a local network segment communicate with each other by using link layer addresses. If a networked device does not have the link layer address of a particular networked device, it may send out a broadcast ARP request to the local network to translate the IP address to a MAC address. The device with the associated IP address directly replies with its MAC address. The networked device that made the ARP request will then use as well as store that information in its ARP cache. An adversary may passively wait for an ARP request to poison the ARP cache of the requesting device. The adversary may reply with their MAC address, thus deceiving the victim by making them believe that they are communicating with the intended networked device. For the adversary to poison the ARP cache, their reply must be faster than the one made by the legitimate IP address owner. Adversaries may also send a gratuitous ARP reply that maliciously announces the ownership of a particular IP address to all the devices in the local network segment. The ARP protocol is stateless and does not require authentication. Therefore, devices may wrongly add or update the MAC address of the IP address in their ARP cache. Adversaries may use ARP cache poisoning as a means to intercept network traffic. This activity may be used to collect and/or relay data such as credentials, especially those sent over an insecure, unencrypted protocol.

This may also enable follow-on behaviors such as or . DHCP is based on a client-server model and has two functionalities: a protocol for providing network configuration settings from a DHCP server to a client and a mechanism for allocating network addresses to clients. The typical server-client interaction is as follows: Adversaries may spoof as a rogue DHCP server on the victim network, from which legitimate hosts may receive malicious network configurations. For example, malware can act as a DHCP server and provide adversary-owned DNS servers to the victimized computers. Through the malicious network configurations, an adversary may achieve the AiTM position, route client traffic through adversary-controlled systems, and collect information from the client network. DHCPv6 clients can receive network configuration information without being assigned an IP address by sending a message to the multicast address. Adversaries may use their rogue DHCP server to respond to this request message with malicious network configurations. Rather than establishing an AiTM position, adversaries may also abuse DHCP spoofing to perform a DHCP exhaustion attack (i.e, ) by generating many broadcast DISCOVER messages to exhaust a network’s DHCP allocation pool.

Steal or Forge Kerberos Tickets: AS-REP Roasting is techniques, Adversaries may reveal credentials of accounts that have disabled Kerberos preauthentication by Kerberos messages. Preauthentication offers protection against offline . When enabled, a user requesting access to a resource initiates communication with the Domain Controller (DC) by sending an Authentication Server Request (AS-REQ) message with a timestamp that is encrypted with the hash of their password. If and only if the DC is able to successfully decrypt the timestamp with the hash of the user’s password, it will then send an Authentication Server Response (AS-REP) message that contains the Ticket Granting Ticket (TGT) to the user. Part of the AS-REP message is signed with the user’s password. For each account found without preauthentication, an adversary may send an AS-REQ message without the encrypted timestamp and receive an AS-REP message with TGT data which may be encrypted with an insecure algorithm such as RC4. The recovered encrypted data may be vulnerable to offline attacks similarly to and expose plaintext credentials. An account registered to a domain, with or without special privileges, can be abused to list all domain accounts that have preauthentication disabled by utilizing Windows tools like with an LDAP filter. Alternatively, the adversary may send an AS-REQ message for each user. If the DC responds without errors, the account does not require preauthentication and the AS-REP message will already contain the encrypted data. Cracked hashes may enable , , and via access to .

Remote Services: VNC is techniques, Adversaries may use to remotely control machines using Virtual Network Computing (VNC). VNC is a platform-independent desktop sharing system that uses the RFB ("remote framebuffer") protocol to enable users to remotely control another computer’s display by relaying the screen, mouse, and keyboard inputs over the network. VNC differs from as VNC is screen-sharing software rather than resource-sharing software. Remote Services: Distributed Component Object Model is techniques, Adversaries may use to interact with remote machines by taking advantage of Distributed Component Object Model (DCOM). The adversary may then perform actions as the logged-on user. The Windows Component Object Model (COM) is a component of the native Windows application programming interface (API) that enables interaction between software objects, or executable code that implements one or more interfaces. Through COM, a client object can call methods of server objects, which are typically Dynamic Link Libraries (DLL) or executables (EXE). Distributed COM (DCOM) is transparent middleware that extends the functionality of COM beyond a local computer using remote procedure call (RPC) technology. Permissions to interact with local and remote server COM objects are specified by access control lists (ACL) in the Registry. By default, only Administrators may remotely activate and launch COM objects through DCOM. Through DCOM, adversaries operating in the context of an appropriately privileged user can remotely obtain arbitrary and even direct shellcode execution through Office applications as well as other Windows objects that contain insecure methods. DCOM can also execute macros in existing documents and may also invoke (DDE) execution directly through a COM created instance of a Microsoft Office application , bypassing the need for a malicious document. DCOM can be used as a method of remotely interacting with .

Email Collection: Email Forwarding Rule is techniques, Adversaries may setup email forwarding rules to collect sensitive information. Adversaries may abuse email forwarding rules to monitor the activities of a victim, steal information, and further gain intelligence on the victim or the victim’s organization to use as part of further exploits or operations. Furthermore, email forwarding rules can allow adversaries to maintain persistent access to victim's emails even after compromised credentials are reset by administrators. Most email clients allow users to create inbox rules for various email functions, including forwarding to a different recipient. These rules may be created through a local email application, a web interface, or by command-line interface. Messages can be forwarded to internal or external recipients, and there are no restrictions limiting the extent of this rule. Administrators may also create forwarding rules for user accounts with the same considerations and outcomes. Any user or administrator within the organization (or adversary with valid credentials) can create rules to automatically forward all received messages to another recipient, forward emails to different locations based on the sender, and more. Adversaries may also hide the rule by making use of the Microsoft Messaging API (MAPI) to modify the rule properties, making it hidden and not visible from Outlook, OWA or most Exchange Administration tools. In some environments, administrators may be able to enable email forwarding rules that operate organization-wide rather than on individual inboxes. For example, Microsoft Exchange supports transport rules that evaluate all mail an organization receives against user-specified conditions, then performs a user-specified action on mail that adheres to those conditions. Adversaries that abuse such features may be able to enable forwarding on all or specific mail an organization receives.

IMAP accounts in Outlook 2013 (and earlier) and POP accounts use Outlook Data Files (.pst) as opposed to .ost, whereas IMAP accounts in Outlook 2016 (and later) use .ost files. Dynamic Resolution: Fast Flux DNS is techniques, Adversaries may use Fast Flux DNS to hide a command and control channel behind an array of rapidly changing IP addresses linked to a single domain resolution. This technique uses a fully qualified domain name, with multiple IP addresses assigned to it which are swapped with high frequency, using a combination of round robin IP addressing and short Time-To-Live (TTL) for a DNS resource record. The simplest, "single-flux" method, involves registering and de-registering an addresses as part of the DNS A (address) record list for a single DNS name. These registrations have a five-minute average lifespan, resulting in a constant shuffle of IP address resolution. In contrast, the "double-flux" method registers and de-registers an address as part of the DNS Name Server record list for the DNS zone, providing additional resilience for the connection. With double-flux additional hosts can act as a proxy to the C2 host, further insulating the true source of the C2 channel.

Encrypted Channel: Asymmetric Cryptography is techniques, Adversaries may employ a known asymmetric encryption algorithm to conceal command and control traffic rather than relying on any inherent protections provided by a communication protocol. Asymmetric cryptography, also known as public key cryptography, uses a keypair per party: one public that can be freely distributed, and one private. Due to how the keys are generated, the sender encrypts data with the receiver’s public key and the receiver decrypts the data with their private key. This ensures that only the intended recipient can read the encrypted data. Common public key encryption algorithms include RSA and ElGamal. For efficiency, many protocols (including SSL/TLS) use symmetric cryptography once a connection is established, but use asymmetric cryptography to establish or transmit a key. As such, these protocols are classified as .

For example, adversaries may construct or use onion routing networks – such as the publicly available network – to transport encrypted C2 traffic through a compromised population, allowing communication with any device within the network. Proxy: Domain Fronting is techniques, Adversaries may take advantage of routing schemes in Content Delivery Networks (CDNs) and other services which host multiple domains to obfuscate the intended destination of HTTPS traffic or traffic tunneled through HTTPS. Domain fronting involves using different domain names in the SNI field of the TLS header and the Host field of the HTTP header. If both domains are served from the same CDN, then the CDN may route to the address specified in the HTTP header after unwrapping the TLS header. A variation of the the technique, "domainless" fronting, utilizes a SNI field that is left blank; this may allow the fronting to work even when the CDN attempts to validate that the SNI and HTTP Host fields match (if the blank SNI fields are ignored). For example, if domain-x and domain-y are customers of the same CDN, it is possible to place domain-x in the TLS header and domain-y in the HTTP header. Traffic will appear to be going to domain-x, however the CDN may route it to domain-y.

Endpoint Denial of Service: OS Exhaustion Flood is techniques, Adversaries may launch a denial of service (DoS) attack targeting an endpoint's operating system (OS). A system's OS is responsible for managing the finite resources as well as preventing the entire system from being overwhelmed by excessive demands on its capacity. These attacks do not need to exhaust the actual resources on a system; the attacks may simply exhaust the limits and available resources that an OS self-imposes. Different ways to achieve this exist, including TCP state-exhaustion attacks such as SYN floods and ACK floods. With SYN floods, excessive amounts of SYN packets are sent, but the 3-way TCP handshake is never completed. Because each OS has a maximum number of concurrent TCP connections that it will allow, this can quickly exhaust the ability of the system to receive new requests for TCP connections, thus preventing access to any TCP service provided by the server. ACK floods leverage the stateful nature of the TCP protocol. A flood of ACK packets are sent to the target. This forces the OS to search its state table for a related TCP connection that has already been established. Because the ACK packets are for connections that do not exist, the OS will have to search the entire state table to confirm that no match exists. When it is necessary to do this for a large flood of packets, the computational requirements can cause the server to become sluggish and/or unresponsive, due to the work it must do to eliminate the rogue ACK packets. This greatly reduces the resources available for providing the targeted service.

Endpoint Denial of Service: Service Exhaustion Flood is techniques, Adversaries may target the different network services provided by systems to conduct a denial of service (DoS). Adversaries often target the availability of DNS and web services, however others have been targeted as well. Web server software can be attacked through a variety of means, some of which apply generally while others are specific to the software being used to provide the service. One example of this type of attack is known as a simple HTTP flood, where an adversary sends a large number of HTTP requests to a web server to overwhelm it and/or an application that runs on top of it. This flood relies on raw volume to accomplish the objective, exhausting any of the various resources required by the victim software to provide the service. Another variation, known as a SSL renegotiation attack, takes advantage of a protocol feature in SSL/TLS. The SSL/TLS protocol suite includes mechanisms for the client and server to agree on an encryption algorithm to use for subsequent secure connections. If SSL renegotiation is enabled, a request can be made for renegotiation of the crypto algorithm. In a renegotiation attack, the adversary establishes a SSL/TLS connection and then proceeds to make a series of renegotiation requests. Because the cryptographic renegotiation has a meaningful cost in computation cycles, this can cause an impact to the availability of the service when done in volume.

Network Denial of Service: Reflection Amplification is techniques, Adversaries may attempt to cause a denial of service (DoS) by reflecting a high-volume of network traffic to a target. This type of Network DoS takes advantage of a third-party server intermediary that hosts and will respond to a given spoofed source IP address. This third-party server is commonly termed a reflector. An adversary accomplishes a reflection attack by sending packets to reflectors with the spoofed address of the victim. Similar to Direct Network Floods, more than one system may be used to conduct the attack, or a botnet may be used. Likewise, one or more reflectors may be used to focus traffic on the target. This Network DoS attack may also reduce the availability and functionality of the targeted system(s) and network. Reflection attacks often take advantage of protocols with larger responses than requests in order to amplify their traffic, commonly known as a Reflection Amplification attack. Adversaries may be able to generate an increase in volume of attack traffic that is several orders of magnitude greater than the requests sent to the amplifiers. The extent of this increase will depending upon many variables, such as the protocol in question, the technique used, and the amplifying servers that actually produce the amplification in attack volume. Two prominent protocols that have enabled Reflection Amplification Floods are DNS and NTP , though the use of several others in the wild have been documented. In particular, the memcache protocol showed itself to be a powerful protocol, with amplification sizes up to 51,200 times the requesting packet.

https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1498/001/

Network Denial of Service: Direct Network Flood is techniques, Adversaries may attempt to cause a denial of service (DoS) by directly sending a high-volume of network traffic to a target. This DoS attack may also reduce the availability and functionality of the targeted system(s) and network. s are when one or more systems are used to send a high-volume of network packets towards the targeted service's network. Almost any network protocol may be used for flooding. Stateless protocols such as UDP or ICMP are commonly used but stateful protocols such as TCP can be used as well. Botnets are commonly used to conduct network flooding attacks against networks and services. Large botnets can generate a significant amount of traffic from systems spread across the global Internet. Adversaries may have the resources to build out and control their own botnet infrastructure or may rent time on an existing botnet to conduct an attack. In some of the worst cases for distributed DoS (DDoS), so many systems are used to generate the flood that each one only needs to send out a small amount of traffic to produce enough volume to saturate the target network. In such circumstances, distinguishing DDoS traffic from legitimate clients becomes exceedingly difficult. Botnets have been used in some of the most high-profile DDoS flooding attacks, such as the 2012 series of incidents that targeted major US banks.

Resource Hijacking: Bandwidth Hijacking is techniques, Adversaries may leverage the network bandwidth resources of co-opted systems to complete resource-intensive tasks, which may impact system and/or hosted service availability. Adversaries may also use malware that leverages a system's network bandwidth as part of a botnet in order to facilitate campaigns and/or to seed malicious torrents. Alternatively, they may engage in proxyjacking by selling use of the victims' network bandwidth and IP address to proxyware services. Finally, they may engage in internet-wide scanning in order to identify additional targets for compromise. In addition to incurring potential financial costs or availability disruptions, this technique may cause reputational damage if a victim’s bandwidth is used for illegal activities.

In response to the large quantity of requests, SMS costs may increase and communication channels may become overwhelmed.

Command and Scripting Interpreter: Unix Shell is techniques, Adversaries may abuse Unix shell commands and scripts for execution. Unix shells are the underlying command prompts on Android and iOS devices. Unix shells can control every aspect of a system, with certain commands requiring elevated privileges that are only accessible if the device has been rooted or jailbroken. Unix shells also support scripts that enable sequential execution of commands as well as other typical programming operations such as conditionals and loops. Common uses of shell scripts include long or repetitive tasks, or the need to run the same set of commands on multiple systems. Adversaries may abuse Unix shells to execute various commands or payloads. Interactive shells may be accessed through command and control channels or during lateral movement such as with SSH. Adversaries may also leverage shell scripts to deliver and execute multiple commands on victims or as part of payloads used for persistence. If the device has been rooted or jailbroken, adversaries may locate and invoke a superuser binary to elevate their privileges and interact with the system as the root user. This dangerous level of permissions allows the adversary to run special commands and modify protected system files.

Event Triggered Execution: Broadcast Receivers is techniques, Adversaries may establish persistence using system mechanisms that trigger execution based on specific events. Mobile operating systems have means to subscribe to events such as receiving an SMS message, device boot completion, or other device activities. An intent is a message passed between Android applications or system components. Applications can register to receive broadcast intents at runtime, which are system-wide intents delivered to each app when certain events happen on the device, such as network changes or the user unlocking the screen. Malicious applications can then trigger certain actions within the app based on which broadcast intent was received. In addition to Android system intents, malicious applications can register for intents broadcasted by other applications. This allows the malware to respond based on actions in other applications. This behavior typically indicates a more intimate knowledge, or potentially the targeting of specific devices, users, or applications. In Android 8 (API level 26), broadcast intent behavior was changed, limiting the implicit intents that applications can register for in the manifest. In most cases, applications that register through the manifest will no longer receive the broadcasts. Now, applications must register context-specific broadcast receivers while the user is actively using the app.

Process Injection: Ptrace System Calls is techniques, Adversaries may inject malicious code into processes via ptrace (process trace) system calls in order to evade process-based defenses as well as possibly elevate privileges. Ptrace system call injection is a method of executing arbitrary code in the address space of a separate live process. Ptrace system call injection involves attaching to and modifying a running process. The ptrace system call enables a debugging process to observe and control another process (and each individual thread), including changing memory and register values. Ptrace system call injection is commonly performed by writing arbitrary code into a running process (e.g., by using ) then invoking that memory with to set the register containing the next instruction to execute. Ptrace system call injection can also be done with / , which copy data to a specific address in the target process's memory (e.g., the current address of the next instruction). Ptrace system call injection may not be possible when targeting processes with high-privileges, and on some systems those that are non-child processes. Running code in the context of another process may allow access to the process's memory, system/network resources, and possibly elevated privileges. Execution via ptrace system call injection may also evade detection from security products since the execution is masked under a legitimate process.

By utilizing the various motion sensors on a device, such as accelerometer or gyroscope, an application could detect that the device is being interacted with. That way, the application could continue to run while the device is not in use but cease operating while the user is using the device, hiding anything that would indicate malicious activity was ongoing. Accessing the sensors in this way does not require any permissions from the user, so it would be completely transparent.

Hide Artifacts: Suppress Application Icon is techniques, A malicious application could suppress its icon from being displayed to the user in the application launcher. Hiding the application's icon programmatically does not require any special permissions. This behavior has been seen in the BankBot/Spy Banker family of malware. Beginning in Android 10, changes were introduced to inhibit malicious applications’ ability to hide their icon. If an app is a system app, requests no permissions, or does not have a launcher activity, the application’s icon will be fully hidden. Otherwise, a synthesized activity is shown, which is a launcher icon that represents the app’s details page in the system settings. If the user clicks the synthesized activity in the launcher, they are taken to the application’s details page in the system settings.

Encrypted Channel: Symmetric Cryptography is techniques, Adversaries may employ a known symmetric encryption algorithm to conceal command and control traffic, rather than relying on any inherent protections provided by a communication protocol. Encrypted Channel: Asymmetric Cryptography is techniques, Adversaries may employ a known asymmetric encryption algorithm to conceal command and control traffic, rather than relying on any inherent protections provided by a communication protocol. Asymmetric cryptography, also known as public key cryptography, uses a keypair per party: one public that can be freely distributed, and one private that should not be distributed. Due to how asymmetric algorithms work, the sender encrypts data with the receiver’s public key and the receiver decrypts the data with their private key. This ensures that only the intended recipient can read the encrypted data. Common public key encryption algorithms include RSA, ElGamal, and ECDSA. For efficiency, many protocols (including SSL/TLS) use symmetric cryptography once a connection is established, but use asymmetric cryptography to establish or transmit a key. As such, these protocols are classified as .

If another certificate is presented, it could indicate device compromise, traffic interception, or another upstream issue. While benign usages are common, it is also possible for adversaries to abuse this technology to protect malicious C2 traffic. In normal, not pinned SSL validation, when a client connects to a server using HTTPS, it typically checks whether the server’s SSL/TLS certificate is signed by a trusted Certificate Authority (CA) in the device’s trust store. If the certificate is valid and signed by a trusted CA, the connection is established. However, with , the client is configured to trust a specific SSL/TLS certificate or public key, rather than relying on the device’s trust store. This means that even if the server’s certificate is signed by a trusted CA, the client will only establish the connection of the certificate or key is pinned. There are two types of :

Compromised systems may leverage popular websites and social media to host command and control (C2) instructions. Those infected systems can then send the output from those commands back over that Web service channel. The return traffic may occur in a variety of ways, depending on the Web service being utilized. For example, the return traffic may take the form of the compromised system posting a comment on a forum, issuing a pull request to development project, updating a document hosted on a Web service, or by sending a Tweet. Popular websites and social media, acting as a mechanism for C2, may give a significant amount of cover. This is due to the likelihood that hosts within a network are already communicating with them prior to a compromise. Using common services, such as those offered by Google or Twitter, makes it easier for adversaries to hide in expected noise. Web service providers commonly use SSL/TLS encryption, giving adversaries an added level of protection.

https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1481/001/

Web Service: Dead Drop Resolver is techniques, Adversaries may use an existing, legitimate external Web service to host information that points to additional command and control (C2) infrastructure. Adversaries may post content, known as a dead drop resolver, on Web services with embedded (and often obfuscated/encoded) domains or IP addresses. Once infected, victims will reach out to and be redirected by these resolvers. Popular websites and social media, acting as a mechanism for C2, may give a significant amount of cover. This is due to the likelihood that hosts within a network are already communicating with them prior to a compromise. Using common services, such as those offered by Google or Twitter, makes it easier for adversaries to hide in expected noise. Web service providers commonly use SSL/TLS encryption, giving adversaries an added level of protection. Use of a dead drop resolver may also protect back-end C2 infrastructure from discovery through malware binary analysis, or enable operational resiliency (since this infrastructure may be dynamically changed).

https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1639/001/

Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol is techniques, Adversaries may steal data by exfiltrating it over an un-encrypted network protocol other than that of the existing command and control channel. The data may also be sent to an alternate network location from the main command and control server. Adversaries may opt to obfuscate this data, without the use of encryption, within network protocols that are natively unencrypted (such as HTTP, FTP, or DNS). Adversaries may employ custom or publicly available encoding/compression algorithms (such as base64) or embed data within protocol headers and fields.

https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1641/001/

Data Manipulation: Transmitted Data Manipulation is techniques, Adversaries may alter data en route to storage or other systems in order to manipulate external outcomes or hide activity. By manipulating transmitted data, adversaries may attempt to affect a business process, organizational understanding, or decision making. Manipulation may be possible over a network connection or between system processes where there is an opportunity to deploy a tool that will intercept and change information. The type of modification and the impact it will have depends on the target transmission mechanism as well as the goals and objectives of the adversary. For complex systems, an adversary would likely need special expertise and possibly access to specialized software related to the system, typically gained through a prolonged information gathering campaign, in order to have the desired impact. One method to achieve is by modifying the contents of the device clipboard. Malicious applications may monitor clipboard activity through the interface on Android to determine when clipboard contents have changed. Listening to clipboard activity, reading clipboard contents, and modifying clipboard contents requires no explicit application permissions and can be performed by applications running in the background. However, this behavior has changed with the release of Android 10. Adversaries may use to replace text prior to being pasted. For example, replacing a copied Bitcoin wallet address with a wallet address that is under adversarial control. was seen within the Android/Clipper.C trojan. This sample was detected by ESET in an application distributed through the Google Play Store targeting cryptocurrency wallet numbers.

Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell is techniques, Adversaries may abuse PowerShell commands and scripts for execution. PowerShell is a powerful interactive command-line interface and scripting environment included in the Windows operating system. Adversaries can use PowerShell to perform a number of actions, including discovery of information and execution of code. Examples include the cmdlet which can be used to run an executable and the cmdlet which runs a command locally or on a remote computer (though administrator permissions are required to use PowerShell to connect to remote systems). PowerShell may also be used to download and run executables from the Internet, which can be executed from disk or in memory without touching disk. A number of PowerShell-based offensive testing tools are available, including , , , and PSAttack. PowerShell commands/scripts can also be executed without directly invoking the binary through interfaces to PowerShell's underlying assembly DLL exposed through the .NET framework and Windows Common Language Interface (CLI).

Out-of-Band Communications Channel is mitigations, Establish secure out-of-band communication channels to ensure the continuity of critical communications during security incidents, data integrity attacks, or in-network communication failures. Out-of-band communication refers to using an alternative, separate communication path that is not dependent on the potentially compromised primary network infrastructure. This method can include secure messaging apps, encrypted phone lines, satellite communications, or dedicated emergency communication systems. Leveraging these alternative channels reduces the risk of adversaries intercepting, disrupting, or tampering with sensitive communications and helps coordinate an effective incident response.

Encrypt Network Traffic is mitigations, Application developers should encrypt all of their application network traffic using the Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocol to ensure protection of sensitive data and deter network-based attacks. If desired, application developers could perform message-based encryption of data before passing it for TLS encryption. iOS's App Transport Security feature can be used to help ensure that all application network traffic is appropriately protected. Apple intends to mandate use of App Transport Security for all apps in the Apple App Store unless appropriate justification is given. Android's Network Security Configuration feature similarly can be used by app developers to help ensure that all of their application network traffic is appropriately protected . Use of Virtual Private Network (VPN) tunnels, e.g. using the IPsec protocol, can help mitigate some types of network attacks as well.

https://www.thaicert.or.th/2025/01/16/%e0%b8%a1%e0%b8%b1%e0%b8%a5%e0%b9%81%e0%b8%a7%e0%b8%a3%e0%b9%8c-wp3-xyz-%e0%b9%82%e0%b8%88%e0%b8%a1%e0%b8%95%e0%b8%b5%e0%b9%80%e0%b8%a7%e0%b9%87%e0%b8%9a%e0%b9%84%e0%b8%8b%e0%b8%95%e0%b9%8c-wordpress/

WP3.XYZ malware attacks over 5,000 WordPress websites, creating fake administrator accounts. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 22/67 (IT) on Thursday, January 16, 2025, discovered a new malware campaign targeting more than 5,000 WordPress websites by creating fake administrator accounts, installing malicious plugins, and stealing sensitive data. Researchers from the security firm c/side found that the malware uses the domain wp3[.]xyz to send data to the attacker's server. After successfully compromising a system, the malicious script creates an account named "wpx_admin" with a password specified in the code. It then installs a plugin named plugin.php, which collects data such as administrator accounts and logs, and sends the data disguised as image requests to evade security detection. C/side states that the malware also includes steps to verify the success of the attack, such as checking whether the account and plugin have been created and activated, to systematically track the status of the attack. For prevention, c/side recommends blocking the wp3[.]xyz domain using firewalls and security tools, checking administrator accounts and installed plugins for unusual activity, and adding CSRF (Cross-Site Request Forgery) protection using short-lived server-side tokens. Furthermore, enabling multi-factor authentication (MFA) will enhance security.

CISA adds BeyondTrust and Qlik Sense vulnerabilities to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) list. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 20/67 (IT) Wednesday, January 15, 2025. The US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added new vulnerabilities to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) list, including CVE-2024-12686, an OS Command Injection vulnerability with a CVSS score of 6.6, found in BeyondTrust Privileged Remote Access (PRA) and Remote Support (RS). Hackers with administrator privileges can exploit this vulnerability to upload malicious files and execute operating system commands. Another added vulnerability is CVE-2023-48365, an HTTP Tunneling vulnerability in Qlik Sense with a CVSS score of 9.6. This vulnerability allows attackers to escalate privileges and send unauthorized HTTP requests to the backend server, a significant risk that could lead to access to sensitive data within the system. To mitigate and reduce the risk from these vulnerabilities, agencies under the Federal Civilian Executive Branch (FCEB) must patch them within a specified timeframe. CISA requires all vulnerabilities to be patched by February 3, 2025, to prevent exploitation and address related vulnerabilities as quickly as possible.

Telefónica confirms internal ticketing system breach after data leak. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 16/67 (IT) Monday, January 13, 2025. Spanish telecommunications company Telefónica has confirmed that its internal ticketing system was hacked after stolen data was published on a hacking forum. The company revealed that it has blocked access and thoroughly investigated the incident. Telefónica is Spain's largest multinational telecommunications company, with over 104,000 employees and operates in 12 countries. The incident stemmed from attackers using stolen employee account information to access the system. The attackers claim to have extracted approximately 2.3 GB of internal documents and tickets, some of which may be related to customers, but most are tickets opened with @telefonica.com emails for internal problem reporting. The attackers claiming responsibility for the incident are identified as DNA, Grep, Pryx, and Rey. Pryx told BleepingComputer that they did not demand a ransom or negotiate with Telefónica before publishing the data. The attack occurred yesterday, and the company immediately reset the passwords of the compromised accounts. Additionally, members of the groups Grep, Pryx, and Rey are also associated with the "Hellcat Ransomware" group, which previously attacked Schneider Electric and stole over 40 GB of data from the company's Jira servers.

SonicWall warns of exploitable vulnerability in SonicOS. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 14/67 (IT) Friday, January 10, 2025. SonicWall has issued a warning urging customers to immediately upgrade their firewall's SonicOS firmware to protect against an authentication bypass vulnerability, CVE-2024-53704, with a CVSS score of 8.2. This vulnerability exists in the SSL VPN and SSH management features. SonicWall states that users with these features enabled are at risk of attack. To address and mitigate this vulnerability, SonicWall recommends upgrading to the following firmware versions: – Gen 6 / 6.5 hardware firewalls: SonicOS 6.5.5.1-6n or later – Gen 6 / 6.5 NSv firewalls: SonicOS 6.5.4.v-21s-RC2457 or later – Gen 7 firewalls: SonicOS 7.0.1-5165 or later, 7.1.3-7015 and above – TZ80: SonicOS 8.0.0-8037 or later. In addition to the firmware upgrade, SonicWall also recommends the following mitigation steps: – Restrict SSL VPN access to trusted sources only, or disable access from the internet. – For SSH management, restrict access to trusted sources only, or disable SSH management from the internet. SonicWall emphasizes that customers should take immediate action to mitigate the risk and prevent exploitation of this vulnerability. Instructions on disabling SSL VPN access can be found at https://www.sonicwall.com/support/knowledge-base/how-can-i-setup-ssl-vpn/170505609285133.

Nessus Scanner Agents offline due to a failed plugin update. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 10/67 (IT) Wednesday, January 8, 2025. Tenable, the developer of the vulnerability scanning tool "Nessus", announced the deactivation of Nessus Scanner Agent versions 10.8.0 and 10.8.1 after discovering that the "differential" plugin update caused the agent to go offline on some systems. This resulted in the company temporarily halting plugin updates to prevent the issue. The company stated that they are urgently investigating and resolving the issue. Tenable announced a remediation plan, stating: – Nessus Agent systems for Tenable Vulnerability Management (TVM), Tenable Security Center (TSC), and Nessus were downgraded from 10.8.0/10.8.1 back to 10.7. – Plugin feed updates were disabled specifically for Nessus Agent versions below 10.8 and all versions of Nessus Scanner linked to TVM. Tenable has released Nessus Agent version 10.8.2 to address this issue and recommends that users running versions 10.8.0 and 10.8.1 upgrade to version 10.8.2 or downgrade to version 10.7.3. It is also recommended to reset the plugins if using profiles for agent upgrades or downgrades to bring the agents back online.

Nuclei vulnerability risks signature bypass and malicious code execution Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 08/67 (IT) Tuesday, January 7, 2025. A high-severity vulnerability (CVE-2024-43405) with a CVSS score of 7.4 has been identified in Nuclei, an open-source vulnerability scanner. This vulnerability allows attackers to bypass signature verification and inject malicious code into templates. The Wiz team reported that the vulnerability stems from differing newline character handling between signature verification and YAML parser data conversion, enabling attackers to insert malicious content while maintaining valid signatures in the normal section. Nuclei supports various protocols, including HTTP, TCP, DNS, and Code, which can execute code on the operating system. Using unsafe templates could lead to system compromise. Wiz's report demonstrates that the "Code" protocol can be used to extract sensitive information from target systems if weaponized with malicious code. This vulnerability affects Nuclei versions 3.0.0 and later and has been patched in version v3.3.2. Users should verify templates before use to prevent malicious code injection. Caution should be exercised when allowing users to modify or upload templates in shared systems to avoid the risk of attacks that could lead to unauthorized command execution, data theft, or system control.

https://www.thaicert.or.th/2025/01/03/lumen-%e0%b8%9b%e0%b8%b4%e0%b8%94%e0%b8%81%e0%b8%b1%e0%b9%89%e0%b8%99%e0%b8%81%e0%b8%a5%e0%b8%b8%e0%b9%88%e0%b8%a1%e0%b9%81%e0%b8%ae%e0%b8%81%e0%b9%80%e0%b8%81%e0%b8%ad%e0%b8%a3%e0%b9%8c-salt-typhoon/

Lumen blocked the hacker group Salt Typhoon from its network after discovering they were targeting attacks in the US and globally. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 04/67 (IT) on Friday, January 3, 2025, reported that Lumen successfully blocked the hacker group Salt Typhoon, linked to China, from its network. They confirmed that no customer data was accessed or leaked. Salt Typhoon, also known as FamousSparrow and GhostEmperor, has been active since 2019, targeting government agencies and telecommunications companies worldwide. Recently, they infiltrated nine US telecommunications companies as part of a cyber espionage campaign. Anne Neuberger, the White House cybersecurity advisor, revealed that the attacks focused on Americans' metadata, including communications of key figures in government and politics. In early December 2024, it was reported that Salt Typhoon had penetrated telecommunications companies in dozens of countries. The Wall Street Journal further reported that at least eight US telecommunications companies were previously affected. In addition to Lumen, major providers such as AT&T and Verizon confirmed they successfully strengthened network security and prevented attacks. Meanwhile, T-Mobile stated that the hackers attempted to penetrate their systems but were unable to access sensitive data or company systems. This incident highlights the importance of cybersecurity measures in the telecommunications sector, which plays a crucial role in national security.

Iran and Russia have been sanctioned after interfering in the U.S. elections with AI and cyberattacks. The U.S. Department of the Treasury, under the Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC), has sanctioned organizations in Iran and Russia that attempted to interfere in the 2024 U.S. presidential election. The Iranian organization is the "Cognitive Design and Production Center" (CDPC) under the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC), which aims to incite social tensions. The Russian organization is the "Center for Geostrategic Expertise" (CGE), which works with the GRU intelligence unit and uses AI to create fake content to spread disinformation. Investigations in 2024 indicated that Iran and Russia were involved in cyberattacks, disinformation, and deception to create divisions in American society. Meta shut down WhatsApp accounts of attackers linked to Iran, while U.S. authorities have filed criminal charges against IRGC individuals who attempted to steal information from government officials. Russia also supported the creation of a network of websites and used fake identities to conceal its connection with the state. The U.S. Treasury Department pointed out that these attempts reflect Russia's strategy to undermine the security of the U.S. and its allies by using cyber tools and fake news sources to cause political and social damage internationally. The U.S. continues to implement strict measures to counter such threats.

https://www.thaicert.or.th/2024/12/25/cisa-%e0%b9%80%e0%b8%9e%e0%b8%b4%e0%b9%88%e0%b8%a1%e0%b8%8a%e0%b9%88%e0%b8%ad%e0%b8%87%e0%b9%82%e0%b8%ab%e0%b8%a7%e0%b9%88%e0%b9%83%e0%b8%99%e0%b8%a3%e0%b8%b0%e0%b8%9a%e0%b8%9a-usaherds-%e0%b8%82/

CISA adds Acclaim Systems' USAHERDS vulnerability to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog. The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) reported on Wednesday, December 25, 2024, that the U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added a vulnerability in Acclaim Systems' USAHERDS system, designated CVE-2021-44207 and with a CVSS severity score of 8.1, to the KEV catalog. This vulnerability involves the use of credentials embedded in the code, allowing attackers to execute malicious code on the system. This vulnerability has been previously exploited by the Chinese APT41 group to attack several U.S. government networks. Affected systems are USAHERDS version 7.4.0.1 and earlier. USAHERDS is a web application developed by Acclaim Systems to assist U.S. government agencies in tracking and managing animal health, including disease outbreak control. It is part of the AgraGuard suite of products that supports agricultural operations and food safety, such as USALIMS, USAPlants, USAFoodSafety, and USAMeals. To prevent and mitigate risks from these vulnerabilities, agencies under the U.S. Federal Civilian Executive Branch (FCEB) are required to remediate the vulnerability within a specified timeframe. CISA has mandated remediation by January 13, 2025, to prevent exploitation and address related vulnerabilities as soon as possible.

CISA adds BeyondTrust software vulnerabilities to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog. The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) reported on Monday, December 23, 2024, that the U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added a Command Injection vulnerability in BeyondTrust Privileged Remote Access (PRA) and Remote Support (RS) software, designated CVE-2024-12356 with a CVSS severity score of 9.8, to the KEV catalog. This vulnerability allows unauthenticated attackers to inject malicious commands and execute them as a site user. It affects all versions of BeyondTrust PRA and RS products. However, BeyondTrust has released patches to address the vulnerability in RS and PRA versions 22.1.x and later. To mitigate and prevent risks from these vulnerabilities, agencies under the U.S. Federal Civilian Executive Branch (FCEB) are required to remediate the vulnerability within a specified timeframe. CISA has mandated completion of remediation by December 27, 2024, to prevent exploitation and address related vulnerabilities as soon as possible.

Attackers are attempting to exploit a vulnerability in Apache Struts, tracked as CVE-2024-53677. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 451/67 (IT) Friday, December 20, 2024. Researchers warn of an Apache Struts vulnerability where attackers are attempting to exploit CVE-2024-53677, which has a CVSS score of 9.5. This vulnerability arises from attackers being able to modify file upload parameters to perform a Path Traversal attack, potentially leading to the upload of malicious files used for Remote Code Execution. This vulnerability affects the following software versions: – Struts 2.0.0 to Struts 2.3.37 (EOL) – Struts 2.5.0 to Struts 2.5.33 (EOL) – Struts 6.0.0 to Struts 6.3.0.2. Dr. Johannes Ullrich, Dean of Research at SANS Technology Institute, states that this vulnerability stems from an incomplete fix for the previous vulnerability, CVE-2023-50164. The new vulnerability is similar to the old one. Furthermore, Proof-of-Concept (PoC) code has been published, and attackers have begun using it in real-world attacks. To mitigate the risk, users should update their software to Struts 6.4.0 or later and utilize the Action File Upload Interceptor to prevent future attacks.

CISA adds Microsoft Windows Kernel-Mode Driver and Adobe ColdFusion vulnerabilities to the (KEV) catalog. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 449/67 (IT) Thursday, December 19, 2024. The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added the Microsoft Windows Kernel-Mode Driver Untrusted Pointer Dereference vulnerability (CVE-2024-35250) and the Adobe ColdFusion Improper Access Control vulnerability (CVE-2024-20767) to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog. Details of the vulnerabilities are as follows: – CVE-2024-35250 has a CVSS score of 7.8 and is an Elevation of Privilege vulnerability in the Windows Kernel-Mode Driver. It allows attackers who are already on the system to elevate their privileges to SYSTEM. The attack is low complexity. – CVE-2024-20767 has a CVSS score of 7.4 and is an Improper Access Control vulnerability in Adobe ColdFusion versions 2023.6, 2021.12 and earlier. Attackers can exploit this vulnerability to read files without authorization. The attack occurs when an externally accessible Admin Panel is enabled. To mitigate and reduce the risk from these vulnerabilities, agencies under the U.S. Federal Civilian Executive Branch (FCEB) must remediate the vulnerabilities within a specified timeframe. CISA has set a deadline of January 6, 2025, to complete remediation to prevent exploitation of these vulnerabilities.

ConnectOnCall reveals data breach affecting over 900,000 users. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 447/67 (IT) Wednesday, December 18, 2024. ConnectOnCall, a telehealth platform and after-hours emergency call service, has disclosed a data breach affecting the personal and medical information of over 900,000 users. The company discovered the security breach on May 12, 2024, and immediately launched an investigation, which found that an unauthorized party had accessed data in ConnectOnCall's systems between February 16 and May 12, 2024. This included communications between providers and patients. Potentially affected information includes names, phone numbers, dates of birth, social security numbers, medical record numbers, and health information such as medical conditions, treatments, and prescriptions. ConnectOnCall has hired cybersecurity experts, taken the system offline, and begun restoring the system, while also notifying law enforcement. Although there are no reports of misuse of the data or harm to patients, the company recommends that those potentially affected exercise caution and report any suspicious activity related to identity theft to their health insurance company or financial institution. ConnectOnCall notified potentially affected users on December 11, 2024, and is offering free credit monitoring and identity theft protection services through Kroll for those whose social security numbers were affected.

CISA adds Microsoft Windows CLFS Driver vulnerability to its catalog (KEV). Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 441/67 (IT) Thursday, December 12, 2024. The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added a vulnerability in the Microsoft Windows Common Log File System (CLFS), designated CVE-2024-49138 with a CVSS score of 7.8, to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog. This vulnerability was addressed in Microsoft's December 2024 Patch Tuesday security updates, which covered a total of 71 vulnerabilities and included the actively exploited CVE-2024-49138. Although Microsoft has not disclosed details about attacks exploiting this vulnerability, experts warn that attackers could use it to elevate privileges to SYSTEM. To mitigate and reduce the risk from these vulnerabilities, agencies under the U.S. Federal Civilian Executive Branch (FCEB) are required to patch vulnerabilities within specified timeframes. CISA mandates that government agencies patch this vulnerability by December 31, 2024, to prevent its exploitation.

Romania faces over 85,000 cyberattacks against election systems. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 437/67 (IT) Monday, December 9, 2024. Romania's Intelligence Service revealed that the country's election systems were subjected to over 85,000 cyberattacks. Attackers gained access to election-related website data and disseminated it on Russian cybercrime forums before the presidential election. Intelligence agencies suggest these attacks may be linked to user account breaches or exploitation of training server vulnerabilities. Heavy attacks occurred on election day and the night after, December 6, 2024. Romania's Constitutional Court annulled the entire election process due to a lack of transparency and interference, ordering the government to set a new election date and develop an action plan to restart the electoral process from scratch. Meanwhile, the pro-Russian candidate, Calin Georgescu, was heavily promoted on TikTok via coordinated accounts and paid advertising, leading to his questionable victory. Romania's Foreign Intelligence Service (SIE) believes Russia employed tactics to interfere in Eastern European elections, viewing Romania as an "enemy" due to its support for NATO and Ukraine. This interference includes disinformation campaigns, propaganda, and backing anti-EU agendas. Intelligence agencies warn that Romania's electoral systems remain vulnerable and at risk of future attacks.

Cisco warns of CVE-2014-2120 vulnerability in ASA being exploited. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 435/67 (IT) Friday, December 6, 2024. Cisco is warning customers about a vulnerability in Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance (ASA) software discovered ten years ago, CVE-2014-2120, which is currently being widely exploited. The vulnerability resides in the WebVPN login page of the ASA software, allowing unauthenticated attackers to perform Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) attacks against WebVPN users on Cisco ASA devices. This vulnerability is due to insufficient input validation, allowing attackers to exploit it by tricking users into accessing malicious links. In November 2024, the Cisco PSIRT (Product Security Incident Response Team) discovered new attempts to exploit this vulnerability in Cisco systems and recommends users update their software to a patched version as soon as possible to mitigate the risk of attack. In addition, CISA in the United States has added this vulnerability to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) Catalog. Cisco emphasizes that customers should review the updated security advisories and take corrective action as soon as possible to prevent attacks from this vulnerability, which continues to be actively exploited by hackers.

Two UK hospitals hit by cyberattacks. Alder Hey Children's Hospital in the UK has revealed that its systems were attacked, with patient data and other sensitive information stolen and published online. The ransomware group Inc Ransom claimed to have obtained data between 2018 and 2024. The hospital confirmed it is increasing security measures and that the incident has not affected current services. Meanwhile, Wirral University Teaching Hospital had to shut down its IT systems and revert to paper records after suspicious activity was detected. The incident caused some services, such as appointments and surgeries, to be postponed. While emergency services remain available, patients may experience longer wait times in the emergency department. Although there is no confirmation that the Wirral incident is ransomware-related, system shutdowns are a common response to such events. Both hospitals are working with relevant authorities to resolve the issues and assess the impact on potentially compromised data.

Hackers stole millions of dollars from Uganda's central bank. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 429/67 (IT) Monday, December 2, 2024. The Ugandan government confirmed on Thursday that the country's central bank was hit by a cyberattack by financially motivated threat actors, resulting in a significant loss of funds. The attack is under investigation by the Criminal Investigations Directorate (CID) of the police and the Office of the Auditor General (OAG). Henry Musasizi, the junior finance minister, revealed in parliament that some central bank accounts were hacked. However, the losses might not be as severe as reported in some media outlets. He added that the bank has undertaken a thorough account reconciliation and investigation into the incident. The Bank of Uganda indicated that the attack involved a threat actor group called “Waste,” believed to be operating from Southeast Asia. The group moved 62 billion Ugandan shillings (approximately $16.8 million) to foreign accounts in early November. According to local media reports, some of the money was transferred to accounts in Japan and the United Kingdom. Authorities in the UK were able to seize more than $7 million, although some had already been withdrawn. In Japan, the attackers reportedly received about $6 million. The central bank has managed to recover some of the funds. The investigation is ongoing to identify those involved and to implement preventive measures for the future.

Critical Vulnerability in WordPress Anti-Spam Plugin Allows Remote Attacks Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 425/67 (IT) Thursday, November 28, 2024: Two critical vulnerabilities affecting WordPress's Spam protection, Anti-Spam, and FireWall could allow unauthenticated attackers to install and activate malicious plugins on vulnerable websites and achieve remote code execution. The vulnerabilities, CVE-2024-10542 and CVE-2024-10781, have a CVSS severity score of 9.8. Both vulnerabilities have been patched in versions 6.44 and 6.45, released this month. The CleanTalk plugin is installed on over 200,000 WordPress websites and blocks spam from comments and forms. However, if attackers can install plugins, it could lead to remote attacks, especially if those plugins have unpatched vulnerabilities. Updating plugins and the WordPress system is crucial for mitigating this risk. Additionally, Sucuri has warned of multiple attack campaigns using compromised WordPress websites to redirect users to phishing sites, steal data, install malware, or run PHP code on the server, further increasing system risk. Administrators should reinforce security and regularly monitor their systems to minimize the chances of being attacked.

CISA adds Array Networks AG and vxAG ArrayOS vulnerability to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog. The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) reported on Wednesday, November 27, 2024, that the U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added vulnerability CVE-2023-28461, with a CVSS score of 9.8, affecting Array Networks AG Series and vxAG ArrayOS (version 9.4.0.481 and earlier) to the KEV catalog. This vulnerability allows attackers to exploit the SSL VPN Gateway via unauthenticated file system access by sending an HTTP request containing a flags attribute in the header and using a vulnerable URL. Attackers can achieve remote code execution and gain control of the system. To mitigate and reduce the risk from these vulnerabilities, agencies under the Federal Civilian Executive Branch (FCEB) are required to remediate the vulnerability within a specified timeframe. CISA requires government agencies to fix this vulnerability by December 16, 2024, to prevent exploitation.

The US has seized the PopeyeTools credit card marketplace and charged its administrators. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 421/67 (IT) Tuesday, November 26, 2024. The US Department of Justice (DoJ) has seized the PopeyeTools website, a dark web marketplace for selling stolen credit card information, and charged three administrators: Abdul Ghaffar, Abdul Sami, and Javed Mirza. They are charged with access device fraud and trafficking in information related to cybercrimes such as financial data theft and ransomware attacks. PopeyeTools has been operating on the dark web since 2016, specializing in the sale of credit card, debit card, and personally identifiable information (PII) for use in fraudulent activities and other cybercrimes. Data for at least 227,000 individuals was offered for sale, generating over $1.7 million in revenue. Authorities also seized $283,000 in cryptocurrency from accounts linked to Sami, as well as seizing the website domain names www.PopeyeTools[.]co.uk and www.PopeyeTools[.]to, which were used to access the platform. This action is part of the US Department of Justice’s strategy to combat cybercrime by seizing websites and assets derived from illegal activities. If convicted, the defendants face a maximum penalty of 10 years in prison per count.

IGT, a global gambling technology company, faces a cyberattack, impacting some IT systems. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 419/67 (IT) Monday, November 25, 2024. International Game Technology PLC (IGT), a global gambling technology company, faced a cyberattack on November 17, 2024, that caused some of the company's IT systems to shut down. IGT immediately responded to the incident, and according to a document filed with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), the company detected that unauthorized outsiders had accessed the organization's IT systems, causing some internal systems and applications to be disrupted. To prevent further damage, IGT shut down the affected systems and launched an investigation into the incident with the assistance of an external consulting team. Although the company has not yet disclosed the details of the attack, based on the nature of the response, it is expected that this incident may be a ransomware attack. Currently, the investigation and system restoration are ongoing to assess the damage and enhance system security.

Oracle warns of vulnerability in Agile PLM Framework being actively exploited. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 416/67 (IT) Friday, November 22, 2024 Oracle issued a warning to users about a serious security vulnerability found in Agile Product Lifecycle Management (PLM) Framework, number CVE-2024-21287 and a severity score (CVSS 7.5). This vulnerability can be exploited remotely without authentication, allowing malicious actors to access sensitive information. This vulnerability allows unauthenticated attackers to access the target system without requiring a username or password. Oracle explains in the advisory that "Successful exploitation of this vulnerability could allow an attacker to download files accessible under the PLM application’s privileges from the target system." Such an attack could lead to the exfiltration of files containing sensitive information without the target system being aware of the intrusion. Security researchers from CrowdStrike, Joel Snape and Lutz Wolf, discovered and reported the vulnerability. Oracle has made efforts to address this issue promptly. However, it is currently unclear what the target of such attacks is or how widespread they are. Administrators are advised to check the software version they are using and immediately install patches or update the system as soon as possible. Doing so will reduce the risk of being attacked and protect important data in the system from malicious actors.

Helldown ransomware attacks Linux systems and VMware servers, causing significant damage. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 414/67 (IT) Thursday, November 21, 2024. The Helldown ransomware group is a new threat in the cyber world, targeting Linux systems and VMware ESXi used in organizations across multiple sectors. Recent attacks reveal that the group exploits vulnerabilities in Zyxel firewall devices to gain access to victim systems. Sekoia reports that Helldown ransomware may be exploiting an undisclosed vulnerability in Zyxel firewalls. Although Zyxel has released patches, there is no clear information about the vulnerability used by the attackers. Helldown exhibits sophisticated attack behavior and focuses on stealing large amounts of data from victims, such as important documents and personal information, which are used as leverage for ransom demands. Since August, Helldown ransomware has attacked 31 victims, mostly in the United States and organizations in various sectors. Helldown also attempts to cover its tracks, such as deleting tools used and overwriting data on hard drives, to hinder the victim's data recovery process. Experts recommend that system administrators regularly update security patches, monitor unusual behavior, and treat virtual systems with the same caution as regular systems, as Helldown is a new threat that is having a severe impact across multiple sectors.

Botnet Exploits Zero-day Vulnerability in EoL GeoVision Devices Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 411/67 (IT) Tuesday, November 19, 2024. Researchers from the Shadowserver Foundation have discovered a botnet exploiting a zero-day vulnerability in end-of-life (EoL) GeoVision devices to attack and control devices that are still in use. The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2024-11120, has a CVSS score of 9.8 and is a pre-auth command injection vulnerability. It was discovered by the Shadowserver Foundation and confirmed with the assistance of TWCERT (Taiwan Computer Emergency Response Team). The vulnerability affects the following GeoVision products: - GV-VS12 - GV-VS11 - GV-DSP_LPR_V3 - GVLX 4 V2 - GVLX 4 V3 According to Shadowserver Foundation data, approximately 17,000 GeoVision devices are connected to the internet and vulnerable to attacks exploiting CVE-2024-11120. The most vulnerable devices are located in the United States (9,179), followed by Germany (1,652), Taiwan (792), and Canada (784), indicating a significant risk for users of these devices. Researchers recommend that users of EoL GeoVision devices should check and consider replacing them with newer models to prevent attacks. Additionally, external access for devices still in use should be disabled to mitigate the risk of being hacked.

Amazon disclosed an employee data breach following the MOVEit attacks in May 2023. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 403/67 (IT) on Wednesday, November 13, 2024, reported that Amazon revealed the data breach which exposed employee information. The data was stolen from a third-party service provider partnered with the company. Amazon did not specify the number of affected employees. The threat actor group "Nam3L3ss" published over 2.8 million records on BreachForums. The exposed data included names, phone numbers, work emails, and building locations. Social security numbers or financial information were not exposed. An Amazon spokesperson confirmed that Amazon and AWS systems remained secure, with no direct attacks on company systems. The stolen data was limited to employee contact information. Amazon has addressed the vulnerability that led to the attack to prevent future incidents. Hudson Rock's analysis found that Nam3L3ss claimed to have data from 25 other large organizations. Although MOVEit was previously used in attacks by the CL0P Ransomware group, it is unconfirmed whether this breach is related to CL0P or another hacker group.

Researchers discovered a new ransomware called 'Ymir' that encrypts systems previously attacked by the RustyStealer malware. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 402/67 (IT) Wednesday, November 13, 2024. Kaspersky researchers discovered a new type of ransomware called Ymir being used in attacks alongside the RustyStealer malware, a data-stealing program that infiltrates victim systems before deploying the ransomware. Ymir attacks networks containing sensitive information, with RustyStealer utilizing techniques to collect credentials and gain system access through privileged accounts. Once installed, Ymir encrypts system files and creates a ransom note in a PDF file to coerce payment. It also modifies Windows settings to display warning messages on the login screen to further pressure victims into complying with the hackers' demands. Ymir ransomware operates stealthily by running in memory and uses ChaCha20 encryption, an advanced encryption algorithm, to encrypt data, making decryption difficult. The malware also scans the system for signs of PowerShell and deletes itself to avoid detection in its final stages. Currently, no data leak site associated with Ymir has been found, suggesting that the attackers may be in the early stages of victim data collection. If this ransomware evolves to include data exfiltration capabilities, it could become an even more dangerous threat.

Palo Alto Networks Warns of Remote Code Execution (RCE) Vulnerability Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 401/67 (IT) Tuesday, November 12, 2024. Palo Alto Networks issued a warning urging customers to immediately check the security settings of their PAN-OS management interface after the discovery of a Remote Code Execution (RCE) vulnerability that could be exploited. Although the source of this allegation is currently unclear, the company is closely monitoring the situation. Currently, there is no evidence of actual zero-day attacks. The company states that even without clear information about the vulnerability or Indicators of Compromise (IoCs), securing the management interface from internet access will significantly reduce risk. They recommend configuring access only from trusted internal IPs. The company's Prisma Access and cloud NGFW solutions are not affected by this issue. Recently, CISA added a vulnerability in the Palo Alto Networks Expedition tool, designated CVE-2024-5910, to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog. This vulnerability was patched in July, and although technical details were released in October, there is no indication of active exploitation at this time.

Newpark Resources, a Texas oil supplier, hit by Ransomware. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 399/67 (IT) Monday, November 11, 2024. On October 29, 2024, Newpark Resources, a major US oil industry supplier, was affected by a ransomware attack that resulted in temporary inaccessibility to some information systems and business applications. After detecting the incident, the company immediately implemented its cyber threat response plan and began investigating the incident with external experts to control the damage. According to the FORM 8-K filed with the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), the company disclosed that the attackers were able to gain partial access to the company's internal systems, causing problems with the systems and applications that support operations and financial reporting. However, production and operations continue as normal. Currently, Newpark Resources is assessing the damage and costs from the attack, but expects that it will not significantly impact its financial position and operations. The company will disclose further information as the situation progresses, and so far no details have been released about the type of malware or the group claiming responsibility for this incident.

Canada orders TikTok to shut down operations in Canada due to security concerns. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 396/67 (IT) for Friday, November 8, 2024. The Canadian government has ordered TikTok, owned by ByteDance in China, to cease operations in the country. The decision is stated to be the result of a national security risk assessment. The review was conducted by Canada’s security and intelligence community. The government emphasized that it will not restrict access to TikTok for the general Canadian public, but advised citizens to assess the potential risks of using the social media app. François-Philippe Champagne, Canada’s Minister of Innovation, Science and Industry, stated that the government wants citizens to be aware of the risks of using social media platforms, particularly in terms of data management and security related to foreign countries. TikTok has been banned on government devices since February 2023. TikTok responded that closing the office in Canada will result in hundreds of employees being laid off. The company intends to challenge this order in court. In a statement, ByteDance confirmed that no user data will be shared with the Chinese government. However, concerns remain that TikTok may be forced to hand over user data. This has resulted in the U.S. enacting a law requiring ByteDance to sell TikTok by January 2025 or face a ban in the country. Currently, TikTok is completely banned in several countries, including Afghanistan, India, Nepal, and Pakistan, and is prohibited on government-issued devices in many countries around the world.

CVE-2024-43093 vulnerability in Android is being actively exploited. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 395/67 (IT) Thursday, November 7, 2024. Google has warned about the CVE-2024-43093 vulnerability in the Android operating system that is being actively exploited by threat actors. This vulnerability is related to privilege escalation in the Android Framework component. If successfully exploited, it could lead to unauthorized access to critical system folders, such as "Android/data," "Android/obb," and "Android/sandbox." Although Google has not yet disclosed the details of this exploit, the company further stated that there is another vulnerability, CVE-2024-43047, that is also being actively exploited. The CVE-2024-43047 vulnerability resides in the Qualcomm component of the Android system. It is a Use-After-Free (UAF) vulnerability that could cause memory corruption due to the way the Digital Signal Processor (DSP) handles Direct Memory Access (DMA) File Descriptors in the Header Buffer. Google reports that both vulnerabilities are being actively exploited in targeted attacks. In September, Google also patched a high-severity vulnerability, CVE-2024-32896 (CVSS score: 7.8), which is a privilege escalation vulnerability in the Android Framework. This vulnerability could be exploited due to a logic error in the code, allowing attackers to escalate privileges without requiring permissions.

Vulnerability in Okta Verify Agent Windows Allows Attackers to Steal User Passwords Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 393/67 (IT) Wednesday, November 6, 2024. Okta, a leading technology company in Identity and Access Management (IAM), has fixed a critical vulnerability in Okta Verify for Windows. This vulnerability could allow attackers to steal user passwords. The vulnerability was discovered during the company's regular penetration testing. The vulnerability affects Okta Verify Agent for Windows versions 5.0.2 through 5.3.2 and is identified as CVE-2024-9191. It is related to the Okta Device Access feature. This vulnerability allows attackers with access to a compromised device to retrieve passwords associated with users' passwordless logins via the OktaDeviceAccessPipe. However, the vulnerability only affects users utilizing the passwordless Okta Device Access feature. Users using Okta Verify on other platforms or only the FastPass feature are not affected. Okta has addressed this vulnerability in version 5.3.3 of the Verify Agent for Windows and recommends that affected customers update to the latest version as soon as possible to mitigate the risk. The vulnerability was initially discovered on April 17, 2024, in version 5.0.2, and Okta released an Early Access version with a fix on September 20, 2024, before the general release on October 25, 2024.

LastPass warns of fake phone numbers trying to steal customer data. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 388/67 (IT) Monday, November 4, 2024. LastPass has warned users about an ongoing phishing campaign. Attackers have been writing 5-star reviews for the LastPass Chrome extension, including a phone number claiming to be customer support. This number directs users experiencing issues to scammers who instruct them to visit the website ‘dghelp[.]top’ to download a remote control program. Users who call the fake number are greeted by someone impersonating an "official" who asks about the issue. Then, they direct the user to the website to trick them into downloading remote access software. This software is installed via ScreenConnect and connects to a control server in Ukraine. LastPass emphasizes that users should never share their passwords with anyone. Researchers state that this fake number is being promoted as a support or customer service line for several other companies such as Amazon, Adobe, Facebook, Netflix, and Capital One. These numbers are being posted in Chrome extension reviews and on user-generated content sites such as company forums and Reddit. Although some posts have been removed, new ones continually appear. Therefore, LastPass users should be cautious and only use support numbers from the official website.

Interbank confirms data breach following failed extortion, customer data leaked online. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 387/67 (IT) Friday, November 1, 2024. Interbank, one of Peru's leading banks, has confirmed a major data breach after hackers compromised its systems and published customer data online. The bank says data from over 2 million customers was affected and that it has increased security measures to protect customer data and transactions. Meanwhile, several customers reported that the bank's application and online platforms were unavailable both during the incident and two weeks prior. However, Interbank confirms that most systems are now back online and emphasizes the security of customer deposits and financial transactions. According to Dark Web Informer, a hacker using the alias "kzoldyck" posted customer data for sale on a forum, claiming to have information on more than 3 million customers, including full names, account numbers, birthdays, addresses, emails, and credit card information, along with customer transaction data. Sensitive information such as usernames and passwords used to access banking systems was also partially disclosed. The hacker revealed that ransom negotiations with Interbank took place two weeks ago but failed because the bank refused to pay. As of now, Interbank has not provided further details about the breach.
