Russia adjusts cyber strategy for the long haul in the Ukraine war. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 265/67 (IT) Thursday, July 25, 2024. In this new strategy, Russia's cyber units are starting to focus on Ukrainian military targets instead of focusing cyberattacks on strategic civilian critical infrastructure targets. Russian officials are specifically targeting military computers and mobile phones before the summer offensive to reclaim Ukrainian territory. This change in cyber strategy stems from a shift in priorities, according to a report by the Royal United Services Institute. Initially, Russia focused on attacking civilian infrastructure in the region because it thought the war would end quickly. Dan Black, manager of cyber espionage analysis at Mandiant, a Google Cloud company, and author of the report, said, "Moscow has rebalanced its overall operational concept to emphasize targets that can provide more direct and tangible battlefield advantages to conventional forces.” Russia's new tactics include hacking devices used by the Ukrainian military, social engineering attacks to penetrate Ukrainian command and control systems, and hacking into webcams in population centers to search for Ukrainian military equipment.

Greece's land registry agency suffered 400 cyberattacks. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 264/67 (IT) Wednesday, July 24, 2024. The Greek land registry has reported 400 cyberattacks targeting its IT infrastructure last week. The agency stated that hackers gained access to employee computers and stole 1.2 GB of data, representing only 0.0006% of the total data held. The stolen data does not contain personal citizen information, but rather general administrative documents. The attack is not expected to affect the agency's operations. Hackers created user accounts to penetrate the agency's main database but were unsuccessful. An investigation by the agency, aided by the Cybercrime Division of the Hellenic National Defense General Staff, confirmed no evidence of ransomware. Several emergency mitigation measures were implemented: – All VPN access was revoked to prevent malicious users. – All employee passwords were reset. – Two-factor authentication was enforced to prevent unauthorized account access. The last attack, on July 19, 2024, was successfully blocked. There are no further updates, so it is unknown if the attacks are ongoing. The agency's digital services remain operational.

Google abandons plan to phase out third-party cookies in Chrome Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 263/67 (IT) Wednesday, July 24, 2024. On Monday, Google announced the cancellation of its plan to phase out third-party cookies in the Chrome web browser, which began more than 4 years ago under the Privacy Sandbox project. This is in response to numerous privacy concerns. Anthony Chavez, Vice President at Google, said the company will launch a new experience in Chrome that allows users to choose to use cookies as needed and can change that option at any time. Google is consulting with regulators and will collaborate with the industry in implementing this change. Although browsers like Apple Safari and Mozilla Firefox have not supported third-party cookies since early 2020, Google continues to face difficulties in doing so due to its significant role in the online advertising market. Efforts to balance privacy and ad support have met with intense scrutiny from regulators and privacy advocates. This change comes just months after Google announced its plan to phase out third-party cookies again, which has been postponed several times due to concerns about fair competition in the digital advertising market. This cancellation reflects the challenge of getting industry consensus on a single solution for managing privacy on the internet.

Critical vulnerability in Cisco SSM On-Prem allows attackers to change user passwords. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 259/67 (IT) Friday, July 19, 2024. Cisco has addressed a critical vulnerability, CVE-2024-20419 (CVSS score: 10.0), in Cisco Smart Software Manager On-Prem (Cisco SSM On-Prem) that allows attackers to change user passwords. The vulnerability stems from an anomaly in the password change process, allowing attackers to exploit it by sending specially crafted HTTP requests to the vulnerable device. This enables hackers to use the API or access the website to change user passwords. Security researcher Mohammed Adel discovered this vulnerability, which affects Cisco SSM On-Prem versions prior to 7.0. Cisco recommends users update to version 7.0 or later to prevent attacks.

North Korean hackers are using a new version of the BeaverTail malware to target macOS users. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 258/67 (IT) Friday, July 19, 2024. Cybersecurity researcher Patrick Wardle has revealed the latest campaign by North Korean-backed hackers, known for scamming victims with fake job postings. This time, they're using a new version of the BeaverTail malware to trick macOS users into downloading a malicious version of Microtalk, a video call service. Wardle explains in his report that the attackers lure victims into downloading a Microtalk update file infected with BeaverTail malware by asking them to participate in a job interview. "Even though the fake website states 'you can start your next video chat with a single click, without downloading anything,' some users may not read all the details," Wardle said. In addition to stealing data from victims' devices, BeaverTail malware can also load additional malware onto the system, including InvisibleFerret. The report adds that North Korean hackers are skilled at targeting macOS users with social engineering attacks. The campaign demonstrates the development of new techniques and methods by North Korean hackers to deceive and attack users, especially in the context of job searches and interviews.

A critical vulnerability in Apache HugeGraph should be patched immediately. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 256/67 (IT) on Thursday, July 18, 2024, warned that malicious actors are actively exploiting a recently disclosed security flaw in Apache HugeGraph-Server, which could lead to remote code execution (RCE) attacks. The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2024-27348 and assigned a CVSS score of 9.8, affects all versions of the software prior to 1.3.0. The flaw resides in the Gremlin Graph Traversal API, allowing attackers to execute remote commands. The Apache Software Foundation urges users to upgrade to version 1.3.0 with Java 11 and enable authentication. Furthermore, enabling the 'Whitelist-IP/port' function enhances the security of RESTful-API operations. Penetration testing firm SecureLayer7 published technical details about the flaw in early June, stating it allows attackers to bypass sandbox restrictions and execute code, granting full control of potentially affected servers. This week, Shadowserver reported observing widespread exploitation attempts leveraging this vulnerability. Users are urged to update their software to the latest version as soon as possible. Vulnerabilities found in Apache projects have been heavily exploited in recent years, notably flaws in Log4j, ActiveMQ, and RocketMQ, providing lucrative attack vectors for nation-states and financially motivated threat actors.

SEXi Ransomware has rebranded as ‘APT Inc.’ but maintains original methods of operation. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 254/67 (IT) Wednesday, July 17, 2024. The SEXi ransomware group, a cybercriminal group that has been attacking organizations since February, has rebranded as APT Inc. since June. This group uses leaked Babuk and LockBit 3 encryptors to attack VMware ESXi and Windows servers. Currently, APT Inc. continues to use the same encryption in its attacks, demanding ransoms ranging from thousands to millions of dollars. Some victims have publicly shared their experiences and APT Inc.'s ransom notes. The ransom note threatens, "You have been hacked! We are APT INC; Go to https://getsession[dot]org/; Download and install; Then add 05c5dbb3e0f6c173dd4ca479587dbeccc1365998ff9042581cd294566645ec7912 to your contact list and message us with this code name – – – > GARAKLY;" They threaten to enforce payment within one week and warn against reporting the incident or seeking help from other agencies. To date, no vulnerabilities in the Babuk and LockBit 3 encryptors have been found, and there are no free methods to recover files encrypted by the group.

Rite Aid confirms data breach after ransomware attack. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 253/67 (IT) Tuesday, July 16, 2024. Pharmaceutical company Rite Aid has confirmed a data breach following a cyberattack in June. Rite Aid is the third largest drugstore chain in the United States, with more than 2,000 stores. The company is investigating the security breach with the assistance of external experts and will notify affected customers. The RansomHub group has claimed responsibility for the breach and announced the theft of 10 GB of customer data, including personal information of 45 million individuals. The group also released some of the allegedly stolen data as proof of the hack and threatened to release the stolen data by July 22 if the company does not pay a ransom. Recently, Rite Aid confirmed that the attackers gained access to the personal identifiable information of more than 24,000 customers, including names, addresses, birth dates, insurance information, and prescription data.

AT&T data breach impacts almost all customers. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 251/67 (IT) Monday, July 15, 2024. U.S. telecommunications provider AT&T has confirmed a massive data breach in which attackers stole the call records of approximately 110 million customers. The stolen data resided on Snowflake. According to Techcrunch, citing an AT&T spokesperson, the incident occurred on April 19, 2024, when the company detected that attackers had stolen call records. The company responded immediately, enlisting the help of external cybersecurity experts and notifying law enforcement. AT&T's investigation believes the attackers accessed AT&T data on a cloud platform between April 14 and April 25, 2024, stealing files containing AT&T records of customer call and text interactions between May 1 and October 31, 2022, and including January 2, 2023. A joint investigation by Snowflake, Mandiant, and CrowdStrike attributed the attack to the financially motivated threat actor UNC5537. Mandiant stated that the attackers used the stolen customer credentials to target at least 165 other organizations, including TicketMaster, Neiman Marcus, and Ticketek.

Military personnel from Middle Eastern countries are being targeted by GuardZoo malware. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 246/67 (IT) for Thursday, July 11, 2024, reports that military personnel from Middle Eastern countries are being targeted by a cyberattack through malware called GuardZoo. This is an Android operating system information-gathering malware. It is estimated that the campaign began in October 2019 and has been linked to the Houthi group. Lookout's report found that the campaign has more than 450 military victims, primarily located in Egypt, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Turkey, the United Arab Emirates, and Yemen. Data suggests that most infections occurred within Yemen. GuardZoo is a modified version of the Android remote access trojan (RAT) known as Dendroid RAT, first discovered in 2014. Codebase changes were made to add new functionality and remove unused functions, and it uses an ASP.NET-built C2 backend. The attacks used WhatsApp and WhatsApp Business as channels for malware distribution, including direct browser downloads. Lookout researchers stated, "GuardZoo focuses on stealing photos, documents, and map files from victims' devices, specifically mapping files, suggesting threat actors may be interested in tracking military troop movements." GuardZoo is used to collect both tactical and strategic military intelligence, which may be used to benefit other operations the Houthi group is undertaking.

Apache HTTP Server fixes vulnerability CVE-2024-39884. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 243/67 (IT) Tuesday, July 9, 2024. The Apache Software Foundation has fixed multiple vulnerabilities in Apache HTTP Server, including denial-of-service (DoS), Remote Code Execution, and Unauthorized access. One of these vulnerabilities is a Critical vulnerability, CVE-2024-39884, a source code disclosure vulnerability. CVE-2024-39884 is caused by a vulnerability in the handling of legacy content-type configurations in Apache HTTP Server version 2.4.60. When using the "AddType" directive and similar settings under certain conditions, it may expose the source code of files that should be processed, such as server scripts and configuration files, allowing attackers to see sensitive information in those files. Apache recommends that users update to version 2.4.61 to fix this issue.

LockBit ransomware group claims to have hacked Fairfield Memorial Hospital in the US. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 239/67 (IT) Friday, July 5, 2024. The LockBit ransomware group has claimed responsibility for hacking the systems of Fairfield Memorial Hospital in Illinois, USA. This incident is another example of US healthcare facilities experiencing cybersecurity breaches. Fairfield Memorial Hospital is located in Fairfield, Illinois, has 25 emergency beds, and more than 400 staff members. The hospital provides a variety of medical services, including emergency services, general surgery, intensive care unit (ICU), and orthopedics. The LockBit group claims to have stolen data from the hospital's healthcare infrastructure and added it to the group's website. The stolen data will be released on July 17, 2024. In addition, researchers from Hack Manack reported that the ransomware group also claimed responsibility for hacking Merryman House and the Florida Department of Health, attacks that put people's lives at risk. This week, Wayne Memorial Hospital in Pennsylvania also fell victim to a cyberattack by the Monti group. And in February, Lurie Children's Hospital, one of the leading children's hospitals in the United States, experienced a cyberattack that impacted operations. Currently, the US healthcare infrastructure continues to face increasing risks from cyberattacks.

Prudential Financial data breach affects more than 2.5 million individuals. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 237/67 (IT) Thursday, July 4, 2024. Insurance company Prudential Financial has confirmed a data breach that occurred in February 2024, affecting over 2.5 million people. The incident occurred on February 4, 2024, and was discovered on February 5, 2024. Although the company did not disclose details of the attack, the Alphv/BlackCat ransomware group claimed responsibility for hacking the security system. The company initially reported in March that the incident affected more than 36,000 individuals. Accessed data included names, addresses, driver's license numbers, and non-driver identification card numbers. In an updated statement, Prudential Financial revealed the incident affected 2,556,210 individuals, and the company is offering two years of free credit monitoring services to those affected.

Landmark administrators reported detecting the breach on May 13th, with evidence suggesting attackers accessed files containing sensitive data such as names, addresses, birth dates, social security numbers, driver's license numbers, passport numbers, financial account numbers, taxpayer identification numbers, medical information, health insurance policy numbers, and life and annuity policy information. Researchers warn that the Mirai botnet is being exploited in end-of-life (EoL) Zyxel NAS devices. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 229/67 (IT) Thursday, June 27, 2024. Researchers from the Shadowserver Foundation warn that the Mirai botnet has started exploiting a recently disclosed vulnerability, CVE-2024-29973 (CVSS score 9.8), in end-of-life (EoL) Zyxel NAS devices. This vulnerability is a command injection vulnerability in the “setCookie” parameter in Zyxel NAS326 firmware prior to V5.21(AAZF.17)C0 and NAS542 firmware prior to V5.21(ABAG.14)C0. An unauthenticated attacker can exploit this vulnerability to execute certain operating system (OS) commands by sending a specifically crafted HTTP POST request. The vulnerability affects NAS326 running firmware version 5.21(AAZF.16)C0 and earlier, and NAS542 running firmware version 5.21(ABAG.13)C0 and older. Currently, researchers from the Shadowserver Foundation report they have started observing attacks exploiting this vulnerability from a botnet similar to Mirai. Experts recommend replacing end-of-life (EoL) devices, which have been found to have publicly disclosed PoCs exploited.

Lockbit claims to have hacked the US Federal Reserve. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 227/67 (IT) on Wednesday, June 26, 2024. The Lockbit Ransomware group claims to have breached the systems of the Federal Reserve and stolen 33 terabytes of sensitive data. Lockbit added the Federal Reserve to its website and threatened to release the stolen data on June 25, 2024, at 20:27:10 UTC. However, they have not yet released any sample of the stolen data. Many experts are skeptical of Lockbit's announcement, as the Federal Reserve is a high-profile target, and a data breach could have serious consequences. Many experts believe the group's announcement is just a ploy for attention. The FBI has invited victims of Lockbit Ransomware to come forward, as there are more than 7,000 decryption keys that can help victims recover their data and get back online for free. Bryan Vorndran, Assistant Director of the FBI Cyber Division, said during the 2024 Boston Conference on Cyber Security that the FBI is contacting Lockbit victims and encouraging anyone who suspects they are a victim to visit the Internet Crime Complaint Center at ic3.gov.

Neiman Marcus data breach disclosed after hackers offered to sell information. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 226/67 (IT) Wednesday, June 26, 2024. Neiman Marcus has disclosed a data breach affecting 64,000 people, as hackers announced the sale of customer data. The investigation found that hackers gained access to personal information such as names, contact information, birthdays, and gift card numbers, but did not disclose gift card PINs. Neiman Marcus took control of the issue and immediately disabled access to the database, while also launching an investigation with cybersecurity experts and law enforcement. After the breach was revealed, a hacker using the name ‘Sp1d3r’ announced the sale of the Neiman Marcus database on a cybercrime forum, stating that they were demanding a ransom from the company, but the company refused to pay. The data was sold for $150,000 and claimed to contain information on over 180 million users, including information such as names, addresses, birthdays, email addresses, and some social security numbers. The campaign reportedly targeted customers who stored data on the Snowflake cloud, which is accessed by at least 165 organizations such as Ticketmaster, Santander Bank, Anheuser-Busch, Allstate, Advance Auto Parts, Mitsubishi, Progressive, and State Farm. Neiman Marcus confirmed to SecurityWeek that the incident was related to the Snowflake attack and is notifying the 64,000 affected customers, adding that the hacker's claims are exaggerated.

Threat Actor is selling 30 million customer records allegedly stolen from TEG. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 225/67 (IT) Tuesday, June 25, 2024. A Threat Actor is offering for sale customer data allegedly stolen from the Australian ticketing company TEG. TEG (Ticketek Entertainment Group) is an Australian company operating in the live entertainment and ticketing industry. The company operates in several countries and sells more than 30 million tickets annually for more than 30,000 events, including live sports, concerts, theater performances, festivals, and exhibitions. TechCrunch reported that a Threat Actor was found offering stolen customer data from TEG on a popular forum. The Threat Actor claims to have data from over 30 million users, such as names, usernames, gender, birthdays, passwords, and email addresses. They shared some sample data as proof. In May, Ticketek disclosed a cyberattack affecting Ticketek Australia user account data. This data was stored on a cloud platform, and although Ticketek did not disclose the provider's name, experts believe it may be Snowflake. TechCrunch is verifying some of the data, but Snowflake has not yet commented on the TEG data breach.

CDK Global outage caused by BlackSuit Ransomware attack. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 223/67 (IT) Monday, June 24, 2024. The BlackSuit Ransomware group is behind the CDK Global IT system outage that significantly impacted car dealership operations across North America. According to multiple sources, one source told BleepingComputer that CDK is negotiating with the ransomware group to obtain a decryptor to prevent the leak of stolen data. The negotiations came after a BlackSuit Ransomware attack forced CDK to shut down its IT systems and data centers to prevent the spread of the attack, including the car dealership platform. The company attempted to restore services on Wednesday but encountered a second cyber incident, forcing another complete shutdown of its IT systems. CDK is a Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) provider whose platform is used by car dealerships for all aspects of operations, including sales, finance, inventory, service, and other back-office tasks. The largest car dealerships, Penske Automotive Group and Sonic Automotive, both revealed they were affected by the outage. BleepingComputer contacted CDK for more information about the incident but has not yet received a response. The BlackSuit group launched in May 2023 and is suspected to be a rebrand of the Royal Ransomware group. An FBI and CISA report revealed that Royal and BlackSuit use similar tactics and encryption coding.

Crown Equipment confirms cyberattack disrupted manufacturing. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 221/67 (IT) Friday, June 21, 2024. Crown Equipment, a forklift manufacturer, confirmed it suffered a cyberattack earlier this month that disrupted production at its plants. Crown is one of the world's largest forklift manufacturers, with 19,600 employees and more than 24 manufacturing facilities worldwide. On June 8, Crown employees reported that the company had been hacked and all IT systems were shut down. Employees were warned to be wary of phishing emails. The IT outage impacted employees' ability to record work hours, access service manuals, and, in some cases, deliver machinery. The company is currently bringing systems back online, although production remains disrupted. Crown has not disclosed the nature of the cyberattack, but international cybercrime organizations speculate that the company may have experienced a ransomware attack. If it is a ransomware attack, it means that the organization's data may have been stolen from the attack and will be disclosed if a ransom is not paid. VMware Releases Patches for Cloud Foundation, vCenter Server, and vSphere ESXi Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 217/67 (IT) Wednesday, June 19, 2024 VMware has released updates to address Critical vulnerabilities affecting Cloud Foundation, vCenter Server, and vSphere ESXi that could be exploited for privilege escalation and remote code execution. The vulnerabilities are as follows: – CVE-2024-37079 and CVE-2024-37080 (CVSS Score: 9.8) are Multiple heap-overflow vulnerabilities in the DCE/RPC protocol implementation that allow a malicious actor with network access to the vCenter Server to achieve remote code execution by sending specially crafted network packets. – CVE-2024-37081 (CVSS Score: 7.8) is a Multiple local privilege escalation vulnerability in VMware vCenter due to a sudo misconfiguration, which a low-privileged user can exploit to gain root privileges. Researchers Hao Zheng and Zibo Li from Chinese cybersecurity firm QiAnXin LegendSec are credited with discovering and reporting CVE-2024-37079 and CVE-2024-37080. CVE-2024-37081 is credited to Matei “Mal” Badanoiu at Deloitte Romania. All three vulnerabilities, affecting vCenter Server versions 7.0 and 8.0, have been addressed in versions 7.0 U3r, 8.0 U1e, and 8.0 U2d.

CISA adds Android Pixel, Microsoft Windows, Progress Telerik Report Server to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 215/67 (IT) Tuesday, June 18, 2024. The US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added three vulnerabilities – Android Pixel, Microsoft Windows, and Progress Telerik Report Server – to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog. – CVE-2024-32896 is a privilege escalation vulnerability in Android's Pixel Firmware, which has been exploited as a zero-day. – CVE-2024-26169 is a privilege escalation vulnerability in Microsoft Windows Error Reporting Service, which can be exploited to gain SYSTEM privileges. – CVE-2024-4358 is an authentication bypass vulnerability in Telerik Report Server that unauthenticated attackers can exploit to access restricted functionality. To mitigate the risk of these vulnerabilities, agencies under the Federal Civilian Executive Branch (FCEB) must remediate the identified vulnerabilities by the due date. To prevent attacks and exploitation of these vulnerabilities, experts recommend that private sector organizations also review the catalog and address these vulnerabilities. CISA has mandated that government agencies remediate these vulnerabilities by July 4, 2024.

The TellYouThePass Ransomware group has exploited a recently patched vulnerability, CVE-2024-4577, a remote code execution flaw in PHP, by deploying webshells and executing encryptor payloads on targeted systems. The attacks began on June 8th, following the release of security updates by PHP maintainers. TellYouThePass Ransomware is known for quickly exploiting publicly disclosed vulnerabilities. In November, they exploited a remote code execution vulnerability in Apache ActiveMQ, and in December 2021, they leveraged the Log4j vulnerability to attack organizations. In the latest incidents observed by researchers at cybersecurity firm Imperva, TellYouThePass utilized the critical CVE-2024-4577 flaw to execute malicious PHP code, employing the Windows mshta.exe binary to run a malicious HTML Application (HTA) file. The vulnerability was discovered on May 7th by Orange Tsai of Devcore, who reported it to the PHP team, and a fix was released on June 6th with the release of PHP versions 8.3.8, 8.2.20, and 8.1.29.

Frontier Communications data breach impacts over 750,000 individuals. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 206/67 (IT) Tuesday, June 11, 2024. A ransomware group called RansomHub claims to have stolen data from over 2 million customers of Frontier Communications, an American telecommunications company. The stolen data includes names, emails, Social Security numbers (SSNs), birth dates, and phone numbers. RansomHub has released images of the stolen data as proof and threatened to publish it if the victim does not pay a ransom within a specified timeframe. In April, Frontier Communications notified the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) that it had to shut down some systems after a cyberattack. The incident was reported on April 14th after unauthorized Threat Actors gained access to parts of its IT environment. The company launched a data breach investigation, assisted by leading cybersecurity experts, and began containment efforts. Initially, the company did not provide details about the attack, but last week started notifying over 751,895 individuals that their personal information had been stolen. To assist affected customers, Frontier Communications is offering one year of free credit monitoring and identity theft resolution services to affected individuals and advises customers to be wary of scams or suspicious transactions.

SolarWinds patches multiple vulnerabilities in Serv-U and SolarWinds Platform. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 204/67 (IT) Monday, June 10, 2024. SolarWinds has released patches to address multiple high-severity vulnerabilities in Serv-U and SolarWinds Platform affecting Platform 2024.1 SR 1 and earlier versions. One of the fixed vulnerabilities, reported by a penetration tester working with NATO, is CVE-2024-28996 (CVSS score 7.5), which allowed users to query the SolarWinds database for information about the network. This vulnerability was discovered by Nils Putnins from the NATO Communications and Information Agency. SolarWinds also addressed several other externally reported vulnerabilities, including CVE-2024-28999 (CVSS score 6.4) and CVE-2024-29004 (CVSS score 7.1), which are a race condition and an XSS bug, respectively, residing in the web console. Cisco addresses Webex vulnerability exploited in German government meetings. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 202/67 (IT) Friday, June 7, 2024. In early May 2024, German media Zeit Online revealed that threat actors exploited a vulnerability in the German government's Cisco Webex software to access critical internal meetings. In March, German authorities admitted to the hacking of military meetings related to military support for Ukraine, which is suspected to be the work of threat actors linked to Russia. Cisco issued an advisory in early May stating that it had discovered a vulnerability in Cisco Webex Meetings that allowed threat actors to access meeting data and metadata. Experts believe the vulnerability exploited was an insecure Direct Object Reference (IDOR), allowing threat actors to access meeting information such as topics and participants, as well as eavesdrop on sensitive meetings. Although the German government uses an internal version of Webex, some online meeting rooms of senior officials were not password-protected. Cisco confirmed that the vulnerability has been fixed and a global fix was implemented on May 28, 2024. Cisco also informed affected customers that no other attempts to exploit this vulnerability were found and emphasized that the company will continue to monitor such activities and provide updates through regular channels.

FBI offers over 7,000 decryption keys to LockBit ransomware victims. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 201/67 (IT) Friday, June 7, 2024. Bryan Vorndran, the FBI's assistant director of the cyber division, speaking at the 2024 Boston Cyber Security Summit on Wednesday, revealed that they have obtained over 7,000 decryption keys for the LockBit ransomware. These keys can be used to recover encrypted data for free. They are calling on victims of LockBit ransomware attacks to come forward to help them restore their data and resume normal operations. “We are reaching out to LockBit victims to help, encouraging those who suspect they are LockBit victims to visit our Internet Crime Complaint Center at ic3.gov.” This assistance to LockBit victims follows law enforcement's seizure of LockBit infrastructure in February 2024 in an international collaborative operation called “Operation Cronos”. At that time, police seized 34 servers containing over 2,500 decryption keys, which helped create free LockBit decryptors. After analyzing the seized data, the UK's National Crime Agency and the US Department of Justice estimate that the criminal gang and its affiliates extorted up to $1 billion after 7,000 attacks targeting organizations worldwide between June 2022 and February 2024.

CISA adds Oracle WebLogic Server OS vulnerability to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 198/67 (IT) Wednesday, June 5, 2024. The US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added an Oracle WebLogic Server OS vulnerability to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog. The vulnerability, CVE-2017-3506 (CVSS score 7.4), is an OS command injection vulnerability affecting Oracle WebLogic Server OS versions 10.3.6.0, 12.1.3.0, 12.2.1.0, 12.2.1.1, and 12.2.1.2. An unauthenticated attacker can gain network access by exploiting the vulnerability via HTTP to compromise the Oracle WebLogic Server. Successful exploitation could lead to unauthorized creation, deletion, or modification of sensitive data, as well as unauthorized access to all data accessible by the Oracle WebLogic Server. To mitigate the risk of this vulnerability, Federal Civilian Executive Branch (FCEB) agencies are required to remediate the identified vulnerability by the due date. To prevent attacks and exploitation of this vulnerability, experts recommend that private sector organizations also review the catalog and address the vulnerability. CISA has mandated that government agencies remediate this vulnerability by June 24, 2024.

Check Point Issues Urgent Fix for Zero-day VPN Vulnerability Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 194/67 (IT) Friday, May 31, 2024 Check Point has released an urgent fix for a zero-day VPN vulnerability, CVE-2024-24919. This vulnerability is being actively exploited in attacks, and the issue affects CloudGuard Network, Quantum Maestro, Quantum Scalable Chassis, Quantum Security Gateways, and Quantum Spark Appliances. Impacted versions are R80.20.x, R80.20SP (EOL), R80.40 (EOL), R81, R81.10, R81.10.x, and R81.20. Last week, the company warned of a surge in attacks targeting VPN solutions, with a rapid increase in probing of Check Point customer VPN access. On May 24, 2024, a significant number of login attempts using old local VPN accounts with only password authentication were detected. The company initiated an investigation into the attacks, involving its incident response, research, technical services, and product specialist teams. Experts identified compromised customers within 24 hours. On May 28th, experts identified the customer attack method and released a fix for Check Point security gateways. The vulnerability could allow attackers to read certain information on internet-facing gateways with remote VPN or mobile access.

A new family of ATM malware is being advertised for sale on underground cybercrime websites. The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 191/67 (IT) reported on Thursday, May 30, 2024, that threat actors are advertising a new ATM malware, claiming it can attack 99% of devices in Europe. The threat actor is offering the malware for $30,000, claiming that "EU ATM Malware" was designed from scratch and can also target approximately 60% of ATMs worldwide. If these claims are true, this malware could be a significant threat to the global financial and banking industry. The ATM malware can target machines produced by several leading vendors, including Diebold Nixdorf, Hyosung, Oki, Bank of America, NCR, GRG, and Hitachi. The malware's developer claims it can generate up to $30,000 per ATM, making it a lucrative tool for cybercriminals. According to the DailyDarkweb website, the malware is fully automated, making it easy and efficient to use and operate. However, it also supports manual operation mode. The seller offers the malware with various payment options, including monthly subscriptions and upfront fees plus a share of the profits from successful attacks. The vendor also provides a payload option for testing to customers, which is valid for three days.

The Blackbasta group claims to have hacked Atlas, one of the largest oil distributors in the United States. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 184/67 (IT) Thursday, May 23, 2024. The Blackbasta group claims to have hacked Atlas, one of the largest oil distributors in the U.S., operating in 49 states. Blackbasta has added Atlas to its list of victims on the Tor leak site. According to researcher Dominic Alvieri, Blackbasta claims to have stolen 730GB of data from Atlas, including internal corporate data. The group released a set of documents as proof of the hack, such as ID cards, payroll applicant data documents, and images of folders exfiltrated from the victim's systems. However, Atlas has not yet disclosed details of the alleged incident. Blackbasta has been operating since April 2022, using a double extortion attack model, which combines data encryption and the threat of data leaks if a ransom is not paid. This type of attack is similar to other ransomware currently in existence.

A cyberattack on the American Radio Relay League (ARRL) has taken its Logbook of the World system offline. The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) reported on Tuesday, May 21, 2024, that the ARRL announced it is experiencing a cyberattack that has disrupted its IT systems and online operations, including email and Logbook of the World. The ARRL represents amateur radio to government regulators, provides technical advice, and promotes activities and educational programs nationwide. Last Thursday, the ARRL announced it had suffered a cyberattack that disrupted its network and systems, including various online services. The ARRL is currently responding to the incident, which has impacted access to its network and systems at headquarters. Several services, such as Logbook of The World and the ARRL Learning Center, have been affected. In an update on Friday, the ARRL reported, to allay members' concerns about data security, that it does not store credit card information or social security numbers, and it is currently unclear whether it has experienced a ransomware attack or another type of cyber incident. BleepingComputer has reached out to the ARRL for further comment but has not yet received a response.

The FBI has seized the notorious BreachForums website. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 178/67 (IT) Friday, May 17, 2024. An international law enforcement operation coordinated by the FBI has seized the notorious website BreachForums. BreachForums is a forum used by cybercriminals to buy, sell, and exchange stolen data, including personal and financial information. Authorities also seized the forum's Telegram page. The BreachForums website currently displays a message informing visitors that the site has been seized by law enforcement and shows the logos of the agencies involved in the operation, including the UK National Crime Agency (UK NCA), the Australian Federal Police, the New Zealand Police, and the Swiss Police. BreachForums launched in 2022 after law enforcement seized RaidForums. Raidforums, a predecessor to BreachForums, operated from early 2015 until February 2022. Anyone with information that could assist in the investigation of BreachForums v2, BreachForums v1, or RaidForums can fill out a questionnaire on the website.

Threat actors can exploit a zero-day vulnerability in older iPhone models. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 174/67 (IT) Wednesday, May 15, 2024. Apple has released urgent updates to fix a code execution vulnerability in iPhone, iPad, and macOS. The vulnerability affects older iPhone models, designated CVE-2024-23296, which is a memory corruption vulnerability in RTKit. Apple RTKit is a real-time embedded operating system that runs on Apple devices. This vulnerability was reported by Mickey Jin (@patch1t), and the company has addressed the issue by releasing updates iOS 16.7.8 and iPadOS 16.7.8, which include updates for iPhone 8, iPhone 8 Plus, iPhone X, iPad 5th generation, iPad Pro 9.7-inch, and iPad Pro 12.9-inch 1st generation. In addition, Apple has released patches to address other issues in several products. These vulnerabilities can be used for arbitrary code execution, privilege escalation, denial-of-service attacks, and unauthorized access to data.

FIRSTMAC LIMITED disclosed a data breach after a cyberattack. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 171/67 (IT) Tuesday, May 14, 2024. Firstmac Limited is an Australian company that operates in home loans and investments. They have various insurance products backed by international companies like Allianz Group. The international rating agency Standard & Poors has given Firstmac the highest rating for stability and lending capacity. The company disclosed a data breach by a ransomware group claiming to have stolen more than 500GB of data from the company, and the company is notifying affected customers. “As soon as we detected the incident, we took steps to secure our systems. We have also engaged cybersecurity experts to assist us with our investigation. Unfortunately, our investigation has identified that an unauthorized third party accessed some customer data.” The personal information disclosed includes names, contact information (residential address, email address, and/or telephone number), date of birth, bank account details, and driver's license numbers. Currently, there is no evidence of impact to current customer accounts, and they note that their funds remain secure. Firstmac Limited is providing identity theft protection services to affected customers and also recommends vigilance and monitoring of bank accounts for suspicious activity.

The UK confirms that the Ministry of Defence was breached by the disclosure of payroll data. The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) reported on Thursday, May 9, 2024, that the UK Government confirmed a threat actor had breached Ministry of Defence data, accessing parts of the military's payment network. The compromised system contained personal information of active and reserve personnel, including some retired veterans. Defence Secretary Grant Shapps said the MoD was aware of the access and isolated the system to prevent the spread of the threat and stopped all payments. The incident did not affect salaries, pension payments to veterans. The compromised system contained personal data, including names and bank details, and in some cases, the addresses of those affected. The data belongs to approximately 272,000 military personnel and veterans. Currently, there is no evidence that hackers stole any other data. Those affected by the breach will be notified by letter about the incident and the information that may have been exposed.

The city of Wichita immediately began responding to the incident to prevent the spread of the threat and is investigating the incident with the assistance of security experts and federal and local law enforcement agencies. The city warned that some services may be temporarily unavailable due to systems being taken offline. Panda Restaurant Group has disclosed a data breach that occurred in March, resulting in the theft of personal information from its affiliates. Panda Restaurant Group, Inc. is the parent company of Panda Inn, Panda Express, and Hibachi-San. Panda Express, the largest Asian-American restaurant chain in the United States, has over 2,200 locations and sales exceeding $3 billion. Panda Restaurant Group discovered the security breach on March 10, 2024. The attack affected some of the company's systems. The incident did not affect in-store systems, company operations, and Panda Restaurant Group responded immediately to the incident, enlisting the help of cybersecurity experts. The disclosed information includes names, other personal information, including driver's license numbers or identification card numbers. Panda Restaurant has provided affected individuals with complimentary CyEx’s Identity Defense Total – 3 Bureau Credit Monitoring and identity protection.

A well-known Finnish hacker has been sentenced to more than six years in prison. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 160/67 (IT) Thursday, May 2, 2024. Aleksanteri Kivimäki, a 26-year-old Finnish hacker, has been sentenced to more than six years in prison for hacking into the psychotherapy clinic of the Vastaamo Psychotherapy center, exposing the treatment records of tens of thousands of patients, and attempting to extort money from the clinic and its clients. The man was arrested in Paris in February 2023 and extradited to Finland for trial. The trial concluded in March 2024, with Kivimäki found guilty on several counts. Kivimäki has denied all charges and may appeal, according to his lawyer. Prosecutors had sought a maximum sentence of seven years, given the nature of the crime. Kivimäki has been involved in several criminal cases in the past, including being a member of the hacking groups Hack the Planet (HTP) and Lizard Squad. In 2013, investigators found malicious code on devices seized from Kivimäki that the HTP group used to attack more than 60,000 servers, exploiting a zero-day vulnerability in Adobe ColdFusion. Brian Krebs reported on this vulnerability in September 2013 after hackers breached the servers of LexisNexis, Kroll, and Dun & Bradstreet.

The company has hired external experts to investigate the cyberattack, which has impacted its systems. London Drugs took immediate action to protect its network and data after learning of the attack, including engaging leading cybersecurity experts to conduct a forensic investigation. ICICI Bank, a major private bank in India, has unintentionally disclosed sensitive information of thousands of new credit cards to recipients. ICICI Bank Limited is an Indian multinational bank and financial services company headquartered in Mumbai, providing a wide range of banking and financial services for corporate and retail customers. The bank has 6,000 branches and 17,000 ATMs across India and operates in 17 countries. Healthcare provider Kaiser Permanente disclosed a security breach that may impact 13.4 million patients in the United States. Kaiser Permanente is a US integrated managed care consortium that operates 39 hospitals and more than 700 medical offices, with over 300,000 personnel, including more than 87,000 physicians and nurses. The healthcare provider reported that approximately 13.4 million current and former patients may have had data leaked, including IP addresses, names, and information about member activity on the company's website and mobile app. The exposed data does not include usernames, passwords, Social Security numbers (SSNs), and financial information. In June 2022, Kaiser Permanente disclosed a data breach that exposed the health data of 69,000 patients, which was caused by unauthorized access to an employee's email account by an external actor. CISA adds Microsoft Windows Print Spooler vulnerability to Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 152/67 (IT) Friday, April 26, 2024. The US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added the CVE-2022-38028 Microsoft Windows Print Spooler Privilege Escalation vulnerability to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog after Microsoft reported that the APT28 group, linked to Russia and also known as Forest Blizzard, Fancybear, or Strontium, has used a tool called GooseEgg to exploit the Windows Print Spooler vulnerability CVE-2022-38028. Although GooseEgg is a simple launcher application, attackers can use it to launch other applications with elevated privileges. By exploiting this, attackers can use the tool to carry out various malicious activities such as remote code execution and installing backdoors. To mitigate the risk of this vulnerability, agencies under the Federal Civilian Executive Branch (FCEB) must patch the identified vulnerability by the deadline to prevent attacks and exploitation. Experts recommend that private sector organizations also check the vulnerability catalog and patch the vulnerability. CISA has ordered government agencies to patch the vulnerability by May 14, 2024.

Google has announced an update to Chrome 124 that will fix four vulnerabilities, including a Critical vulnerability, CVE-2024-4058. This vulnerability could be exploited for Arbitrary Code Execution. Google has credited two members of Qrious Secure for reporting CVE-2024-4058, who received a $16,000 reward for the discovery. Qrious Secure are experienced hackers who enjoy finding and exploiting vulnerabilities. Earlier this year, the group also reported two other Chrome vulnerabilities, CVE-2024-0517 and CVE-2024-0223. Synlab Italia, a medical center company, suspends operations after a ransomware attack. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 148/67 (IT) Wednesday, April 24, 2024. Last week, on April 18, Synlab Italia, a medical center company, announced that it had suffered a security breach and had to shut down all computers to limit the damage. Synlab Italia is part of Synlab, which operates in 30 countries worldwide, with 380 laboratories and medical centers across Italy, with an annual turnover of $426 million. As a result of this incident, all laboratory analysis and sample collection services have been suspended until further notice. Customers are advised to contact Synlab by phone, as email services have also been suspended. The company recently announced that it has begun gradually reactivating some services, with no definite recovery timeline specified. The company advises customers to check its website or follow Synlab's social media channels for further updates. Currently, no ransomware group has claimed responsibility for the cyberattack on Synlab Italia.

Experts warn of Critical Zero-Day vulnerability in CrushFTP. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 146/67 (IT) Tuesday, April 23, 2024. Crowdstrike experts warn that threat actors are exploiting a critical zero-day vulnerability in CrushFTP enterprise in targeted attacks. CrushFTP is a file transfer server software that enables secure and efficient file transfers. It supports features such as FTP, SFTP, FTPS, HTTP, HTTPS, WebDAV, and WebDAV SSL protocols, allowing users to securely transfer files across different networks. CrushFTP v11 versions lower than 11.1 have a vulnerability that allows users to bypass VFS and download system files, and this will be fixed in v11.1.0. For clients using a DMZ (demilitarized zone), the CrushFTP instance front-end will be protected from attacks. The vulnerability was discovered and reported by Simon Garrelou from Airbus CERT, who received credit. This vulnerability has not yet received a CVE. It is recommended that CrushFTP users follow the vendor's website for the latest advice and prioritize patching.

The company has released Avalanche version 6.4.3 to address the security flaws. Users are advised to download the Avalanche installer and update to the latest Avalanche 6.4.3. Cisco warns of a global surge in brute-force attacks targeting VPN and SSH services. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 142/67 (IT) Thursday, April 18, 2024 Cisco has issued a warning about a global increase in brute-force attacks targeting various devices, including Virtual Private Network (VPN) services, web application monitoring interfaces, and SSH services since March 18, 2024. Successful attacks can lead to unauthorized network access, account lockout, or denial of service. Targeted devices include: – Cisco Secure Firewall VPN – Checkpoint VPN – Fortinet VPN – SonicWall VPN – RD Web Services – Mikrotik – Draytek – Ubiquiti. Cisco Talos states that some services used in the attacks include TOR, VPN Gate, IPIDEA Proxy, BigMama Proxy, Space Proxies, Nexus Proxy, and Proxy Rack, among others. A complete list of indicators related to the activity, such as IP addresses and usernames/passwords, can be found here: https://github.com/Cisco-Talos/IOCs/blob/main/2024/04/large-scale-brute-force-activity-targeting-vpns-ssh-services-with-commonly-used-login-credentials.txt

The ransomware group Dark Angels claims to have stolen data from chip manufacturer Nexperia. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 141/67 (IT) Thursday, April 18, 2024. Chip manufacturer Nexperia confirmed it was targeted by hackers after a ransomware group claimed to have stolen a large amount of data from the company's systems. Nexperia, based in the Netherlands, a subsidiary of China's Wingtech Technology, designs and manufactures semiconductors for the automotive, industrial, mobile, and consumer sectors. The ransomware group called Dark Angels (also known as Dunghill) announced on a Tor website on April 10th that it had stolen 1 TB of data from Nexperia. The alleged data includes quality control information, customer folders of nearly 900 companies (including major companies such as Apple, IBM, Huawei, and SpaceX), confidential project data, industrial production information, and corporate data. The ransomware group has publicly released some files as proof, but they threaten to leak all the stolen data unless a ransom is paid. Nexperia has confirmed that some of its servers were accessed by unauthorized third parties in March and has notified data protection authorities and law enforcement. The company cited an ongoing investigation as the reason for not being able to disclose further information. The Dark Angels ransomware group is known for its attack on Johnson Controls, where hackers claimed to have stolen 27 GB of data and demanded a $51 million ransom in February. The company said the costs associated with the incident exceeded $27 million.

CISA adds PAN-OS Command Injection vulnerability to Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 140/67 (IT) Wednesday, April 17, 2024. The US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added the Palo Alto Networks PAN-OS Command Injection vulnerability, CVE-2024-3400, to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog. CVE-2024-3400 (CVSS score 10.0) is a command injection vulnerability in Palo Alto Networks' PAN-OS software that allows unauthenticated attackers to exploit the vulnerability to execute arbitrary code with root privileges on affected firewalls. This vulnerability affects PAN-OS 10.2, PAN-OS 11.0, and PAN-OS 11.1 firewalls. Palo Alto Networks and Unit 42 have investigated activity related to the CVE-2024-3400 PAN-OS vulnerability and found that threat actors have been exploiting it since March 26, 2024. To mitigate the risk of this vulnerability, Federal Civilian Executive Branch (FCEB) agencies are required to remediate identified vulnerabilities within the specified timeframe to prevent attacks and exploitation. Experts recommend that private sector organizations also review the vulnerability catalog and address these vulnerabilities. CISA has ordered government agencies to patch this vulnerability by April 19, 2024.

A critical RCE vulnerability in over 92,000 D-Link NAS devices is now being exploited. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 136/67 (IT) Wednesday, April 10, 2024. Attackers are targeting over 92,000 end-of-life (EOL) D-Link Network Attached Storage (NAS) devices. A zero-day remote code execution (RCE) vulnerability, CVE-2024-3273, has been disclosed in D-Link NAS devices. This vulnerability affects several D-Link NAS models, including DNS-340L, DNS-320L, DNS-327L, DNS-325, and others, as first reported by BleepingComputer on Saturday. Successful exploitation of CVE-2024-3273 could allow attackers to execute arbitrary commands on the system and potentially access sensitive information without authorization, modify system configurations, or cause denial of service. D-Link recommends discontinuing the use of end-of-life D-Link devices and switching to products with updated firmware. D-Link's policy for end-of-life products is that they are no longer supported, and all firmware development for the product ceases. In recent months, other EOL D-Link devices have been targeted by multiple Mirai-based DDoS botnets.

Hackers exploited a vulnerability in the Magento platform to steal payment information from e-commerce websites. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 133/67 (IT) on Tuesday, April 9, 2024 reported that a hacker group exploited a critical vulnerability in Magento, an open-source e-commerce platform, by inserting a backdoor into e-commerce websites. The attack exploited vulnerability CVE-2024-20720 (CVSS score: 9.1), "Improper Neutralization of Special Elements," which could pave the way for arbitrary code execution. The company issued a fix as part of a security update released on February 13, 2024. Sansec said it discovered "cleverly crafted layout templates in the database" used to automatically insert malicious code to execute arbitrary commands. The command is 'sed,' which is used to insert a code-execution backdoor responsible for delivering the Stripe Payment Skimmer to intercept and steal financial information to another compromised Magento store website. The Russian government ordered six individuals involved to compensate the base that used skimmer malware to steal credit card and payment information from foreign e-commerce stores since at least the end of 2017. The suspects include Denis Priymachenko, Alexander Aseyev, Alexander Basov, Dmitry Kolpakov, Vladislav Patyuk, and Anton Tolmachev. The Prosecutor General's Office of the Russian Federation stated that members of the hacker group illegally obtained information on nearly 160,000 payment cards of foreigners. Afterward, they resold them through underground websites.

The researcher who reported it received a $5,500 reward for the discovery. Wordfence reported the vulnerability to the plugin maintainers on March 25th. Online shopping platform PandaBuy data leak impacts 1.3 million users. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 128/67 (IT) Wednesday, April 3, 2024. Data of more than 1.3 million customers on the online shopping platform PandaBuy has been leaked. This occurred due to two attackers exploiting multiple vulnerabilities to breach the system. The attackers, named ‘Sanggiero’ and ‘IntelBoker,’ claimed to have breached PandaBuy by exploiting several critical vulnerabilities in the platform's API and other vulnerabilities that allowed access to the website's internal services. The stolen data includes User ID, first name, last name, phone number, email, login IP, Order Data, Order_Id, Zip, Country, and more. Troy Hunt, creator of Have I Been Pwned (HIBP), tested password reset requests using the leaked addresses and confirmed that at least 1.3 million email addresses are valid and originated from PandaBuy. PandaBuy has not made any statement regarding the data breach. Therefore, users of PandaBuy accounts should reset their passwords as soon as possible.

Cisco released updates to address several high-severity vulnerabilities affecting IOS and IOS XE Software, as follows: – CVE-2024-20311 Successful exploitation of this vulnerability could allow an attacker to send crafted Locator ID Separation Protocol (LISP) packets to conduct a denial-of-service (DoS) attack. – CVE-2024-20314 Successful exploitation of this vulnerability could allow an attacker to send certain IPv4 packets to conduct a DoS attack by causing high CPU utilization and halting traffic processing. – CVE-2024-20307 & CVE-2024-20308 Successful exploitation of these vulnerabilities could allow an unauthenticated attacker to conduct a DoS attack. – CVE-2024-20259 Successful exploitation of this vulnerability could allow an attacker to send crafted DHCP requests to conduct a DoS attack. – CVE-2024-20303 Successful exploitation of this vulnerability could allow an unauthenticated attacker to continuously send specially crafted packets, causing a DoS attack. The INC Ransom gang stole 3TB of data from Scotland's National Health Service (NHS). Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 122/67 (IT) Friday, March 29, 2024. The INC Ransom gang has listed Scotland's National Health Service (NHS) as a victim on their Tor leak site. The group claims to have stolen 3TB of data from the NHS. The Ransom group has released sample images of medical documents as proof of the hack and will release the stolen data if the NHS does not pay the ransom. The cyberattack occurred on March 15, 2023. Scotland's NHS, or National Health Service, is the publicly funded healthcare system in Scotland. It provides a range of health services, including hospitals, mental health services, and community care. The Scottish government runs its own NHS in Scotland, separate from the NHS systems in England, Wales, and Northern Ireland. The Scottish government is working with health boards, Police Scotland, and other agencies, including the National Crime Agency and the National Cyber Security Centre, to assess the extent of the data breach and the potential impact on affected individuals. The INC Ransom group has been operating since 2023 and has claimed responsibility for breaches against at least 65 organizations to date.

Fortinet's FortiClient EMS vulnerability is being exploited in attacks. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 120/67 (IT) Wednesday, March 27, 2024. The US cybersecurity agency CISA has warned organizations about a recently disclosed vulnerability, CVE-2023-48788, in Fortinet FortiClient Enterprise Management Server (EMS) being actively exploited. The vulnerability affects the enterprise endpoint management solution and is a critical SQL injection flaw that could allow unauthenticated attackers to execute arbitrary code using specially crafted requests. Fortinet disclosed the vulnerability on February 22 and released patches for FortiClient EMS versions 7.0.11, 7.2.3, and newer. The UK’s National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) and Fortinet are credited with discovering the flaw. On March 21, cybersecurity firm Horizon3[.]ai published technical details of the vulnerability and released a Proof-of-Concept (PoC) exploit. CISA added CVE-2023-48788 to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog on Monday, urging organizations to patch as soon as possible. Fortinet has updated its advisory to add that the flaw is being exploited in attacks.

Cybercriminals accelerate online scams during Ramadan. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 118/67 (IT) Tuesday, March 26, 2024. Resecurity has observed a significant increase in fraud and scam activity during Ramadan in the Middle East. Organizations in the Middle East face increased fraud risks, especially in Saudi Arabia, where consumer spending ranks highest in the region, exceeding $16 billion. This surge is driven by rapidly increasing e-commerce activity, which has attracted cybercriminals seeking to exploit platforms for scams, resulting in significant financial impacts for both consumers and businesses. The overall financial impact is estimated between $70 and $100 million. Resecurity has protected its clients by blocking over 320 fraud and scam attempts impersonating logistics providers and e-government services. Cybercriminals exploit platforms like Sadad, Musaned, Ajeer, Ejar, and well-known logistics services to trick internet users into various scams. Resecurity advises clients not to disclose personal and payment information on suspicious websites or to individuals impersonating bank or government employees. Over 39,000 websites infected with new malware in ‘Sign1’ campaign Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 117/67 (IT) Tuesday, March 26, 2024. Website security company Sucuri warns that more than 39,000 websites are infected with a new family of malware that redirects website visitors to fraudulent domains and unwanted advertisements. The name Sign1 comes from the discovery of JavaScript malware in WordPress custom HTML widgets or within the Simple Custom CSS and JS WordPress plugin that attackers added to compromised websites. Using this method, hackers spread malware to websites without placing malicious code in server files, allowing the malware to go unnoticed for long periods, as it is common for security providers to scan website files for malware rather than checking databases. The injected code is responsible for changing the URL to be executed in the victim's browser every 10 minutes, but only if the visitor comes from major websites such as Facebook, Google, Instagram, and Yahoo. In the past six months, Sucuri has identified more than 39,000 websites infected with various forms of this malware, and recently more than 2,500 websites have been infected in the past two months. Therefore, maintaining security, system administration, and website monitoring should be a top priority for website owners.

German police seized the Nemesis Market. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 116/67 (IT) Monday, March 25, 2024. The German Federal Criminal Police Office and the Cybercrime Unit in Frankfurt have seized the server infrastructure of the global illegal darknet market called Nemesis Market in Germany and Lithuania. This operation was coordinated between German, American, and Lithuanian law enforcement agencies. They also seized 94,000 euros in digital currency. Nemesis Market has been operating since 2021, with over 150,000 users and more than 1,100 registered vendor accounts worldwide. Investigations revealed that almost 20 percent of the vendor accounts were from Germany. The marketplace offered illegal goods including drugs, stolen data, credit card information, and a wide range of cybercrime services such as ransomware, phishing, and DDoS attacks. Currently, the Nemesis Market website displays a banner informing users that the site has been seized by law enforcement.

E-Root Marketplace administrator sentenced to 42 months for selling 350,000 stolen credentials. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 109/67 (IT) Wednesday, March 20, 2024. 31-year-old Sandu Boris Diaconu was sentenced to 42 months in prison in the U.S. for operating an illegal marketplace called E-Root Marketplace, which offered 350,000 stolen credentials for sale. He was charged with conspiracy to commit access device fraud and computer fraud, and possession of 15 or more unauthorized access devices. He pleaded guilty on December 1, 2023. The E-Root Marketplace operated through a widely distributed network and was able to hide the identities of administrators, buyers, and sellers. Buyers could search for compromised computer credentials on E-Root, such as usernames and passwords, that would allow buyers to remotely access computers for the purpose of stealing personal information or manipulating computer content remotely. The marketplace also concealed transaction paths by using an online payment system called Perfect Money, which allowed Bitcoin to be converted to Perfect Money. The infrastructure associated with E-Root and Perfect Money was seized by law enforcement in late 2020. It is estimated that more than 350,000 credentials were advertised for sale in the illegal marketplace, with many victims falling under ransomware attacks and tax fraud schemes.

International Monetary Fund (IMF) Email Accounts Compromised Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 108/67 (IT) Tuesday, March 19, 2024. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has disclosed a security breach by a Threat Actor who compromised 11 email accounts earlier this year. The agency discovered the incident on February 16, 2024, and immediately launched an investigation with the assistance of cybersecurity experts. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is a major financial agency of the United Nations and an international financial institution funded by 190 member countries. Its mission is “working to foster global monetary cooperation, secure financial stability, facilitate international trade, promote high employment and sustainable economic growth, and reduce poverty around the world.” The investigation into the 11 compromised IMF email accounts affected has so far not revealed any additional indicators or evidence, and the investigation is ongoing. This incident is not the first time the IMF has faced such problems; the IMF experienced a major security breach in 2011.

The US has seized $1.4 million in Tether (USDT) cryptocurrency from a tech support scam gang. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 103/67 (IT) Friday, March 15, 2024. US law enforcement agencies seized the digital currency, believed to be proceeds from a tech support scam. After the FBI received a court order to seize the funds from the suspected fraud, the money will be returned to the victims. One of the scam's forms targeted elderly victims in the United States. Victims would receive pop-up alerts on their computer screens claiming their system had been compromised. The victims would then be directed to contact Microsoft or Apple and call a phone number belonging to the scammers posing as technical support staff. The scammers would then convince the victims to install remote access programs on their systems. They would tell the victims that their social security numbers and bank accounts had also been compromised. They would then trick the victims into contacting another scammer impersonating an employee of the victim's bank. The victims would be persuaded to convert their money into cryptocurrency and transfer it to digital wallets belonging to the scammers and their accomplices. According to the FBI’s 2023 Internet Crime Report, reported losses totaled more than $12.5 billion, a 22% increase compared to 2022.

Acer in the Philippines has confirmed that employee data has been stolen. A hacker known as 'ph1ns' has published a link for downloading the stolen database, which is available for free download on a data breach forum website. The data belongs to Acer employees. Acer is a Taiwanese computer hardware and electronics manufacturer. The attacker stated that the attack did not involve ransomware or data encryption, but was purely a data theft. They confirmed they did not attempt to extort the company, but presented evidence that they wiped data on the compromised server before losing access. Acer confirmed the data is theirs, but was not stolen directly from the company’s systems. They have reported the incident to the National Privacy Commission (NPC) and the Cybercrime Investigation and Coordination Center (CICC) in the Philippines. The incident is currently under investigation.

CHAVECLOAK is a new banking Trojan targeting Brazilian users via phishing attacks. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 99/67 (IT) Wednesday, March 13, 2024: Users in Brazil are being targeted by a new banking Trojan called CHAVECLOAK, which is spread through phishing emails containing PDF attachments. These emails trick users into downloading a ZIP file and subsequently use DLL side-loading techniques to finally install the malware. The attack chain involves the use of DocuSign-themed lures (electronic signature transaction management system) to trick users into opening a PDF file with a button to read and sign a document. Clicking this button leads to the retrieval of an installer file from a shortened link using the Goo.su URL shortening service. Inside the installer is an executable file named "Lightshot.exe," which utilizes DLL side-loading to load "Lightshot.dll," which is the CHAVECLOAK malware. This allows attackers to steal sensitive information, log keystrokes, and display deceptive pop-up windows to victims.

A group of 40 state attorneys general sent a letter to Meta, the parent company of Instagram and Facebook, expressing "serious concerns" over a significant increase in consumer complaints regarding account takeovers by malicious actors who change passwords. They urged Meta to improve its preventative measures. Once malicious actors gain control, they immediately change passwords, locking out legitimate owners. They then post content, access private messages, contact individuals for scams, and engage in other harmful or illegal behavior. Besides demanding immediate action to improve mitigation strategies and response to affected users, the attorneys general also requested data from Meta on the number of account takeovers in the past five years, suspected causes for the increase, and existing safeguards.

CISA adds Android Pixel and Sunhillo SureLine vulnerabilities to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 94/67 (IT) Friday, March 8, 2024. The US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added two vulnerabilities affecting Android Pixel and Sunhillo SureLine to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog: – CVE-2023-21237: An information disclosure vulnerability in Android Pixel. – CVE-2021-36380: An OS Command Injection vulnerability in Sunhillo SureLine. The Android Pixel vulnerability, CVE-2023-21237, allows for information disclosure without requiring privileges or user interaction. Google addressed this issue in June 2023. The second vulnerability, CVE-2021-36380, is an OS Command Injection vulnerability in Sunhillo SureLine. Exploiting this vulnerability allows execution of arbitrary commands with root privileges. According to Binding Operational Directive (BOD) 22-01: Reducing the Significant Risk of Known Exploited Vulnerabilities, FCEB agencies must remediate these vulnerabilities by the specified deadline to prevent attacks. Experts recommend that private organizations also review the catalog and address these vulnerabilities in their infrastructure. CISA has ordered federal civilian agencies to remediate these vulnerabilities by March 26, 2024.

'Lotus Bane,' a new APT group, is behind attacks on Vietnamese financial organizations. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 93/67 (IT) reported on Friday, March 8, 2024, that financial organizations in Vietnam have been targeted by a new cyber attacker group called Lotus Bane. This is part of a cyber attack first detected in March 2023. Group-IB said that this is an advanced persistent threat (APT) group, believed to have been active since 2022. The exact specifics of the attack patterns are still unknown. Group-IB explains that the techniques used by Lotus Bane overlap with OceanLotus, a Vietnamese threat group also known as APT32, Canvas Cyclone (formerly Bismuth), and Cobalt Kitty. This stems from the use of malware such as PIPEDANCE. It is worth noting that PIPEDANCE was first documented by Elastic Security Labs in February 2023, linked to cyber attacks targeting an unnamed organization in Vietnam in late December 2022. The Lotus Bane group was involved in the attack, primarily targeting the banking sector in the APAC region. Although the attacks took place in Vietnam, their sophisticated methods indicate the potential for attacks on other countries within the APAC group. Ongoing investigations may shed more light on their origins. The presence and activities of the Lotus Bane group in the APAC region highlight the need for continuous vigilance and strong cybersecurity measures.

Cybersecurity alert: Beware of hackers sending phishing messages to hack your Facebook page. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) prevention methods are as follows: 1. Do not use easily guessed passwords. Set complex passwords with special characters, uppercase and lowercase letters, and numbers. Use Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) as a minimum. 2. Users with social media accounts that use the same password as their email or other platforms are at high risk of having another system using the same password easily accessed. 3. Enable login notifications for social media. If someone logs in from a device or browser not normally used, the platform will send a notification immediately. 4. Do not fall for emails prompting you to change your password without your initiation. If you need to change your password, go directly to the platform's page and change it yourself.

Apple releases emergency updates to address two iOS zero-day vulnerabilities. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 92/67 (IT) Thursday, March 7, 2024. Apple has released emergency updates to address two iOS zero-day vulnerabilities, CVE-2024-23225 and CVE-2024-23296, which have been exploited in attacks. The first vulnerability, CVE-2024-23225, is a Kernel memory corruption vulnerability, and the second, CVE-2024-23225 (likely meant to be CVE-2024-23296), is an RTKit memory corruption vulnerability. Both vulnerabilities allow attackers arbitrary kernel read and write to bypass kernel memory protections. Apple has confirmed that both vulnerabilities have been exploited in attacks. Affected devices include iPhone XS and later, iPad Pro 12.9-inch 2nd generation and later, iPad Pro 10.5-inch, iPad Pro 11-inch 1st generation and later, iPad Air 3rd generation and later, iPad 6th generation and later, and iPad mini 5th generation and later. Apple has addressed both vulnerabilities with the release of iOS 17.4, iPadOS 17.4, iOS 16.7.6, and iPadOS 16.7.6.

Ransomware groups GhostSec and Stormous are targeting attacks in 15 countries. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 91/67 (IT) for Thursday, March 7, 2024. Cisco Talos researcher Hetan Raghuprasad reports that "ransomware groups GhostSec and Stormous are jointly carrying out double-extortion ransomware attacks against various businesses in several countries." These attacks are targeting victims in countries such as Cuba, Argentina, Poland, China, Lebanon, Israel, Uzbekistan, India, South Africa, Brazil, Morocco, Qatar, Turkey, Egypt, Vietnam, Indonesia, and Thailand. The businesses most affected include technology, education, manufacturing, government organizations, transportation, energy, medical, real estate, and telecommunications. GhostSec is part of a coalition called The Five Families, which includes ThreatSec, Stormous, Blackforums, and SiegedSec, founded in August 2023. Late last year, the cybercrime group invested in ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) with the GhostLocker malware, offering it for $269.99 per month. Shortly after, the Stormous ransomware group announced that it would use Python-based ransomware in attacks. Talos' latest findings show that the two groups have joined forces and released an updated version of GhostLocker malware in November 2023, as well as starting a new RaaS program in 2024 called STMX_GhostLocker.

Hikvision Patches High-Severity Vulnerability in Security Management System Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 90/67 (IT) Wednesday, March 6, 2024. Hikvision, a Chinese manufacturer of CCTV equipment, has released patches to address two vulnerabilities in its Security Management System. The most serious vulnerability, CVE-2024-25063, has a High-Severity rating and could lead to unauthorized access. This vulnerability affects HikCentral Professional version 2.5.1 and lower. Hikvision says it's caused by insufficient server-side validation. If exploited, it could allow attackers to access certain URLs that they should not be able to access. The second vulnerability, CVE-2024-25064, has a medium severity rating. This vulnerability affects HikCentral Professional versions 2.0.0 through 2.5.1. Hikvision says it's caused by insufficient server-side validation, allowing logged-in attackers to access resources they shouldn't be able to access by modifying parameter values. Hikvision recommends users patch as soon as possible, as vulnerabilities in Hikvision products can be exploited in malicious attacks.
