Experts have disclosed two critical vulnerabilities in on-premises versions of JetBrains TeamCity software. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 89/67 (IT) Wednesday, March 6, 2024. Researchers at Rapid7 have disclosed two new critical security vulnerabilities in JetBrains TeamCity On-Premises versions: CVE-2024-27198 (CVSS score: 9.8), an authentication bypass vulnerability in the TeamCity web component due to a path traversal issue, and CVE-2024-27199 (CVSS score: 7.3), an authorization bypass vulnerability in the TeamCity web component due to a path traversal issue. These vulnerabilities could allow an unauthenticated attacker with HTTP(S) access to the TeamCity server to bypass authentication checks and gain administrative control of the server. These vulnerabilities affect all TeamCity On-Premises versions up to 2023.11.3 but have been addressed with the release of version 2023.11.4. The company has also released a security patch plugin for customers who cannot patch their systems. Recently, JetBrains also addressed another critical vulnerability in the TeamCity server, tracked as CVE-2024-23917 (CVSS score: 9.8), which could be exploited by an unauthenticated attacker to gain administrative control of the server.

Threat actors hacked Chunghwa Telecom in Taiwan. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 88/67 (IT) Tuesday, March 5, 2024. Threat actors stole sensitive and confidential data from the telecommunications company Chunghwa Telecom, as disclosed by the Ministry of Defense. Chunghwa Telecom Company, Ltd. (Chinese Telecommunications Company) is the largest telecommunications provider in Taiwan and provides PSTN exchange, mobile, and local broadband services in the country. According to the Taiwanese Ministry of Defense, threat actors stole sensitive data from the company, including 1.7 terabytes of military and government documents. This includes contracts between the Navy and Chunghwa Telecom. The data has been advertised for sale on the dark web. Taiwan has become a prime target for cyberattacks before the national elections. Cybersecurity experts say these attacks mostly originate from threat actors associated with China. Taiwan remains the target of numerous cyber espionage campaigns.

EKEN brand wireless video doorbells have a security vulnerability that could allow spying. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 87/67 (IT) Tuesday, March 5, 2024. Researchers from Consumer Reports (CR) have discovered serious vulnerabilities in wireless video doorbell products manufactured by Eken Group Ltd. from China under the brands EKEN and Tuck. These are sold at major retailers such as Amazon, Walmart, Shein, and Sears. The security flaws could allow malicious actors to view video from the devices or take complete control of them. Attackers can exploit the flaws to create accounts in the application and access the doorbell products by pairing them with other devices. Malicious actors can then view images and lock out the device owners. Steve Blair, CR's privacy and security testing engineer, found at least 10 other similar-looking doorbell camera products sold under different brand names, all controlled through the same mobile app called Aiwit, owned by EKEN. Some major online retailers, such as Walmart, have removed the flawed products from their catalogs and offered refunds to customers who purchased the devices. However, EKEN smart wireless video doorbell devices are currently still being sold on Amazon.

CISA adds Microsoft Streaming Service vulnerability to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 86/67 (IT) Monday, March 4, 2024. The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added vulnerability CVE-2023-29360 (CVSS score 8.4) Microsoft Streaming Service to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog. Attackers can exploit this vulnerability to gain system privileges. The vulnerability was discovered by Thomas Imbert (@masthoon) from Synacktiv (@Synacktiv) through the Trend Micro Zero Day Initiative. According to Binding Operational Directive (BOD) 22-01: Reducing the Significant Risk of Known Exploited Vulnerabilities, FCEB agencies must patch the vulnerability by the deadline to prevent attacks and exploitation of vulnerabilities in the catalog. Experts recommend that private organizations also check the catalog and patch vulnerabilities in their infrastructure. CISA has ordered federal agencies to patch this vulnerability by March 21, 2024.

Rhysida ransomware demands $3.6 million for stolen children's hospital data. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 84/67 (IT) Friday, March 1, 2024. The Rhysida ransomware group claims to have carried out a cyberattack on Lurie Children's Hospital in Chicago in early February. Lurie is a leading children's hospital in the United States, providing care to more than 200,000 children annually. The attack caused health services to shut down and some treatments to be postponed. It affected email, telephone, internal internet, and doctors were forced to use paper for prescriptions. The Rhysida ransomware group listed Lurie Children's on the dark web, claiming to have stolen 600 GB of data from the hospital and offering to sell the stolen data for 60 BTC ($3,700,000) to a single buyer. They set a deadline of seven days, after which the data will be sold to multiple buyers at a lower price or for free on Rhysida's platform.

LockBit ransomware group is back in action with a new encryptor and servers. Last week, law enforcement agencies NCA, FBI, and Europol carried out a joint operation called 'Operation Cronos' to suppress the LockBit ransomware group. In this operation, law enforcement seized infrastructure, decryptor data, and shut down the LockBit website used for leaking stolen data. However, the LockBit ransomware group is returning to attacks, using a newly updated encryptor and a new server infrastructure setup for publishing leaks and ransom negotiations. According to BleepingComputer, the operation's negotiation server is back online but is only functional for victims of new attacks. While LockBit was being suppressed, approximately 180 affiliated cybercriminal groups continued ransomware operations. It is unclear how many are still working together in a Ransomware-as-a-Service model, as one publicly disclosed their operation on X. However, LockBit states that they are currently recruiting experienced pentesters to rejoin the operation, which may lead to increased attacks in the future.

Cencora, a pharmaceutical giant, has been hit by a cyberattack, with data stolen from its IT systems. Cencora, formerly known as AmerisourceBergen, provides pharmaceutical services, distributing medicines and solutions for medical offices, pharmacies, and animal health. The company reported revenue of $262.2 billion in fiscal year 2023 and has approximately 46,000 employees. On February 21, 2024, Cencora discovered that its data had been stolen, some of which may include personal information. The company filed an 8-K form with the SEC. Cencora says it has taken containment steps and launched an investigation with the help of law enforcement, external cybersecurity experts, and external consultants to examine the incident. The company has confirmed that the cyberattack is not related to the Optum Change Healthcare ransomware attack that led to disruptions in prescription billing. Currently, there is no additional information on which attackers or ransomware are claiming responsibility for the attack.

LiteSpeed plugin vulnerability in WordPress puts over 5 million websites at risk. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 81/67 (IT) on Thursday, February 29, 2024, disclosed a security vulnerability in the LiteSpeed Cache plugin in WordPress that could allow unauthorized users to escalate their privileges. The vulnerability, identified as CVE-2023-40000, was patched in October 2023 in version 5.7.0.1. The LiteSpeed Cache plugin has been installed over 5 million times, with the latest version, 6.1, released on February 5, 2024. However, WordPress security authorities say CVE-2023-40000 resulted from a lack of user input sanitization and output escaping. The vulnerability is rooted in a function called update_cdn_status() and is reproducible in default installations. "Because the XSS payload is placed as an admin notice, and admin notices can be displayed on wp-admin endpoints, this vulnerability can easily be exploited by users with access to the wp-admin area." This allows authenticated attackers with contributor-level privileges and above to inject arbitrary web scripts into web pages that will execute whenever a user accesses the injected page.

ThyssenKrupp, a steel giant, confirms a cyberattack on its automotive division. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 80/67 (IT) Wednesday, February 28, 2024. ThyssenKrupp confirmed a systems breach attack on its automotive division last week, forcing IT systems to shut down to respond to the threat. ThyssenKrupp is one of the world's largest steel producers, with more than 100,000 employees and annual revenue of more than $44.4 billion (2022). A company spokesperson confirmed that the attack only affected the Thyssenkrupp Automotive Body Solutions business unit. The Automotive Body Solutions IT security team worked with the ThyssenKrupp Group IT security team to contain the threat. Therefore, various security measures were implemented, and some system applications were temporarily shut down. ThyssenKrupp further clarified that none of the other units were affected by the cyberattack. BleepingComputer contacted ThyssenKrupp to inquire about the reported outage. The company confirmed that production systems were shut down but clarified that customers were not affected. Currently, no ransomware group or threat actor has claimed responsibility for the attack on ThyssenKrupp. Thus the type of breach remains unknown.

Cyberattack against the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 78/67 (IT) Tuesday, February 27, 2024. The Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP), Canada's federal and national law enforcement agency, has confirmed being targeted by a cyberattack. The RCMP also reported the incident to the Office of the Privacy Commissioner (OPC). Following the incident, the police are investigating the cyberattack. An RCMP spokesperson said in a statement to CBC News that there was no impact on RCMP operations, and no threat to the safety and security of Canadians. Canadian law enforcement did not provide details about the cyberattack. In November 2023, the Canadian government disclosed a data breach after attackers hacked two government contractors. The Canadian government identified the two contractors as Brookfield Global Relocation Services (BGRS) and SIRVA Worldwide Relocation & Moving Services. The hacks resulted in the exposure of sensitive information of an undisclosed number of government employees. Data belonging to current and former Canadian government employees, members of the Canadian Armed Forces, and Canadian police officers was also exposed.

INTELBROKER hackers claim to have attacked Los Angeles International Airport systems. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 77/67 (IT) Tuesday, February 27, 2024. IntelBroker hackers announced on the Hackread website that they had gained access to the CRM system, a service system of Los Angeles International Airport. They exploited a vulnerability in the target's system. The attack occurred this month. IntelBroker is a notorious hacker group involved in attacks on well-known companies such as DC Health Link, Volvo, and Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE). They were also behind the recent Facebook Marketplace database leak. The hackers claim to have accessed a database containing confidential information of private aircraft owners. The database contains 2.5 million records, including the following information: – Full name – CPA number – Email (including 1.9 million emails – after removing duplicates, 15,800 emails remain) – Company name – Aircraft model number – Tail number (the identification number painted on the tail of the aircraft). This cyberattack did not affect passengers or travelers.

Critical vulnerability in VMware (EAP) requires immediate uninstallation. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 76/67 (IT) Friday, February 23, 2024. VMware recommends users uninstall the deprecated VMware Enhanced Authentication Plugin (EAP), which has an Arbitrary Authentication Relay vulnerability, CVE-2024-22245 (CVSS score: 9.6). The VMware Enhanced Authentication Plugin (EAP) was designed to simplify access to the vSphere management interface through Windows Authentication connections and smart card functionality with Windows Client. This plugin was deprecated in 2021 with the release of vCenter Server 7.0u2. There is also another vulnerability associated with the plugin: CVE-2024-22250 (CVSS score: 7.8). Remediation requires removing the EAP plugin both from the browser plugin (EAP 6.7.0) and the Windows Service (VMware Plug-in service). These vulnerabilities were reported by Ceri Coburn from Pen Test Partners.

ConnectWise fixes Critical vulnerabilities in ScreenConnect remote access tool. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 74/67 (IT) Thursday, February 22, 2024 ConnectWise has announced two Critical vulnerabilities in ScreenConnect remote desktop access: – CWE-288 Authentication bypass using an alternate path or channel (CVSS score 10) – CWE-22 Improper limitation of a pathname to a restricted directory (“path traversal”) (CVSS score 8.4) Both vulnerabilities were reported on February 13, 2024, through the company's vulnerability disclosure channel via the ConnectWise Trust Center. Due to the high risk of these vulnerabilities being targeted, affecting ScreenConnect 23.9.7 and earlier, ConnectWise recommends updating to version 23.9.8 immediately.

XSS vulnerabilities in Joomla could expose millions of websites to remote code execution (RCE) attacks. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 73/67 (IT) Thursday, February 22, 2024. Joomla, an open-source content management system (CMS), has multiple cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerabilities that could lead to remote code execution (RCE) attacks. The Sonar vulnerability research team discovered one of the underlying vulnerabilities, tracked as CVE-2024-21726, which is significant because it affects Joomla's core filtering component. Attackers can exploit this XSS vulnerability to inject malicious scripts into a victim's website. Attackers can steal visitor data, perform malicious redirects, or infect users with malware. In this case, attackers could cause problems by tricking an administrator into clicking a malicious link. Joomla powers approximately 2% of all websites, with most deployments publicly accessible, making these sites potential targets for cyber threat actors. The issue has been addressed in Joomla versions 5.0.3/4.4.3, which have been released. Therefore, users and administrators should update as soon as possible to avoid becoming victims of attackers.

LockBit ransomware gang's website seized in international law enforcement operation Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 71/67 (IT) Wednesday, February 21, 2024 The LockBit ransomware gang's website has been seized by law enforcement agencies, who claim to have disrupted the group's operations and will release details of the operation against the group soon. The group's .onion website displays the message "This website is now under the control of law enforcement," specifically the UK's National Crime Agency (NCA). "We can confirm that LockBit's services have been disrupted as a result of international law enforcement action, an ongoing and evolving operation." The page states that the NCA worked with the FBI and "international law enforcement agencies" under the operation name Cronos. The page also features the logos of Europol and law enforcement agencies from Australia, Germany, the Netherlands, Japan, France, and Switzerland, along with the flags of those countries, as well as those of Canada, Sweden, and Finland. While the website itself is not the ransomware gang's primary tool, Europol has reportedly been credited with shutting down LockBit. So perhaps Operation Cronos has indeed disrupted LockBit's operations.

CISA warns of Cisco ASA/FTD vulnerability CVE-2020-3259 being exploited by Ransomware. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 68/67 (IT) Monday, February 19, 2024. The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) warns that the Akira Ransomware group is exploiting the Cisco ASA/FTD vulnerability CVE-2020-3259 (CVSS score: 7.5) which is commonly exploited, and CISA has added the Cisco ASA/FTD vulnerability to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog. The vulnerability CVE-2020-3259 is an information disclosure vulnerability in the web services interface of Cisco ASA/FTD. CISA mentioned that the vulnerability is being used in Ransomware campaigns, but did not disclose which Ransomware groups are exploiting it. In January, researchers from cybersecurity firm Truesec reported forensic data showing the Akira Ransomware group exploiting the Cisco ASA (Adaptive Security Appliance) and FTD (Firepower Threat Defence) vulnerability. Attackers can use the vulnerability to extract sensitive information from the device's memory, including usernames and passwords. CISA has ordered government agencies to patch the CVE-2020-3259 vulnerability by March 7, 2024, and advised private sector organizations to inspect and patch the vulnerability in their infrastructure as well.

Microsoft released its February 2024 Patch Tuesday, addressing 72 security vulnerabilities, including 2 zero-days currently being exploited. Five vulnerabilities are rated Critical, 65 are rated Important, and 2 are rated Moderate. The two vulnerabilities under active attack are: – CVE-2024-21412 (CVSS score 8.1) – Internet Shortcut Files Security Feature Bypass Vulnerability. This allows unauthenticated attackers to send specially crafted files designed to bypass security checks. Attackers must trick victims into clicking a link to the file. – CVE-2024-21351 (CVSS score 7.6) – Windows SmartScreen Security Feature Bypass Vulnerability. This allows authorized attackers to bypass SmartScreen. Attackers can exploit this by sending malicious files to users and enticing them to open them. ZDI has published the full list of CVEs released by Microsoft: https://www.zerodayinitiative.com/blog/2024/2/13/the-february-2024-security-update-review

A ransomware attack shuts down over 100 hospitals in Romania. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 64/67 (IT) Thursday, February 15, 2024 Romania confirms that a ransomware attack on the Hipocrate Information System (HIS) has disrupted operations at over 100 hospitals. The Hipocrate Information System (HIS) is software designed to manage medical activities and administration of hospitals and healthcare institutions. The Romanian Ministry of Health reported that on February 11, a major ransomware attack occurred on the HIS system, resulting in a system crash, encrypting files and databases. Initially, 21 hospitals were affected, a number later confirmed to have risen to 25. Another 79 hospitals shut down their systems as a precautionary measure. The Romanian Ministry of Health further reported that cybersecurity experts, including those from the National Cyber Security Directorate, are monitoring the situation to prevent other hospitals from being affected. The DNSC reports that the attackers used Phobos Ransomware, also known as Backmydata Ransomware, and demanded 3.5 BTC (approximately 157,000 euros). It is currently unknown whether the attackers stole sensitive data from the affected entities.

Two taxi drivers involved in the JFK Airport taxi dispatch system hack have been sentenced to prison. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 63/67 (IT) Thursday, February 15, 2024. Two taxi drivers accused of participating in a cyberattack scheme targeting the taxi dispatch system at John F. Kennedy International Airport were sentenced to prison by a US court on Monday. The individuals, Daniel Abayev, was sentenced to 4 years and Peter Leyman to 2 years, a $160,000 fine, and nearly $3.5 million in restitution. Both are US citizens residing in New York. They pleaded guilty in October 2023 to conspiracy to commit computer intrusion, working with two Russians, Aleksandr Derebenetc and Kirill Shipulin, from at least September 2019 to September 2021. They paid Russian hackers to breach the JFK Airport taxi dispatch system to manipulate the taxi queue, prioritizing drivers who paid Abayev and Leyman. At JFK, taxis wait in a holding lot before being dispatched to terminals based on arrival order, often waiting hours. The scheme allowed some drivers to skip the queue. Officials say up to 1,000 taxis per day used this method, paying $10 each time to jump the line.

Bank of America warns customers of a data breach from one of its service providers. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 62/67 (IT) Wednesday, February 14, 2024. Bank of America, one of the leading financial institutions in the country, warned customers of a data breach that may have exposed personal information after Infosys McCamish Systems (IMS), a vendor of Bank of America, was hacked last year. The compromised personally identifiable information (PII) includes names, addresses, social security numbers, birth dates, and financial information, including account and credit card numbers. The personal information of approximately 57,028 customers may have been exposed. Infosys McCamish Systems (IMS) is a subsidiary of Infosys BPM Infosys McCamish, with more than 300,000 employees and customers in over 56 countries. The incident occurred on November 3, 2023, when IMS systems were affected by a cybersecurity incident involving unauthorized access to IMS systems, resulting in some IMS applications becoming unavailable. On November 4, 2023, the LockBit ransomware group claimed responsibility for the attack on IMS and claimed to have encrypted more than 2,000 systems. A Bank of America spokesperson did not comment when contacted by BleepingComputer.

The U.S. federal government has arrested two men involved in The Warzone RAT operation. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 60/67 (IT) Tuesday, February 13, 2024. The Department of Justice announced the seizure of domains used to sell the Warzone RAT Trojan for remote access. The seizure is the result of an international law enforcement operation. Federal authorities in Boston seized www.warzone[.]ws and three related domains that sold Warzone RAT malware, a remote access trojan (RAT) that allows cybercriminals to connect to victims' computers for malicious purposes, such as browsing the victim's file system, taking screenshots, logging keystrokes, stealing usernames and passwords, and viewing the victim through their camera, all without the victim's knowledge or consent. The U.S. investigation led to charges against two men: Daniel Meli (27) and Prince Onyeoziri Odinakachi (31). Both were charged with selling and supporting Warzone RAT and other malware. The two were arrested on February 7, 2024, on charges of conspiracy, accessing a protected computer to obtain information, and illegally selling and advertising interception devices. Each faces a maximum sentence of five years in prison and a $250,000 fine.

The Ransomware group Black Basta claims to have stolen three terabytes of data from Hyundai Motor Europe. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 58/67 (IT) Monday, February 12, 2024. BleepingComputer reports that the car manufacturer Hyundai Motor Europe was breached by the Ransomware group Black Basta, which claims to have stolen three terabytes of data from the company. The incident occurred in January when the company experienced IT issues resulting in downtime caused by the ransomware attack. However, the company did not disclose the information. Later, Hyundai informed BleepingComputer that it had experienced a cyberattack without providing details about the incident. Hyundai initiated an investigation into the incident and received assistance from external cybersecurity and legal experts. They also notified relevant local authorities. Hyundai Motor Europe only reported unauthorized access to some parts of the network, allowing attackers to access email addresses, physical addresses, telephone numbers, and vehicle identification numbers of affected individuals, but no financial information has been disclosed. Previously, in April 2023, Hyundai experienced a data breach affecting Italian and French car owners and customers who booked test drives.

Alert regarding a new Remote Code Execution (RCE) attack in Fortinet SSL VPN. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT), the National Computer Security Incident Response Team, has received an alert about a new Remote Code Execution (RCE) vulnerability in Fortinet SSL VPN, CVE-2024-21762, with a Critical severity level (CVSS 9.6). This vulnerability allows unauthorized attackers to execute code remotely. Affected versions: FortiOS 7.4.0 to 7.4.2, FortiOS 7.2.0 to 7.2.6, FortiOS 7.0.0 to 7.0.13, FortiOS 6.4.0 to 6.4.14, FortiOS 6.2.0 to 6.2.15, all versions of FortiOS 6.0. Solution: Update software to the patched version: Fortinet has released patches for the affected FortiOS versions. Users should update their software to the latest version as soon as possible. Temporarily disable SSL VPN: For users who cannot update the software immediately, it is recommended to temporarily disable SSL VPN to mitigate the risk from this vulnerability. Critical JetBrains TeamCity On-Premise Vulnerability Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 56/67 (IT) Friday, February 9, 2024. JetBrains warns customers about a critical security vulnerability in its TeamCity On-Premises continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) software that can be exploited. CVE-2024-23917 has a CVSS score of 9.8. The vulnerability could allow unauthenticated attackers with HTTP(S) access to the TeamCity server to bypass authentication checks and gain administrator privileges. The vulnerability affects all TeamCity On-Premises versions from 2017.1 to 2023.11.2. The vulnerability was discovered by an unnamed security researcher who was credited with the discovery and reported the vulnerability on January 19, 2024. The vulnerability has been patched in version 2023.11.3. Users who cannot update their server to version 2023.11.3 can download a security patch plugin to mitigate the vulnerability. Currently, there is no evidence that this vulnerability has been exploited, but a similar vulnerability in the same product, CVE-2023-42793 (CVSS: 9.8), was exploited last year.

Cybersecurity vendor Fortinet warns of two critical vulnerabilities in FortiSIEM, tracked as CVE-2024-23108 and CVE-2024-23109 (CVSS score 10), which could lead to remote code execution allowing unauthorized commands to be run via crafted API requests. Affected products are: * FortiSIEM versions 7.1.0 to 7.1.1 * FortiSIEM versions 7.0.0 to 7.0.2 * FortiSIEM versions 6.7.0 to 6.7.8 * FortiSIEM versions 6.6.0 to 6.6.3 * FortiSIEM versions 6.5.0 to 6.5.2 * FortiSIEM versions 6.4.0 to 6.4.2 In February 2024, Fortinet updated two 2023 advisories on OS Command Injection vulnerabilities affecting FortiSIEM products. Both issues are linked to vulnerability CVE-2023-34992 (CVSS score 9.8), which was addressed in October 2023.

Cyberattack Impacts Operations at LURIE Children's Hospital Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 50/67 (IT) Tuesday, February 6, 2024. A cyberattack on Lurie Children's Hospital in Chicago has taken IT systems offline, seriously impacting operations and disrupting medical care. Lurie Children's Hospital is one of the leading children's hospitals in the United States, with a wide range of specialized medical services including pediatric surgery, oncology, cardiology, neurology, and neonatology. Lurie Children's is also the acute care children's hospital in Chicago with 360 beds and more than 1,665 physicians on the medical staff and 4,000 employees. The hospital immediately announced its incident response and notified law enforcement. It is working with leading experts to investigate the incident. Lurie confirmed that the attack disrupted access to the internet, email, phone service, and the hospital's MyChat platform. Currently, no ransomware group has claimed responsibility for the cyberattack on Lurie Children's Hospital. Cyberattacks on hospitals are highly impactful and dangerous.

AnyDesk Remote Desktop Software hacked, users should change passwords. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 48/67 (IT) Monday, February 5, 2024. AnyDesk, the maker of remote desktop software, revealed on Friday that it was affected by a cyber attack that compromised its production systems. The German company said the incident was investigated and found not to be a ransomware attack, and it has notified relevant authorities. AnyDesk has revoked all passwords to the web portal, my.anydesk[.]com, and recommends that users change their passwords and download the latest version of the software. AnyDesk did not disclose when its systems were breached, and it is currently unknown whether any data was stolen after the attack. AnyDesk has more than 170,000 customers, including Amedes, AutoForm Engineering, LG Electronics, Samsung Electronics, Spidercam, and Thales. Vulnerabilities in WatchGuard and Panda Security products lead to code execution. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 44/67 (IT) Wednesday, January 31, 2024. Vulnerabilities in WatchGuard and Panda Security products could cause denial of service (DoS) or arbitrary code execution. These vulnerabilities were found in the Panda Kernel Memory Access driver (pskmad_64.sys) installed with WatchGuard EPDR, Panda AD360, and Panda Dome for Windows. There are two vulnerabilities: CVE-2023-6330, a memory pool overflow vulnerability, and CVE-2023-6331, an out-of-bounds write vulnerability. Although both vulnerabilities could lead to code execution, the impact is mitigated because attackers need administrator privileges to exploit them successfully. Both vulnerabilities have been addressed with the release of WatchGuard EPDR and Panda AD360 version 8.00.22.0023 and Panda Dome version 22.02.01. More information about the patched vulnerabilities can be found on the WatchGuard security advisory page.

750 million Indian mobile phone user data found for sale on the dark web. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 43/67 (IT) Wednesday, January 31, 2024. CloudSEK, an Indian data security company, claims that last week, data of 750 million mobile network users in India was found on the dark web, with two criminal gangs offering the data for sale for just $3,000. CloudSEK identifies CyboDevil and UNIT8200 as the sellers of the 1.8TB data, which includes mobile subscriber names, phone numbers, addresses, and identification numbers of those in India. CloudSEK's investigative report found that the leak was not caused by a data breach from an Indian telecommunications provider, but the means of obtaining the data are undisclosed. The company says its initial analysis found that the leak will affect all major telecommunications providers because the leak of personally identifiable information (PII) poses a significant risk to both individuals and organizations, which can lead to financial loss, identity theft, reputational damage, and the possibility of cyberattacks.

Kansas public transportation affected by Ransomware. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 40/67 (IT) Monday, January 29, 2024. Kansas City Area Transportation Authority (KCATA) announced it was hit by ransomware on Tuesday, January 23rd. KCATA is a public transportation agency that operates 78 bus routes with 300 buses. The company reports 10.5 million riders annually. The ransomware cyberattack affected the call center, rendering it unable to receive calls. Although the call center was disrupted, KCATA routes continued to operate normally. Therefore, passenger transport operations were not affected, and all services continued to operate, including buses and air transportation services. Following the attack, KCATA contacted relevant agencies and the FBI. Medusa ransomware claimed responsibility for the attack on KCATA and posted sample data allegedly belonging to KCATA on the dark web. The attackers gave KCATA 10 days to negotiate a settlement and demanded $2,000,000. Medusa also offered the option to extend the deadline for publicly releasing the stolen data for $100,000 per day.

Thousands of GitLab servers are vulnerable to Zero-click attacks. The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 38/67 (IT) on Friday, January 26, 2024, reported that GitLab has released security patches affecting both Community and Enterprise Editions to address a Critical vulnerability, CVE-2023-7028 (CVSS score 10), impacting the following versions: – 16.1 before 16.1.5 – 16.2 before 16.2.8 – 16.3 before 16.3.6 – 16.4 before 16.4.4 – 16.5 before 16.5.6 – 16.6 before 16.6.4 – 16.7 before 16.7.2. CVE-2023-7028 is an authentication bypass vulnerability that allows attackers to send account password reset requests to unverified email addresses, potentially leading to account takeover without user interaction. The vulnerability has been addressed in GitLab versions 16.7.2, 16.5.6, and 16.6.4, with fixes backported to 16.1.6, 16.2.9, and 16.3.7. Researchers at ShadowServer reported 5,379 instances exposed online are vulnerable to this flaw, with the majority of vulnerable servers located in the United States (964), Germany (730), and Russia (721).

Critical vulnerability affects Fortra GoAnywhere MFT. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 36/67 (IT) Thursday, January 25, 2024. Fortra warns of an authentication bypass vulnerability, CVE-2024-0204 (CVSS score 9.8), affecting the Fortra GoAnywhere MFT (Managed File Transfer) product. Fortra GoAnywhere Managed File Transfer is a solution that provides secure and efficient file management and transfer. It is a centralized platform for managing automated file transfers between different systems and applications, enabling secure and controlled data movement across the enterprise network. Unauthorized users can exploit CVE-2024-0204 to create administrator users using the device's administrative portal. The vulnerability affects Fortra GoAnywhere MFT 6.x from 6.0.1 and Fortra GoAnywhere MFT 7.4.0 and earlier versions. Fortra has addressed the vulnerability with the release of GoAnywhere MFT 7.4.1. The vulnerability was reported by Mohammed Eldeeb and Islam Elrfai of Spark Engineering Consultants on December 1, 2023. In February 2023, the Clop ransomware group claimed to have stolen sensitive data from more than 130 organizations by exploiting the zero-day vulnerability CVE-2023-0669 in Fortra's GoAnywhere Managed File Transfer secure file transfer tool.

LoanDepot, a US lending company, has had the personal data of approximately 16.6 million customers stolen. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 33/67 (IT) reported on Wednesday, January 24, 2024, that LoanDepot, one of the largest retail lenders in the United States, confirmed that the personal information of approximately 16.6 million customers was stolen. The company filed further details with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) on January 22, 2024. LoanDepot stated that the cyberattack occurred on January 8, 2024, and was a ransomware attack. The company is still investigating the breach and has enlisted the help of external forensic and cybersecurity experts. Preliminary investigation results show that "unauthorized third parties gained access to the sensitive personal information of approximately 16.6 million customers in their system." LoanDepot will notify affected customers of the data breach and offer free credit monitoring and identity protection services. The company also stated that it is making progress in restoring its lending and social media lending services. Experts have shown that LoanDepot's website was down briefly before being restored within a few hours. However, customers unable to use some LoanDepot services have posted on social media expressing their dissatisfaction with the incident.

VMware Fixes Critical Vulnerability in Aria Automation Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 28/67 (IT) Friday, January 19, 2024 VMware warned customers of a critical vulnerability affecting its Aria Automation multi-cloud infrastructure automation platform. VMware Aria Automation (formerly vRealize Automation) is a cloud automation platform that simplifies and streamlines the deployment and management of cloud infrastructure and applications. It's a comprehensive platform for automation across various environments, including VMware Cloud on AWS, VMware Cloud on Azure, and VMware Cloud Foundation. VMware has addressed the vulnerability, CVE-2023-34063 (CVSS score 9.9), which affects the Aria Automation platform. The vulnerability is a Missing Access Control issue that can be exploited by authenticated attackers to gain unauthorized remote access to organizations and workflows. The vulnerability was discovered by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) team. CVE-2023-34063 affects versions prior to 8.16 and Cloud Foundation. VMware recommends users update their platform installations to version 8.16.

Experts warn of vulnerability affecting Bosch BCC100 Thermostat devices. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 24/67 (IT) Wednesday, January 17, 2024. Researchers from Bitdefender have warned of a high-severity vulnerability affecting Bosch BCC100 Thermostat devices, designated CVE-2023-49722 (CVSS score: 8.3). The vulnerability was reported to the vendor in August 2023 and patched in November 2023. The thermostat includes two microcontrollers working together: a Hi-Flying HF-LPT230 chip, which handles Wi-Fi functions, and an STMicroelectronics STM32F103 chip, which acts as the central processing unit. Attackers could exploit the vulnerability to send malicious commands to the thermostat device. The vulnerability affects the following products: – Bosch BCC101 CVE-2023-49722 Versions: 4.13.20 – v4.13.33 – Bosch BCC102 CVE-2023-49722 Versions: 4.13.20 – v4.13.33 – Bosch BCC50 CVE-2023-49722 Versions: 4.13.20 – v4.13.33. The vendor addressed the vulnerability by releasing WiFi firmware 4.13.33 and closing port 8899. Home users should check their IoT devices and consider isolating them from the network, which can be done by setting up a dedicated network for IoT devices.

Apple has patched a vulnerability in the Magic Keyboard that allowed monitoring of Bluetooth traffic. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 22/67 (IT) on Tuesday, January 16, 2024, reported that Apple released an update to Firmware 2.0.6 for the Magic Keyboard to address a Bluetooth keyboard injection vulnerability, CVE-2024-0230. This session management vulnerability could be exploited by attackers to access accessories and spy on Bluetooth traffic. The vulnerability was discovered by Marc Newlin from SkySafe, who stated that an attacker near the victim could exploit unauthenticated Bluetooth to connect to the vulnerable device and inject keystrokes. This could allow actions such as installing apps, executing arbitrary commands, forwarding messages, and more. The Firmware 2.0.6 update for the Magic Keyboard is available for the standard Magic Keyboard, Magic Keyboard with Numeric Keypad, Magic Keyboard with Touch ID, and Magic Keyboard with Touch ID and Numeric Keypad.

CISA warns that attackers are exploiting a Microsoft SharePoint vulnerability. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 19/67 (IT) Monday, January 15, 2024. CISA warns that attackers are currently exploiting a Microsoft SharePoint privilege escalation vulnerability, which can be linked to a critical remote code execution vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2023-29357. This vulnerability allows remote attackers to gain administrator privileges on unpatched servers. Attackers gain access to a forged JWT authentication token and use it to attack the network, bypassing authentication and allowing them to gain the privileges of authenticated users. Remote attackers can also execute arbitrary code on compromised SharePoint servers through command injection when this flaw is chained with the CVE-2023-24955 SharePoint Server remote code execution vulnerability. Although further details about the exploitation according to CVE-2023-29357 have not been provided, CISA has added the vulnerability to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog and now requires US federal agencies to patch the vulnerability by January 31, 2024.

The X account of the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) was hacked and used to spread fake news about Bitcoin ETF approval. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 18/67 (IT) on Friday, January 12, 2024. Hackers hacked the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC)'s X account and used it to spread fake news about Bitcoin ETF approval. The post stated, "Today, the SEC granted approval for Bitcoin ETFs for listing," and was quickly deleted. This fake news immediately impacted the Cryptocurrency industry, with Bitcoin's price temporarily increasing to $48,000 before dropping to around $45,000 after the SEC's denial. SEC Chair Gensler posted a message from the account disclosing the hack, stating that the SEC has not approved the listing and trading of bitcoin exchange-traded products at this time. It is unclear how the hackers gained access to the SEC's social media account and whether 2FA was used. The SEC has notified law enforcement agencies and is investigating the security breach.

CISA adds Apache Superset vulnerability to Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 16/67 (IT) Thursday, January 11, 2024. The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added a vulnerability in Apache Superset, CVE-2023-27524, to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog. Apache Superset is an open-source Data Visualization and Exploration Platform based on the Python Flask Framework. According to Binding Operational Directive (BOD) 22-01: Reducing the Significant Risk of Known Exploited Vulnerabilities, FCEB agencies must remediate this vulnerability by the due date to prevent attacks and exploitation of vulnerabilities in the catalog. CISA has ordered federal civilian agencies to fix this vulnerability by January 29, 2024. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 13/67 (IT) reported on Wednesday, January 10, 2024, that sensitive documents belonging to the Swiss Air Force were leaked on the dark web as a result of a cyberattack. The BlackCat ransomware group targeted ULTRA INTELLIGENCE & COMMUNICATIONS, a US security provider, and the Swiss Federal Department of Defence confirmed that the Air Force was one of the affected organizations and has launched an investigation. The BlackCat ransomware group stole approximately 30 gigabytes of sensitive documents from the US company. The attack disrupted online payments. In response to the attack, LoanDepot investigated and collaborated with law enforcement and forensic experts to confirm the full extent of the breach. A cyberattack occurred at Beirut International Airport, the capital of Lebanon. The attackers compromised the Flight Information Display System (FIDS). Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 11/67 (IT) reported on Tuesday, January 9, 2024, that hackers attacked Beirut-Rafic Al Hariri International Airport in Lebanon and breached the Flight Information Display System (FIDS). Rafic Hariri International Airport is the main international airport serving Beirut, the capital of Lebanon. The airport is named after former Lebanese Prime Minister Rafic Hariri and is located approximately 9 kilometers from downtown Beirut. The airport is a major gateway for both domestic and international air travel. The cyberattack involved hackers posting messages on screens in the airport. The messages claimed that Hezbollah and Iran are pushing the country towards war, disregarding the Lebanese people. The messages also mentioned the smuggling of weapons to be used for bombing the airport. According to local television station LBCI, the cyberattack also disrupted the baggage screening system, known as the Baggage Handling System (BHS). Airport officials had to use police dogs to complete baggage checks. The cyberattack comes amid heightened tensions between Israel and Lebanon. However, no hacker group has claimed responsibility for the attack so far.

Orrick, Herrington & Sutcliffe LLP is a global law firm serving clients in the technology, energy, and finance sectors on various legal practices including corporate, finance, litigation, intellectual property, and cybersecurity. Ukraine's SBU revealed that attackers linked to Russia hacked surveillance cameras for espionage. The SBU disabled two cameras used by Russian air forces to attack Kyiv on January 2nd. The cameras were installed in a residential building and near a parking lot. Hackers compromised the cameras to spy on air defenses and infrastructure in the same area. They changed the cameras' viewing angles and connected them to the YouTube streaming platform. Since Russia's invasion of Ukraine, the SBU has disabled about 10,000 surveillance cameras that Russia could hack to adjust missile strikes. New version of MEDUZA STEALER data theft tool launched on the DARK WEB. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 5/67 (IT) Thursday, January 4, 2024. Resecurity's HUNTER unit has detected the developers of MEDUZA STEALER, a tool used for stealing information, have launched a new version (2.2). This version has significant improvements, including support for more client software (including browser-based cryptocurrency wallets), an upgraded credit card (CC) grabber, and additional advanced operations for transferring password storage data on various platforms to extract credentials and tokens. Meduza is also a major competitor to Azorult, Redline, Racoon, and Vidar Stealer, which are used by cybercriminals for account takeover (ATO), online banking theft, and financial fraud. Those behind the development of Meduza have publicized this upgrade on various DARK WEB forums and Telegram groups. Currently, MEDUZA STEALER also supports Windows Server 2012/2016/2019/2022 and Windows 10/11.

The Black Basta Ransomware decryptor has been released. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 3/67 (IT) Wednesday, January 3, 2024. Security researchers have released a new toolkit designed to help victims of Black Basta Ransomware. This toolkit can recover stolen files. SR Labs Research revealed in a recent GitHub post that these tools exploit a weakness in Black Basta's encryption algorithm. Analysis indicates that files can be recovered, whether fully or partially, depending on the file size. Files smaller than 5,000 bytes cannot be recovered. Files between 5,000 bytes and 1GB can be fully recovered. For files larger than 1GB, the first 5,000 bytes will be lost, but the rest can be recovered. The tool works when Black Basta encrypts files with only zeros, which is why it only works with larger files. However, the decryption tool will only work with Black Basta Ransomware used in attacks around April 2023. Black Basta is one of the most successful ransomware-as-a-service operations, generating over US$100 million since April 2022.
No date found

Interpol arrests 3,500 cybercriminals and seizes $300 million. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 537/66 (IT) Thursday, December 21, 2023. An international law enforcement operation codenamed ‘Operation HAECHI IV’ has led to the arrest of 3,500 low-level cybercrime suspects and the seizure of $300 million in illicit proceeds. South Korean authorities led the HAECHI operation and worked with law enforcement agencies from 34 countries, including the United States, United Kingdom, Japan, Hong Kong, China, and India. The latest operation, which took place between July and December 2023, targeted threat groups involved in voice phishing attacks, romance scams, online sextortion, investment fraud, money laundering related to illegal online gambling, business email compromise, and e-commerce fraud. Arrests made during this operation involved online gambling criminals in Manila, whom Korean police had been pursuing for over two years. Operation HAECHI IV saw a 260% increase in arrests compared to HAECHI III, which took place between June and November 2022. Interpol and its partners arrested 975 suspects during that operation and seized $130,000,000.

Mr. Cooper (formerly Nationstar Mortgage LLC) is a Dallas-based residential mortgage company with 9,000 employees and millions of customers. It is one of the largest servicers in the United States, servicing over $937 billion in loans. The company has issued a data breach notification warning of a cyberattack that exposed the information of 14.7 million customers who have mortgages with the company. In response to the incident, the company shut down its entire IT system, including the online payment portal used to pay mortgages, for over a week. Further disclosures about the incident revealed that the company found evidence that attackers accessed customer information. The company has reported to the Attorney General's office that the incident affected over 14.7 million customers. The exposed information includes: * Full name * Address * Phone number * Social Security number (SSN) * Date of birth * Bank account number The exposed information may put affected individuals at risk of phishing, scams, and social engineering. Customers should be wary of scams. At this time, no further details have been released about the type of cyberattack, and no ransomware group has claimed responsibility for the attack on Mr. Cooper.

Sophos backports RCE fix after attacks on unsupported firewalls. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 532/66 (IT) Friday, December 15, 2023. Sophos has updated the CVE-2022-3236 vulnerability for end-of-life (EOL) firewall firmware versions after hackers were found to be exploiting the vulnerability. This is a code injection vulnerability in the User Portal and Webadmin of Sophos Firewall that allows remote code execution. Although Sophos automatically patched devices configured to accept automatic security updates by January 2023, more than 4,000 devices remain vulnerable. These devices are older models running EOL firmware requiring manual patching. Hackers have exploited this vulnerability to scan for EOL devices and firmware from vendors. Therefore, it is highly recommended that organizations update EOL devices and firmware to the latest version. If using an older version of Sophos Firewall, it is recommended to update to one of the following Sophos Firewall versions: – v19.0 GA, MR1 and MR1-1 – v18.5 GA, MR1, MR1-1, MR2, MR3 and MR4 – v18.0 MR3, MR4, MR5 and MR6 – v17.5 MR12, MR13, MR14, MR15, MR16 and MR17 – v17.0 MR10.

A new hacker group, "GambleForce," is using SQL injection attacks to target organizations in the APAC region. The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 531/66 (IT), Friday, December 15, 2023, and Group-IB have discovered this previously unknown hacker group. They have been linked to SQL injection attacks against companies in the Asia-Pacific (APAC) region, stealing sensitive data such as user credentials. These operations have been ongoing since at least September 2023. They have also exploited CVE-2023-23752, a medium-severity vulnerability in the Joomla CMS. The group has targeted 24 organizations across various sectors, including government, retail, and tourism, in countries such as Australia, Brazil, China, India, Indonesia, the Philippines, South Korea, and Thailand, with six successful attacks. GambleForce's modus operandi involves using specific open-source tools such as dirsearch, sqlmap, Tinyproxy, and redis-rogue-getshell in various stages of the attack, with the ultimate goal of exfiltrating sensitive data from compromised networks. The attackers also utilize a legitimate post-exploitation framework called Cobalt Strike. Interestingly, versions of the tools found on the attack infrastructure use Chinese-language commands, although the origin of the group remains unclear.

On Monday, Apple released iOS and iPadOS with security patches to address several serious vulnerabilities that exposed mobile users to malicious attacks from malicious hackers. The latest iOS 17.2 and iPadOS 17.2 fix at least 11 documented security vulnerabilities, the most serious of which is a memory corruption issue in ImageIO that could lead to arbitrary code execution when processing certain images. The iOS 17.2 release also addresses code execution vulnerabilities in the WebKit rendering engine and memory security issues that allowed applications to break out of the device's sandbox. The company also fixed a privacy issue in Accounts, an information disclosure issue in AVEVideoEncoder, an extension suite that allowed access to sensitive user data, and a Siri flaw that allowed attackers with physical access using voice bots to access sensitive user information.

Atlassian has found 4 new RCE vulnerabilities in its products. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 524/66 (IT) Friday, December 8, 2023. Atlassian, an Australian software company, has disclosed 4 vulnerabilities that allow Remote Code Execution (RCE). Security patches have been released to address these Remote Code Execution (RCE) vulnerabilities. The details of the vulnerabilities are as follows: – CVE-2022-1471 (CVSS score: 9.8) is an RCE vulnerability in the SnakeYAML library that affects several products. Many Atlassian data center and server products use the SnakeYAML library for Java, which is vulnerable to deserialization that can lead to RCE (Remote Code Execution). – CVE-2023-22522 (CVSS score: 9.0) is an RCE vulnerability in Confluence Data Center and Confluence Server. – CVE-2023-22523 (CVSS score: 9.8) If exploited, this vulnerability allows attackers to perform RCE (Remote Code Execution) by gaining privileges on the machine where the Assets Discovery agent is installed. – CVE-2023-22524 (CVSS score: 9.6) All versions of the Atlassian Companion app for MacOS, except version 2.0.0, are affected by the Remote Code Execution (RCE) vulnerability CVE-2023-22524. This allows attackers to use WebSockets to bypass the Atlassian Companion and MacOS Gatekeeper block lists to allow code execution. It is not clear whether all of these vulnerabilities have been exploited in the wild.

The UK government has strongly denied reports that the Sellafield nuclear plant has been targeted by malware for years. A report published in the Guardian claimed the controversial complex was hacked by "cyber threat groups linked to Russia and China" and that malware was detected in 2015, possibly existing earlier. The report said dormant, embedded malware in an unspecified system could have exposed information related to nuclear material movements and security. The UK government statement affirmed that "there is no record or evidence that Sellafield Limited's network has been subject to a successful attack from cyber threat groups, as has been reported by the Guardian." It added, "Our monitoring systems are robust and we have high confidence that no such malware exists on our systems. All of our systems and servers have multiple layers of protection. The critical networks that allow us to operate safely are isolated from our general IT network. This means that an attack on our IT systems would not be able to penetrate these networks.”

Rhysida ransomware group hacks King Edward VII's Hospital in London. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 516/66 (IT) Friday, December 1, 2023. King Edward VII's Hospital is a private hospital located on Beaumont Street in the Marylebone district of London. It provides specialist medical treatment focusing on musculoskeletal health, the urinary system, women's health, and digestive health. This hospital has a long history, dating back to when the Prince of Wales (later King Edward VII) founded it in 1899 to provide high-quality medical care to the working class. The Rhysida ransomware group claims to have hacked King Edward VII's Hospital in London and added it to the list on their Tor leak site. The ransomware group has published evidence in the form of images of stolen documents, including medical reports, registration forms, X-rays, prescriptions, medical reports, and others. The ransomware group claims to have stolen a large amount of sensitive data, including the data of many patients and employees, including the medical records of members of the royal family, and is about to auction the data for 10 BTC. Typically, the ransomware group plans to sell the stolen data to a single buyer and will publicly disclose the data within seven days of the announcement. Recently, the Rhysida ransomware group added the British Library and China Energy Engineering Corporation to the list of victims on their Tor leak site.

Exploitation of critical ownCloud vulnerability begins. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 514/66 (IT) Thursday, November 30, 2023. Attackers have started exploiting an ownCloud vulnerability after its public disclosure. The vulnerability, CVE-2023-49103, resides in the Graphapi app and allows attackers to retrieve sensitive information, including credentials, license keys, and other system data. This affects Graphapi versions 0.2.0 through 0.3.0 and cannot be mitigated by disabling the Graphapi app. Changing passwords for admin accounts, access keys, and credentials for email servers and databases is required. The vulnerability was disclosed on November 21, along with two other critical vulnerabilities in the software (CVE-2023-49104 and CVE-2023-49105). On Monday, the US cybersecurity agency CISA added the vulnerabilities to its weekly report, although a severity rating hasn't been assigned yet. Shadowserver Foundation, a non-profit cybersecurity organization, warns that it has identified approximately 11,000 ownCloud instances exposed on the internet that are potentially at risk. The largest number of instances are located in Germany (2,000), followed by the United States (1,400), and France (1,300). Russia, Poland, the Netherlands, Italy, the United Kingdom, Canada, and Spain also have exposed instances. Shadowserver warned that the vulnerability is very easy to exploit and advised administrators to follow the mitigation steps outlined by ownCloud.

GoTitan botnet spotted exploiting recent Apache ActiveMQ vulnerability. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 513/66 (IT) Thursday, November 30, 2023. A recently disclosed security vulnerability affecting Apache ActiveMQ is being exploited by attackers to spread a new Go-based botnet called GoTitan, as well as a .NET program known as PrCtrl Rat, which can remotely control malware-infected hosts. The attack involves exploiting a remote code execution vulnerability (CVE-2023-46604, CVSS score: 10.0) that has been used in attacks by various hacker groups, including the Lazarus group, in recent weeks. After a successful breach, the threat actors are found to drop further payloads from remote servers. One of these is GoTitan, a botnet designed to orchestrate distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks via protocols such as HTTP, UDP, TCP, and TLS. Fortinet has also observed cases where vulnerable Apache ActiveMQ servers are being targeted to deploy another DDoS botnet called Ddostf, Kinsing malware for cryptojacking, and a command-and-control (C2) framework named Sliver. Another prominent malware delivered is a remote access trojan called PrCtrl Rat that establishes contact with a C2 server to receive further instructions for actions on the system, such as collecting data files and downloading and uploading files from the server.

Cyberattack on MSP CTS May Impact Hundreds of UK Law Firms Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 510/66 (IT) Tuesday, November 28, 2023. A cyberattack targeting CTS, a managed service provider (MSP) for UK law firms, may have impacted hundreds of them. CTS provides IT services to the UK legal sector. The company announced it is investigating a cyberattack that caused service disruption. The incident impacted a portion of its services and may affect hundreds of UK law firms. The company is receiving assistance from a cyber forensics firm. CTS plans to restore all services; however, it hasn’t provided a definite timeline for full recovery. Estate Agent Today reported that attackers may have exploited the CitrixBleed vulnerability (CVE-2023-4966). This vulnerability allowed attackers to gain initial access to the organization’s infrastructure. On October 10th, Citrix published information about the critical CVE-2023-4966 vulnerability in Citrix NetScaler ADC/Gateway devices. MSPs are high-value targets for threat actors aiming to carry out supply chain attacks.

A worm released by Russian hackers is spreading globally. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 505/66 (IT) Friday, November 24, 2023. A Russian-backed hacker group targeting Ukrainian entities has been using malware for espionage. Whether accidentally or intentionally, the worm-type malware has spread to organizations in other countries. This group, known by various names such as Gamaredon, Primitive Bear, ACTINIUM, Armageddon, and Shuckworm, has been operating since at least 2014 and has been identified as a Russian state security service hacking group. One of the tools used in the attacks against Ukraine is a worm called LitterDrifter. This malware, written in Visual Basic Scripting, is designed to spread from one computer to another via USB drives and has two functions: to spread from USB drive to USB drive and to spread itself to devices connected to those drives. The malware constantly communicates with command-and-control servers operated by the Gamaredon group. The Gamaredon group focuses its attacks on various Ukrainian targets, but due to the nature of the worm, researchers have observed its spread to countries such as the United States, Vietnam, Chile, Poland, and Germany. Researchers have also observed evidence of spread in Hong Kong. This may indicate that LitterDrifter is spreading beyond the intended targets of the Russian hackers.

The Canadian government has been impacted by data breaches from two contractors. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 502/66 (IT) Wednesday, November 22, 2023. The Canadian government announced that two contractors, Brookfield Global Relocation Services (BGRS) and SIRVA Worldwide Relocation & Moving Services, experienced security breaches in October, resulting in the disclosure of sensitive government employee data. This data included information on current and former government employees, members of the Canadian Armed Forces, and Canadian police officers. The government has not yet disclosed the name of the ransomware groups that breached the two companies, but the LockBit Ransomware group has claimed responsibility for the attack on SIRVA, claiming to have stolen over 1.5 TB of data. In response to the security breaches, the Canadian government is offering credit monitoring services and issuing passports to those affected by the incidents. The government advises individuals who may be affected to: – Update login credentials used with BGRS or SIRVA Canada – Enable multi-factor authentication on accounts used for online transactions – Monitor financial and personal online accounts for unusual activity.

U.S. National Security Laboratory Employee Data Leaked Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 501/66 (IT) Wednesday, November 22, 2023. The hacker group SiegedSec has disclosed the personal information of thousands of employees at the Idaho National Laboratory (INL), a nuclear research laboratory and an agency of the U.S. Department of Energy. In a post, SiegedSec claimed to have accessed the data of hundreds of thousands of users, employees, and members of the public, including names, social security numbers, bank account information, and addresses. They posted samples of the leaked data, but it cannot be confirmed whether SiegedSec possesses the large dataset they claim to have stolen. An INL spokesperson confirmed the breach and stated that the laboratory is still investigating the incident. They indicated that the breach impacted a server supporting the Oracle HCM system, which supports INL's human resources applications, and that they took immediate action to protect employee data. The hackers did not state their reason for targeting INL. However, the breach raises serious national security concerns, as INL employees and scientists work on some of the United States' most sensitive national security projects, including protecting critical infrastructure, such as the U.S. power grid, from cyber and physical attacks. Personal information, such as detailed employee and banking information, is a treasure trove for foreign intelligence agencies seeking to penetrate the laboratory.

Yamaha Motor confirms Data Breach following Ransomware attack. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 500/66 (IT) Tuesday, November 21, 2023. Personal information of employees of Yamaha Motor's affiliate in the Philippines was stolen due to a ransomware attack targeting the affiliate. The incident occurred on October 25th and affected a server managed by Yamaha Motor Philippines, the motorcycle manufacturing and sales affiliate in the country. On November 16th, it was revealed that some personal information stored by Yamaha Motor Philippines was stolen. Yamaha did not specify the ransomware group responsible for the attack, but the INC Ransom group claimed responsibility. According to SentinelOne, the INC Ransom group exploited the CVE-2023-3519 vulnerability, a critical Citrix NetScaler ADC and Gateway vulnerability disclosed in July. Last week, the INC Ransom group published data allegedly stolen from Yamaha Motor Philippines, including identification documents, employee badges, and various internal documents. In recent months, the ransomware group has claimed responsibility for hacking into several organizations, including WellLife Network, Decatur Independent School District, Guardian Alarm, EFU Life Assurance, and Global Export Marketing.

Israeli man sentenced to 80 months in US for role in massive phishing campaign. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 499/66 (IT) Tuesday, November 21, 2023. 52-year-old Aviram Azari was sentenced to 80 months in prison for computer intrusion, internet fraud, and theft of sensitive data. He participated in a large-scale spearphishing campaign targeting companies and individuals in the United States and around the world. The man was arrested in September 2019 while entering the United States. From approximately November 2014 to September 2019, Mr. Azari participated in phishing campaigns targeting individuals and companies in the United States and globally. He paid various hacking groups, including some based in India, to send phishing emails to victims of various projects. Upon successfully accessing victims' accounts, they would send the victim's information to Mr. Azari, who then disseminated the information to the media. Officials obtained evidence of over 100 successful attacks by Azari's targets but believe the number of those hacked may be as high as 100 times that amount.

Google warns hackers exploited Zimbra zero-day vulnerability in attacks on government organizations. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 498/66 (IT) Monday, November 20, 2023. Google's Threat Analysis Group (TAG) has discovered that attackers exploited a zero-day vulnerability in Zimbra Collaboration email servers to steal sensitive data from government systems in several countries. Hackers were found to have exploited this vulnerability, CVE-2023-37580 (moderate severity), since June 29th. A fix was released on July 25th with version 8.8.15 Patch 41 of the software, leaving almost a month for the issue to be exploited. The vulnerability is an XSS (cross-site scripting) issue in the Zimbra Classic Web Client. According to Google's threat analysts, attackers exploited systems belonging to governments in Greece, Moldova, Tunisia, Vietnam, and Pakistan to steal email data, user credentials, and authentication tokens. Google's report did not reveal many details about the attackers, but warned about the importance of timely updates even for moderate severity vulnerabilities, as attackers can use them for further attacks. The exploitation of CVE-2023-37580 is one of several examples of XXS vulnerabilities used to target mail servers, such as CVE-2022-24682 and CVE-2023-5631 affecting Zimbra and Roundcube.

Google reveals 'Reptar' vulnerability in Intel CPUs. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 497/66 (IT) on Monday, November 20, 2023. Google's information security engineering team has discovered a new security vulnerability in Intel CPUs that could allow attackers to run code on vulnerable systems. Google has named this vulnerability "Reptar," and it affects a large number of Intel CPUs, including those used in cloud computing environments. Reptar, identified as CVE-2023-23583, allows attackers to leak information from the system vulnerability and use it to steal sensitive data such as credit card numbers, passwords, etc. Google has notified Intel and other industry players about this issue and has implemented mitigations and issued guidance to confirm the problem. They explained that the issue was found in certain Intel processors due to an error in the CPU's handling of redundant prefixes. The company has released patches for this issue. This CPU vulnerability affects several Intel desktop, mobile, and server CPUs, including the 10th Gen Intel® Core™ processor family, 3rd Gen Intel® Xeon® Scalable processors, Intel® Xeon® D processors, and 11th Gen Intel® Core™ processor family, and CPUs used in cloud computing environments, etc. The company is working on a long-term fix, but in the meantime, users are advised to patch their devices immediately.

Samsung Experiences Data Breach Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 496/66 (IT) Friday, November 17, 2023 Samsung Electronics experienced a data breach that exposed customer personal information without authorization. The data breach was discovered on November 13, 2023, and affects customers who purchased products from the Samsung UK online store between July 1, 2019, and June 30, 2020. Attackers exploited a vulnerability in an application, the name of which the company did not specify. The company informed customers that affected information may include name, phone number, address, and email address, stating that financial information was not affected. A Samsung spokesperson told BleepingComputer that the security breach is limited to the United Kingdom and affects only e-store customers. Customers in the United States were not affected by the breach.

CISA adds vulnerabilities in Juniper devices to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 492/66 (IT) Wednesday, November 15, 2023. CISA has added 6 vulnerabilities to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog, including 5 affecting Juniper Junos OS and 1 affecting the support software SysAid SysAid IT. The vulnerabilities are as follows: – CVE-2023-47246 SysAid Server Path Traversal Vulnerability – CVE-2023-36844 Juniper Junos OS EX Series PHP External Variable Modification Vulnerability – CVE-2023-36845 Juniper Junos OS EX Series and SRX Series PHP External Variable Modification Vulnerability – CVE-2023-36846 Juniper Junos OS SRX Series Missing Authentication for Critical Function Vulnerability – CVE-2023-36847 Juniper Junos OS EX Series Missing Authentication for Critical Function Vulnerability – CVE-2023-36851 Juniper Junos OS SRX Series Missing Authentication for Critical Function Vulnerability. FCEB agencies must remediate the identified vulnerabilities by the due date to protect networks from exploitation of vulnerabilities in the catalog. Experts also recommend that private organizations review the catalog to address vulnerabilities in their infrastructure. CISA has ordered federal agencies to remediate the vulnerabilities by November 17, 2023, while the SysAid Server Path Traversal vulnerability must be remediated by December 4, 2023.

Australia's major ports disrupted by cyberattack. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 490/66 (IT) Tuesday, November 14, 2023 reported a cyberattack on DP World Australia, a major Australian transportation company. This may be a ransomware attack. It has resulted in disruptions at major ports. In response to the attack, DP World disconnected systems from the internet and shut down ground operations at ports in Sydney, Melbourne, Fremantle, and Brisbane. Darren Goldie, Australia's National Cyber Security Coordinator, said ships could still load and unload containers, but could not leave port. The Australian government is currently assisting the company in restoring normal operations. DP World has not disclosed any information about the attack. Although the shutdown is in response to a ransomware attack, renowned researcher Kevin Beaumont has reported it as a ransomware attack and that attackers exploited a recently disclosed Citrix Netscaler vulnerability called CitrixBleed, which has been widely exploited in attacks.

The LOCKBIT ransomware group has published data stolen from Boeing. The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 489/66 (IT) reported on Tuesday, November 14, 2023, that at the end of October, the Lockbit ransomware group added Boeing to the list of victims on its data leak site. The group claimed to have stolen a large amount of sensitive data from the company and threatened to publish it if the company did not contact them by a deadline of November 2, 2023, later extended to November 10, 2023. In early November 2023, Boeing confirmed that its services division had been affected by a cyberattack and said that the investigation was ongoing. The attack targeted elements of the parts and distribution business run by the global services division, and the company reported the incident to law enforcement and relevant regulatory bodies. However, Boeing refused to pay the ransom demanded, and the LockBit group has now published over 40GB of data. Bleeping Computer analyzed the leaked data and reported that it mostly consists of backups for various systems. The most recent document in the leak is dated October 22, 2023. It is currently unclear how the attackers breached the company, but some experts speculate that they may have exploited the CVE-2023-4966 vulnerability in Citrix NetScaler ADC/Gateway devices. Researchers at Mandiant have observed zero-day exploitation of this vulnerability since late August.

Police seize BulletProftLink phishing-as-a-service (PhaaS) platform. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 488/66 (IT) Monday, November 13, 2023. The BulletProftLink phishing-as-a-service (PhaaS) platform with over 300 phishing templates has been seized, according to the Royal Malaysia Police. In September 2021, Microsoft reported a large-scale phishing campaign which such a service could facilitate, offering numerous templates for buyers. The service also collected all credentials stolen by members (1,618 at the time) from phishing attacks. With assistance from the Australian Federal Police and the FBI, Malaysian police were able to operate and disrupt several domains used by the illicit storefront. Police arrested eight suspects on November 6. Officials also seized digital wallets worth approximately $213,000, servers, computers, jewelry, vehicles, and payment cards. With the servers seized, law enforcement can examine them to identify users of the platform, some of whom paid a $2,000 monthly subscription fee to access the logs. These phishing pages also proxied their pages through legitimate cloud services, such as Google Cloud and Microsoft Azure, to evade security tools.

Russia's state-owned Sberbank hit by 1 million RPS DDoS attack. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 486/66 (IT) Friday, November 10, 2023. Sberbank, a Russian financial institution, announced that it had faced the most intense Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack two weeks ago. Sberbank is a majority state-owned banking and financial services company and the largest institution in Russia, holding about one-third of all assets in the country. Following the Russian invasion of Ukraine, the bank has faced international sanctions and has been the target of hacktivists several times. Russian news agency Interfax reported that the attack reached one million requests per second (RPS). The latest damage caused Russia's financial system related to the National Payment Card System (NSPK), the provider of Mir cards, to become unavailable on October 30, 2023. They later deleted a post about a data breach affecting customers. The NSPK told the media that the attackers were unable to steal sensitive customer data, as the website did not store such information, and assured that the cyberattack did not affect the payment system. TheRecord later reported that hacktivists from the 'DumpForums' group and the Ukrainian Alliance Cyber Alliance claimed responsibility for the attack, claiming to have stolen 31 GB of data.

MARINA BAY SANDS luxury hotel in Singapore experiences data breach. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 483/66 (IT) Thursday, November 9, 2023. The luxury hotel Marina Bay Sands (MBS) in Singapore experienced a data breach affecting 665,000 customers. The hotel discovered the security breach on October 20, 2023, where malicious actors accessed some customer loyalty program member data on October 19 and 20, 2023. The hotel's security team immediately investigated the incident. Based on their investigation, there is currently no evidence that the unauthorized actors misused the information to harm customers. The hotel does not believe that member information from the Sands Rewards Club casino rewards program was affected. The disclosed information includes: name, email address, phone number, country of residence, and membership number. The hotel will notify affected customers about the issue and report the incident to relevant authorities in Singapore and other relevant countries. Currently, the hotel has not disclosed technical details about the incident.
