Experts warn ransomware groups are exploiting vulnerabilities in Atlassian and Apache. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 481/66 (IT) Wednesday, November 8, 2023. Rapid7, a cybersecurity firm, has observed multiple ransomware groups starting to exploit recently disclosed vulnerabilities in Atlassian Confluence and Apache ActiveMQ, vulnerability numbers CVE-2023-22518 and CVE-2023-22515. Both vulnerabilities are critical, allowing attackers to create unauthorized Confluence administrator accounts and cause data loss. On November 6, Atlassian updated its advisory, noting multiple instances of the vulnerability being exploited and is adjusting the vulnerability's CVSS score from 9.8 to 10.0, indicating maximum severity. The escalation is due to a change in the attack scope, with numerous threat actors and exploits targeting vulnerable internet-facing Atlassian Confluence servers to retrieve malicious payloads hosted on remote servers, which leads to the execution of ransomware payloads on compromised servers. Data collected by GreyNoise indicates that exploitation attempts originate from IP addresses in three different countries: France, Hong Kong, and Russia.

Iranian hackers launch destructive cyberattacks against Israel's technology and education sectors. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 480/66 (IT) Tuesday, November 7, 2023. Israel's education and technology sectors were targeted by destructive cyberattacks in October. The attacks were carried out by Iranian hackers known as Agonizing Serpens, also known as Agrius, BlackShadow, and Pink Sandstorm (formerly Americium). Their attacks are characterized by the theft of sensitive data, such as personally identifiable information (PII) and intellectual property. According to Palo Alto Networks Unit 42, as told to The Hacker News, Agonizing Serpens APT used public and custom tools like Sqlextractor, WinSCP, and PuTTY, and released wiper malware: – MultiLayer, a .NET malware that identifies files for deletion or corruption with random data to prevent recovery and render systems unusable. – PartialWasher, a C++ malware that scans drives and wipes specified folders and subfolders. – BFG Agonizer, malware that relies on open-source software called CRYLINE -v5.0. Unit 42 researchers say the Agonizing Serpens APT group has significantly increased its capabilities and invested resources to evade EDR and other security measures.

Google warns that hackers can abuse GOOGLE CALENDAR. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 479/66 (IT) Tuesday, November 7, 2023. Google has issued a warning about several threat actors sharing proof-of-concept (PoC) regarding exploiting the GOOGLE Calendar service to host command-and-control (C2). This tool, called Google Calendar RAT (GCR), uses Google Calendar Events for C2 using a Gmail account. It was first published on GitHub in June 2023. Threat Horizons Report No. 8 states that the use of this tool has not yet been observed, but cyber threat intelligence has seen the PoC concept shared in underground forums and the Dark Web. Google says GCR works on compromised machines, periodically checking calendar event descriptions for new commands, and executes commands on the target device. It then updates the event description with the command output. This tool operates on legitimate infrastructure, making it more difficult for security personnel to detect suspicious activity.

FSB arrests Russian hackers working for Ukrainian cyber forces. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 475/66 (IT) Friday, November 3, 2023. The Russian Federal Security Service (FSB) announced and released a statement on Tuesday stating that officers arrested two hackers believed to be assisting Ukrainian forces in carrying out cyberattacks against critical infrastructure targets in Russia. The two suspects were detained on the same day but in different areas of Siberia. Both were charged with the serious crime of treason, which carries a maximum sentence of 20 years. One suspect is a student at Tomsk State University of Control Systems and Radio Electronics. Russian media said the investigation found that he had helped a group of Ukrainian hackers in cyberattacks on Russian data infrastructure networks. He was put on a plane and sent to a pre-trial detention center in Lefortovo, Moscow, known as the infamous KGB prison and the former interrogation site for political prisoners. The second suspect is a 36-year-old man from the small town of Belovo, believed to be a member of Ukraine's cyber unit. He is believed to have been involved in cyber operations linked to Ukrainian forces, using malware and cyberattacks to disrupt critical infrastructure networks in Russia.

The British Library experienced a major outage affecting its website and various services following a cyberattack on October 28th. The British Library, the UK's national library and one of the largest in the world, located in London, holds over 150 million items, including books, manuscripts, maps, newspapers, magazines, music recordings, and films. This technical disruption resulted from a cyber incident, impacting the website, online catalog, and offsite services including public Wi-Fi. The incident is currently under investigation with assistance from the National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) and other experts. The library has not released technical details regarding the attack, and it is currently unclear whether the attackers were able to access staff and user data.

Atlassian warns of a critical vulnerability in Confluence Data Center and Server that could lead to data loss if exploited by an unauthenticated attacker. The vulnerability, CVE-2023-22518, has a CVSS score of 9.1 out of 10 and is described as an improper authorization vulnerability. All versions of Confluence Data Center and Server are vulnerable and have been patched in the following versions: – 7.19.16 and later – 8.3.4 and later – 8.4.4 and later – 8.5.3 and later – 8.6.1 and later. The Lockbit Ransomware group claims to have hacked the aircraft engine and weapons manufacturer and threatens to expose the stolen data. Boeing is one of the world's largest aerospace manufacturers and defense contractors. In 2022, it had sales of $66.61 billion. The Lockbit Ransomware group has added Boeing to the list of victims on its Tor leak site. It claims to have stolen a large amount of sensitive data from the company and threatens to publish it if Boeing does not contact them by the deadline (November 2, 2023, 13:25:39 UTC). The group has not yet released any samples. In mid-October, the Lockbit Ransomware group claimed to have hacked technology services giant CDW, demanding an $80 million ransom. Hacktivist activity related to the Gaza conflict is dwindling. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 467/66 (IT) Monday, October 30, 2023: Cyber activity by Hacktivist groups related to the conflict between Israel and Hamas has significantly slowed. Some groups no longer have plans for such attacks, and others have shifted their focus to targets outside of Israel. Research by Security Scorecard, published this month, found that several Hacktivist groups had planned attacks or identified targets, but many have gone silent or shifted to selling attack services. Dark Storm, a pro-Palestinian group, posted claims on a Dark Web forum in August 2023 that it would "attack Israeli infrastructure." In early October, it claimed to be preparing attacks on Israel's European allies. Several Hacktivist groups threatened disruptive attacks against Israeli and Palestinian targets, while the SiegedSec group claimed responsibility for attacks on Israeli infrastructure and industrial control systems. Furthermore, Solomon’s Ring, a Persian-speaking, pro-Palestinian hacktivist channel, has not claimed an attack since October 8, despite being active since October 2022 and claiming to have hacked and stolen data from Israeli data centers, though without evidence. Meanwhile, KillNet Palestine (likely part of the Russian Hacktivist group KillNet) has not posted any new content since its founding announcement on October 13.

VMware Releases Patches for Critical vCenter Server RCE Vulnerability Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 466/66 (IT) Friday, October 27, 2023. VMware has released updates to address a critical vulnerability in vCenter Server that allows remote code execution on the system. The vulnerability, CVE-2023-34048 (CVSS score: 9.8), is an out-of-bounds write vulnerability in the DCE/RPC protocol implementation. If an attacker has network access to the vCenter Server, it could lead to an out-of-bounds write and allow remote code execution. The vulnerability was discovered and reported by Grigory Dorodnov from the Trend Micro Zero Day Initiative. VMware states that there is no workaround for the vulnerability, only security updates in the following software versions: – VMware vCenter Server 8.0 (8.0U1d or 8.0U2) – VMware vCenter Server 7.0 (7.0U3o) – VMware Cloud Foundation 5.x and 4.x. The company is working on patches for vCenter Server 6.7U3, 6.5U3, and VCF 3.x. A recent update also revealed vulnerability CVE-2023-34056 (CVSS score: 4.3), a partial information disclosure vulnerability impacting vCenter Server. Exploitation could allow a malicious actor with non-administrator privileges to access unauthorized information. VMware urges customers to act swiftly and apply the fixes as soon as possible to mitigate potential threats.

Former NSA employee pleads guilty to attempting to sell classified documents to Russia. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 463/66 (IT) Thursday, October 26, 2023. Jareh Sebastian Dalke, 31, a former employee of the U.S. National Security Agency (NSA), has pleaded guilty to six counts of attempting to transmit National Defense Information (NDI) to an agent of the Russian Federation. Dalke admitted to attempting to transmit classified military and security information. Dalke worked as an information systems security designer for the NSA from June 6, 2022, to July 1, 2022, and held a top-secret security clearance. Dalke admitted that between August and September 2022, he used an encrypted email account to send messages containing excerpts from three classified documents to a person he believed to be a Russian agent, requesting $85,000. In reality, the person was an FBI agent. The three copied documents contained NDI, classified as top secret and Sensitive Compartmented Information (SCI). Dalke was arrested by the FBI on September 28, shortly after sending the files. Sentencing is scheduled for April 26, 2024. He faces a maximum sentence of life in prison.

The following details of students, applicants, alumni, donors, employees, and contractors were exposed: – Social Security numbers – Driver's license or other government-issued identification numbers – Financial account or payment card numbers – Health information. The data of research participants and patients of University Health Service and School of Dentistry may have been affected: – Demographic information (e.g., Social Security number, driver's license or government-issued identification number) – Financial information (e.g., financial account or payment card numbers, or health insurance information) – Clinical information from University Health Service and the School of Dentistry (e.g., medical record number, or diagnoses, treatments, or medication history) – Information related to participation in certain research studies.

The Philippines' Department of National Defense has ordered its personnel to stop using AI-powered image-generating applications. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 459/66 (IT) Tuesday, October 24, 2023. The Philippines' Department of National Defense warned of the risks of using AI-powered applications to create images of individuals and ordered its personnel to immediately cease using such apps. On October 14, Defense Secretary Gilberto Teodoro Jr. issued an order to stop using AI-powered image generation applications and to exercise caution in sharing information online. This is due to the Philippine forces' ongoing efforts to quell decades-long communist and Muslim insurgencies, and to protect its interests in the disputed South China Sea. It is currently unclear whether the order was issued in response to a specific incident or to address potential attacks aimed at exploiting data collected by these AI-powered applications. However, the memo warns about applications used to create digital avatar profile pictures after users submit at least 10 pictures of themselves. The avatars can then mimic how users actually speak and move. The order states that these AI-powered applications pose significant privacy and security risks, as they can be misused to create fake profiles that can lead to identity theft, social engineering, phishing attacks, and other malicious activities.

Taiwanese network equipment manufacturer D-Link confirms a data breach that exposed low-sensitivity and semi-public information. The company confirms that the data is not from the cloud system, but is expected to be from the old D-View system, which reached end-of-life in early 2015. The data was used for registration purposes. So far, there is no evidence that the old data contains user IDs or financial information. A post shared on BreachForums on October 1, 2023, revealed the theft of personal information of a large number of government officials in Taiwan, including source code for D-Link's D-View network management software. D-Link has contacted cybersecurity firm Trend Micro to investigate the incident. In addition, there was an incident where an employee fell victim to a Phishing attack, and the company has increased operational security. The exact details of the attack have not yet been released, but the company emphasizes that current customers may not be affected by this incident.

Milesight industrial router vulnerability possibly exploited in attacks. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 17/66 (OT) Wednesday, October 18, 2023. A vulnerability affecting some industrial routers from Chinese CCTV product manufacturer Milesight may be exploited in attacks. Several UR series industrial cellular routers from Milesight (Ursalink) are affected by CVE-2023-43261, a high-severity vulnerability that exposes system log files, such as ‘httpd.log’. The exposed logs contain passwords for the administrator and other users, which can be exploited by unauthenticated remote attackers to gain unauthorized access to the targeted devices. Passwords are not stored in plain text in the log files, but they can be easily decoded. Researcher Bipin Jitiya disclosed details of the vulnerability and publicly released a Proof-of-Concept (PoC) exploit, and notified Milesight of the findings. Milesight says UR series routers can be deployed in various sectors, including industrial automation, traffic signaling, medical devices, and retail. Analysis of various firmware versions conducted by VulnCheck suggests that CVE-2023-43261 may have been present for several years. Shodan and Censys search engines show roughly 5,500 Milesight devices exposed on the internet, but only 6.5%, or less than 400 devices, appear to still be running a vulnerable firmware version.

CERT-UA reports 11 Ukrainian telecom providers were cyberattacked. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 454/66 (IT) Wednesday, October 18, 2023. The Computer Emergency Response Team of Ukraine (CERT-UA) revealed that at least 11 telecom providers in the country were attacked between May and September 2023. The agency is tracking the activity under the name UAC-0165, identified as an attack resulting in service disruption for customers. The attacks used two special programs called POEMGATE and POSEIDON, which allow for credential theft and remote control of infected hosts. To erase forensic traces, the WHITECAT utility was used. Moreover, unauthorized access to the providers' infrastructure was achieved using regular VPN accounts not protected by multi-factor authentication. CERT-UA stated that the attackers' intent was to compromise accountants' computers to steal authentication data (logins, passwords, keys/certificates) or alter details of financial documents in remote banking systems to send unauthorized payments.

Microsoft Defender Thwarts Akira Ransomware Group Attack Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 452/66 (IT) Tuesday, October 17, 2023. Microsoft announced that Microsoft Defender for Endpoint helped block a large-scale hacking campaign carried out by Akira ransomware (tracked as Storm-1567). The attacks occurred in early June 2023, targeting industrial organizations. Akira ransomware, launched in March 2023, claims to have attacked several organizations across various industries, including education, finance, and real estate. Like other ransomware groups, they have developed a Linux encryptor to target VMware ESXi servers, exploiting devices not equipped with Microsoft Defender for Endpoint to evade detection. Microsoft Defender's capabilities can prevent compromised accounts from accessing endpoints and other network resources. This protection limits the attackers' capabilities regardless of Active Directory status or account privilege levels.

The Lockbit ransomware group is demanding an $80 million ransom from CDW. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 450/66 (IT) on Monday, October 16, 2023 reported that the Lockbit ransomware group claims to have hacked CDW, a large technology solutions and services company for businesses, government, and education, known as CDW-G, which focuses services on US government agencies. These include K-12 schools, universities, non-profit healthcare organizations, state and local, and federal governments. The Lockbit ransomware group has demanded an $80 million ransom. CDW disclosed that it detected suspicious activity related to its Sirius Federal server and quickly launched an investigation, assisted by external cybersecurity experts. The server is not related to customers and is separate from other CDW-G systems' CDW network. The company also said that systems remain operational. Brett Callow, a threat analyst at cybersecurity firm Emsisoft, described the ransom amount in this case as the third largest, at least.

ALPHV Ransomware group claims attack on circuit court Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 448/66 (IT) Thursday, October 12, 2023. The ALPHV (BlackCat) ransomware group claims responsibility for the attack that affected the systems of the court across Northwest Florida last week. The group obtained personal details such as social security numbers and CVs of employees, including judges, and threatened to release the stolen data online to force the court back into negotiations. The Circuit Court revealed last week that it was investigating a cyberattack that disrupted operations on the morning of Monday, October 2nd. This incident will affect court operations in Escambia, Okaloosa, Santa Rosa, and Walton counties for an extended period. Court officials also confirmed that all facilities remained open without interruption, and the court is not interested in the ransom demands from the ALPHV ransomware attack. The BlackCat/ALPHV ransomware group emerged in November 2021 as a rebranding of DarkSide/BlackMatter. Initially known as DarkSide, it rebranded as BlackMatter in July 2021 before operations ceased in November 2021. As BleepingComputer reported last week, the ALPHV ransomware attack on MGM Resorts resulted in losses of approximately 100 million dollars.

Cisco releases urgent patch to fix critical vulnerability in Emergency Responder system. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 444/66 (IT) Monday, October 9, 2023. Cisco has released an urgent update to address a critical vulnerability affecting the Emergency Responder system, which allows unauthenticated remote attackers to access the system using hard-coded credentials. Vulnerability number CVE-2023-20101 (CVSS score: 9.8). Attackers can exploit this vulnerability by using an account to log in to the affected system. If exploited successfully, attackers can log in to the affected system and execute arbitrary commands as root. The vulnerability affects Cisco Emergency Responder version 12.5(1)SU4 and has been fixed in version 12.5(1)SU5. Other product versions are not affected. This disclosure comes less than a week after Cisco warned of exploitation of a vulnerability in IOS and IOS XE software (CVE-2023-20109, CVSS score: 6.6), which could allow authenticated remote attackers to execute arbitrary commands on affected systems. Users should update to the latest version to prevent potential threats.

Cyberattack disrupts LYCA MOBILE services Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 442/66 (IT) Friday, October 6, 2023 Lyca Mobile, an international mobile virtual network operator, has been the victim of a cyberattack that disrupted its network. Lyca Mobile is a Mobile Virtual Network Operator (MVNO) that provides prepaid mobile phone services to customers in many countries around the world. The company does not own the wireless network infrastructure, but leases network services from mobile operators instead, and Lycamobile serves more than 60 countries, reaching more than 15 million prepaid customers worldwide. The company issued a statement announcing that it had been the victim of a cyberattack that disrupted its network. The cyberattack occurred last week, preventing customers from accessing top-ups through the company's channels. The cyberattack did not affect services in the United States, Australia, Tunisia, and Ukraine. The company has investigated the security breach with the support of technical experts and has notified relevant regulatory and law enforcement agencies in each affected market. The company announced that it has restored affected services in all markets, but some operational services have not yet been resolved. The company did not provide details about the attack, but it is likely that the company was hit by Ransomware.

WS_FTP Vulnerability CVE-2023-40044 Exploited in the Wild Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 440/66 (IT) Thursday, October 5, 2023. Experts warn of vulnerability CVE-2023-40044, which attackers are exploiting in Progress Software's WS_FTP product. Progress Software recently warned customers to patch the critical vulnerability CVE-2023-40044 (CVSS score 10) in WS_FTP Server software used by IT teams worldwide. The vulnerability was discovered by researchers at cybersecurity firm Assetnote. A pre-authenticated remote attacker can exploit a .NET deserialization issue in the Ad Hoc Transfer module to execute arbitrary commands on the underlying WS_FTP server operating system. This vulnerability affects WS_FTP Server versions prior to 8.7.4 and 8.8.2. Assetnote researchers discovered approximately 2,900 internet-exposed hosts running WS_FTP and also published a PoC exploit for this vulnerability. Cybersecurity firm Rapid7 reported that attackers began exploiting CVE-2023-40044 after Assetnote published the PoC.

BunnyLoader malware targeting browsers and digital wallets. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 439/66 (IT) Thursday, October 5, 2023. Zscaler ThreatLabz has revealed a new Malware-as-a-Service (MaaS) threat called "BunnyLoader" being traded on underground websites. The tool is priced at $250 and is under active development, with rapid development, feature updates, and bug fixes. BunnyLoader is mostly written in C/C++ and is a fileless loader that performs malicious activities in memory, making it more difficult for cybersecurity operators to detect. BunnyLoader has a variety of capabilities such as a keylogger that records keystrokes and steals a large amount of information, including data from web browsers and digital wallets, and can perform remote command execution (RCE). Since its initial release on September 4, 2023, BunnyLoader has been continuously updated with bug fixes and new functionality.

Zanubis Android banking Trojan poses as a Peruvian government app to attack users. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 437/66 (IT) on Tuesday, October 3, 2023, detected a new Android banking Trojan malware called Zanubis, which disguises itself as a Peruvian government app to trick users into installing it. Kaspersky, in an analysis published last week, stated that "The primary distribution method for Zanubis involves impersonating legitimate Android applications in Peru. It then tricks users into enabling accessibility permissions and takes complete control of the device." Zanubis, originally documented in August 2022, is the latest addition to a long list of Android banking Trojans targeting the Latin American (LATAM) region. Targets include more than 40 banks and financial institutions in Peru. It is primarily known for abusing accessibility permissions on infected devices to display fake overlay screens on top of target apps in an attempt to steal credentials. It can also collect contact information, installed app lists, and system metadata. Kaspersky said it observed the latest Zanubis samples in April 2023, masquerading as the Peruvian customs and tax authority application, Superintendencia Nacional de Aduanas y de Administración Tributaria (SUNAT). Once installed, this allows Zanubis to perform keylogging or screen recording to steal sensitive information.

CISA adds JBoss RichFaces Framework vulnerability to Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 436/66 (IT) Monday, October 2, 2023. The US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added a critical vulnerability, CVE-2018-14667 (CVSS score 9.8), affecting Red Hat JBoss RichFaces Framework to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog. The vulnerability is an Expression Language (EL) injection via the UserResource resource, affecting RichFaces Framework versions 3.X through 3.3.4. This allows unauthenticated, remote attackers to exploit this vulnerability to execute arbitrary code via org.ajax4jsf.resource.UserResource$UriData. The vulnerability was discovered by security researcher Joao Filho Matos Figueiredo. According to Binding Operational Directive (BOD) 22-01, to mitigate the risk of this vulnerability, FCEB agencies are required to remediate the identified vulnerabilities by the due date to prevent network compromise from exploitation of vulnerabilities in the Catalog. Experts also recommend that private organizations review the Catalog and remediate the vulnerability. CISA has ordered federal civilian agencies to remediate this vulnerability by October 19, 2023.

Unpatched ZERO-DAY RCE vulnerability affects over 3.5 million EXIM servers. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 435/66 (IT) Monday, October 2, 2023. Experts warn of a critical Zero-day vulnerability, CVE-2023-42115 (CVSS score 9.8), in all versions of the Exim Mail Transfer Agent (MTA) software. This vulnerability allows unauthenticated remote attackers to exploit it and execute remote code (RCE) on exposed internet servers. The vulnerability stems from an out-of-bounds write issue within the SMTP service, caused by a lack of validation of user-supplied data. This allows remote attackers to run arbitrary code on affected Exim installations. No authentication is required to exploit this vulnerability. Researchers disclosed the vulnerability via ZDI on June 6, 2022, and ZDI reported it to the vendor on June 14, 2022. On September 25, 2023, ZDI requested an update and informed the vendor of their intention to publicly disclose the Zero-day on September 27, 2023. The development team has yet to fix this vulnerability, which has been present for over a year.

Hackers are exploiting a high-severity vulnerability in the Openfire messaging server to encrypt servers with ransomware and deploy cryptominers. Openfire is a widely used open-source Java-based chat (XMPP) server with over 9 million downloads, extensively used for cross-platform communication. The vulnerability, designated CVE-2023-32315, is an authentication bypass affecting the Openfire administrative console, allowing unauthenticated attackers to create new admin accounts on vulnerable servers. The flaw impacts all Openfire versions from 3.10.0 (2015) up to 4.6.7 and from 4.7.0 to 4.7.4. Although Openfire patched the vulnerability with versions 4.6.8, 4.7.5, and 4.8.0 released in May 2023, VulnCheck reported that in mid-August 2023, over 3,000 Openfire servers were still running vulnerable versions. BleepingComputer found multiple reports from customers stating their Openfire servers were encrypted with ransomware. It is unclear which ransomware group is behind these attacks, and it appears the attackers are not solely targeting Openfire servers but also web servers with other vulnerabilities. Therefore, it's crucial to keep all server security updates current.

RHYSIDA ransomware group attacks Kuwait's Ministry of Finance. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 431/66 (IT) Thursday, September 28, 2023. Last week, a ransomware attack targeted the Kuwaiti government. The attack occurred on September 18th, and government experts immediately initiated incident response procedures to mitigate the cyber threat. Kuwait's Ministry of Finance officially announced the incident on Twitter. Officials shut down affected systems to prevent the threat from spreading. The Ministry's message indicated that payment and payroll systems were impacted, as they were hosted on a separate network. “The Ministry of Finance announces that one of its systems was subjected to a hacking attempt and the system was shut down. Currently, the ministry is still unable to fully restore the system.” According to a press release issued by the Kuwaiti government this week, local authorities, including the National Cyber Center, are investigating the incident with assistance from cybersecurity companies. This week, the Rhysida ransomware group claimed responsibility for the attack and added the ministry to the list of victims on its data leak site on the Tor network. The group also published a set of documents as proof of the hack. The Rhysida ransomware group has been operating since May 2023, according to the gang’s Tor leak site, and has listed at least 44 companies as victims of its attacks.

Warn to patch TeamCity Instance to avoid server hacking. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 428/66 (IT) on Tuesday, September 26, 2023, experts warn of a critical vulnerability in TeamCity CI/CD servers that can be exploited to gain access to vulnerable servers. JetBrains TeamCity is a popular Continuous Integration and Continuous Delivery (CD) server developed by JetBrains, a software development company that provides tools for developers. TeamCity is designed to automate various software development processes, including building, testing, and deploying applications, and offers a wide range of features to support collaborative development. The vulnerability is an authentication bypass that affects on-premise versions of TeamCity, allowing attackers to exploit the vulnerability to steal source code, stored service secrets, and organizational private keys by injecting malicious code. TeamCity servers version 2023.05.3 and lower can bypass authentication, which allows unauthenticated attackers to remotely execute code (RCE) on the server. The vulnerability affects on-premise versions 2023.05.3 and lower. JetBrains has addressed the vulnerability with the release of version 2023.05.4, and this vulnerability does not affect TeamCity Cloud. Sonar says it cannot publish details of this vulnerability because it is exploitable.

Personal data of 25,000 Hong Kongers at risk after a cyberattack against the consumer watchdog, up from a previous estimate of 8,000. The Hong Kong Consumer Council revealed that the personal data of more than 25,000 people may have been leaked. Council CEO Gilly Wong Fung-han said Monday that externally provided computer systems, such as inquiry management and price-checking tools, had been restored, but there might be delays in handling complaints. The council has notified those affected by the data breach, including staff, former employees, 25,000 Choice magazine subscribers and 1,600 voters who participated in earlier activities. Data potentially stolen includes the credit card details of about 8,000 Choice magazine subscribers, the identity documents, addresses and birth dates of current and former staff, as well as family member details, resumes of job applicants from the past two years, and contact information of business partners.

National Student Clearinghouse data breach affects approximately 900 schools in the U.S. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 425/66 (IT) Monday, September 25, 2023. The National Student Clearinghouse (NSC), a U.S.-based non-profit organization that provides educational verification and reporting services to educational institutions, employers, and other organizations, has disclosed a data breach affecting approximately 900 U.S. schools that use its services. The security breach resulted from a cyberattack exploiting a vulnerability in managed file transfer (MFT) from the large-scale MOVEit hack campaign that targeted organizations worldwide in late May. This attack occurred on May 30th, and malicious actors were able to access related files containing personal information such as names, birth dates, contact information, social security numbers, student identification numbers, and certain school-related records (e.g., enrollment records, degree records, and program level information). According to the data breach notification letter, the information affected by this incident varies by individual.

GitLab Releases Urgent Security Patches for Critical Vulnerability Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 424/66 (IT) Friday, September 22, 2023. GitLab has released patches to address a critical vulnerability that allows attackers to execute other users' pipelines. This vulnerability, identified as CVE-2023-5009 (CVSS score: 9.6), affects all versions of GitLab Enterprise Edition (EE) from 13.12 and prior to 16.2.7, as well as from 16.3 and prior to 16.3.4. Successful exploitation of this vulnerability could allow attackers to access sensitive information or leverage the elevated permissions of the impersonated user to modify source code or execute arbitrary code on the system. Security researcher Johan Carlsson (aka joaxcar) is credited with discovering and reporting the vulnerability CVE-2023-3932. GitLab addressed the vulnerability in early August 2023, with fixes included in GitLab versions 16.3.4 and 16.2.7. Users are urged to update their GitLab installations to the latest versions as soon as possible to mitigate potential risks.

Clop Ransomware group steals data from major hospitals in North Carolina Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 420/66 (IT) Tuesday, September 19, 2023. Nuance, a Microsoft-owned technology company, has revealed that the Clop Ransomware group has stolen personal data from major hospitals in North Carolina as part of the Progress MOVEit Transfer campaign. MOVEit Transfer is used for secure file transfers using SFTP, SCP, and HTTP uploads. The Clop Ransomware group (also known as Lace Tempest) has been credited by Microsoft for the campaign that exploited the Zero-day vulnerability CVE-2023-34362 in the MOVEit Transfer platform. The company said the Clop group may have stolen personal data from several hospitals in North Carolina and other healthcare providers, including: – Atrium Health – Catawba Valley Medical Center – Charlotte Radiology – Duke University Health System – DLP Central Carolina Medical Center – ECU Health – FirstHealth of the Carolinas – Mission Health System – Novant Health – Novant Health New Hanover Regional Medical Center – UNC Health – Wake Radiology Diagnostic Imaging – WakeMed Health and Hospitals. Currently, many hospitals in the United States have been targeted by cyberattacks. The Rhysida Ransomware group has added three more U.S. hospitals to the list of victims on its Tor site after the PROSPECT MEDICAL attack on the systems of 3 hospitals and other healthcare facilities.

Mozilla fixes critical Zero-day vulnerability in Firefox and Thunderbird. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 418/66 (IT) Friday, September 15, 2023. Mozilla released a security update to fix a critical Zero-day vulnerability, CVE-2023-4863, in Firefox and Thunderbird that is being actively exploited. The vulnerability is a heap buffer overflow in WebP, previously addressed in Google Chrome before version 116.0.5845.187. It allows remote attackers to write out-of-bounds memory via a crafted HTML page, potentially leading to arbitrary code execution. The vulnerability was reported by Apple Security Engineering and Architecture (SEAR) and The Citizen Lab at the Munk School of the University of Toronto. Mozilla has not disclosed details about the attacks exploiting the flaw. This vulnerability affects Firefox 117.0.1, Firefox ESR 115.2.1, Firefox ESR 102.15.1, Thunderbird 102.15.1 and Thunderbird. The CVE-2023-4863 vulnerability has been addressed with the release of Firefox 117.0.1, Firefox ESR 115.2.1, Firefox ESR 102.15.1, Thunderbird 102.15.1, and Thunderbird 115.2.2. Google recently released an emergency security update to address the same vulnerability (CVE-2023-4863) in Chrome. This is the 4th Zero-day vulnerability patched by Google in 2023.

Google fixes the fourth Chrome zero-day vulnerability of 2023. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 414/66 (IT) Wednesday, September 13, 2023. Google has released an emergency security update to fix a zero-day vulnerability that has been widely exploited since the beginning of the year. The vulnerability, designated CVE-2023-4863, is the fourth zero-day vulnerability patched by Google in 2023. CVE-2023-4863 is a heap buffer overflow in WebP. The vulnerability was reported by Apple Security Engineering and Architecture (SEAR) and The Citizen Lab at the Munk School of the University of Toronto on Wednesday, September 6th. Chrome users should update their web browser to version 116.0.5845.187 for Mac and Linux, and 116.0.5845.187/.188 for Windows as soon as possible. This year, Google has fixed the following zero-day vulnerabilities exploited in Chrome: – CVE-2023-2033 (CVSS score: 8.8) – Type Confusion in V8 – CVE-2023-2136 (CVSS score: 9.6) – Integer overflow in the Skia graphics library – CVE-2023-3079 (CVSS score: 8.8) – Type Confusion in V8

CISA adds Critical Apache RocketMQ vulnerability to Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 410/66 (IT) Monday, September 11, 2023. The US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added the critical vulnerability CVE-2023-33246 (CVSS score 9.8) affecting Apache RocketMQ to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog. Various RocketMQ components, including NameServer, Broker, and Controller, have extranet leaks and lack authentication, allowing attackers to exploit this vulnerability by using the update configuration function to execute commands as the active RocketMQ system user. Attackers can also forge RocketMQ protocol content. This vulnerability affects Apache RocketMQ versions 5.1.0 and earlier. Users should update to version 5.1.1. Apache's advisory was released in May, but CISA added the issue to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog after cybersecurity firm VulnCheck published technical details about the vulnerability. CISA ordered federal agencies to patch this vulnerability by September 27, 2023. FCEB agencies must remediate identified vulnerabilities by the due date to protect against attacks exploiting vulnerabilities in the Catalog. Experts also recommend that private sector organizations review the Catalog and address vulnerabilities in their infrastructure.

More than a dozen vulnerabilities in security cameras made by the defunct company Zavio remain unpatched. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 408/66 (IT) Friday, September 8, 2023. BugProve, a provider of IoT firmware analysis platforms, has disclosed details of more than a dozen vulnerabilities found in security cameras made by Zavio, a Chinese company that has since shut down. However, the cameras are reportedly still in use in the United States and Europe. Because Zavio is defunct, BugProve worked with CCTV Camera Pros, a major Zavio camera distributor in the US, to investigate the vulnerabilities and report them to the US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) for public disclosure and CVE assignment. According to the companies, seven of the vulnerabilities can be exploited for unauthenticated remote code execution with root privileges. These flaws allow attackers to completely take over the targeted devices. IP cameras are often targeted by botnet herders and used in DDoS and other attacks. CISA has assigned only two CVE identifiers, CVE-2023-4249 and CVE-2023-3959, as the vulnerabilities stem from the same root cause. Since the affected Zavio cameras will not receive patches, users are advised to replace the devices in order to prevent becoming victims of malicious attacks. Security camera experts are reportedly informing customers that Zavio cameras are no longer available and suggesting alternatives.

These updates target critical Android components without requiring devices to reboot. The second part of this month's Android security updates will arrive on devices as the 2023-09-05 security patch level, with fixes for 12 more vulnerabilities in Qualcomm components. German financial authority website disrupted by DDoS attack. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 404/66 (IT) Wednesday, September 6, 2023. The German Federal Financial Supervisory Authority (BaFin) announced that it was hit by a distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attack. It is not yet clear who is behind the DDoS attack, but media speculate that it was launched by professional Russian hackers in response to Germany’s financial and military support for Ukraine. BaFin’s website was included in a list of attack targets published by the pro-Russian Killnet group on Telegram in January. The German Federal Financial Supervisory Authority (BaFin) is the national financial regulatory authority in Germany. It is a federal agency under the Federal Ministry of Finance. BaFin is responsible for supervising banks, insurance companies, investment firms and other financial institutions. It also regulates the stock market and the financial services industry. Security measures were implemented immediately after the attack began on Friday, September 1, 2023. BaFin stated that all other systems were not affected and the website is now back online. BleepingComputer said that the website was attacked at the database host that contains information on listed companies and public tenders.

Freecycle website confirms data breach affecting 7 million users. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 403/66 (IT) Wednesday, September 6, 2023. The Freecycle website, an online community created by people who want to reduce waste and recycle unnecessary items, is a place where members can exchange information about unwanted items and arrange for pick-up and delivery. Freecycle, a non-profit organization, has confirmed a large-scale data breach affecting more than 7 million users. The data breach was discovered a few weeks after stolen data was offered for sale on a data trading website on May 30th. The stolen data includes usernames, user IDs, email addresses, and MD5-hashed passwords. According to Freecycle's report, no other information was disclosed. After learning of the breach, Freecycle said it reported the incident to relevant authorities and warned affected users to immediately change their account passwords. They also advised users to be wary of phishing emails and to avoid clicking on links in emails from unknown sources.

The University of Sydney (USYD) announced a data breach by malicious actors who disclosed personal information of applicants who registered recently. The university, founded in 1850, has nearly 70,000 students and approximately 8,500 academic and administrative staff, and is one of Australia's most important educational institutions. The university's data breach announcement stated that the incident affected only a portion of applicants and that a preliminary investigation found no evidence that student, staff, or alumni data was affected. The university said it is still in the process of reviewing the data accessed by the attackers and is asking all international applicants to follow the advice provided on the university's website. Earlier this week, the University of Michigan announced the shutdown of systems critical to its operations to address a serious cybersecurity incident. In June, the University of Manchester suffered a data breach in which hackers stole a quantity of data from its network.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 400/66 (IT) Monday, September 4, 2023. The LockBit Ransomware group claims to have hacked the Commission des services electriques de Montréal (CSEM), the agency responsible for underground electrical wiring in Montreal, Canada, established in 1910 through a public-private partnership. CSEM's mission is to provide a safe, reliable, and sustainable underground electrical network for the city. Its main tasks are planning and coordinating underground electrical wiring, managing and maintaining the underground electrical network, and providing information and education about the underground electrical network. CSEM confirmed a data breach on August 3, 2023, and confirmed that it refused to pay the ransom. The agency immediately launched a security breach investigation with the assistance of law enforcement agencies, and CSEM has now recovered the affected systems. The LockBit Ransomware group published the stolen data on August 30, 2023. Since August 1, the LockBit group has accessed over 140 organizations worldwide.

A new scam disguised as the YouPorn website threatens to leak your sex tape. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 399/66 (IT) Monday, September 4, 2023. This week, a new form of extortion scam is being shared. It involves sending emails claiming to be from the adult website YouPorn, stating that a sexual video of the recipient will be published by uploading it to a network of adult websites. This email claims to be from info@youporn[.]com and has the subject line "Uploaded content: Feedback required". The message warns that your sex tape will be published on the website within the next 7 days unless you request its removal. The email includes links that claim to allow you to remove the video for free. However, these links are empty, causing your browser to open to the website's homepage. The email then lists paid options that can be used to remove the video from YouPorn and all websites in the adult network. These services are priced at $199, $699, or $1,399, with each tier claiming to offer additional protection. However, as far as those involved have investigated, it has been found that the campaign has not been very successful. It is important to emphasize that these emails are a scam. If you receive this email, simply delete it. While it may sound scary, it is nothing more than a scam from malicious actors.

Chinese hackers target US and other governments with Barracuda device vulnerability. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 397/66 (IT) Friday, September 1, 2023. Mandiant, a cybersecurity firm, has revealed details of a sophisticated global espionage campaign, suspected to be the work of a Chinese state-sponsored threat group called UNC4841. This group exploited a zero-day vulnerability (CVE-2023-2868) in Barracuda Email Security Gateway (ESG) appliances to infiltrate the systems of government agencies and organizations worldwide. Mandiant's investigation revealed that the campaign lasted eight months, from October 2022 to June 2023. The campaign involved the deployment of multiple advanced malware families, including Skipjack, DepthCharge, Foxglove, Foxtrot, and a new version of Seaspy. These malware families enabled the attackers to collect information, steal credentials, and evade detection. Affected sectors include national governments, technology companies, local governments, telecommunications providers, manufacturing entities, and universities. Although the campaign affected a limited number of ESG appliances globally (approximately 5%), the impact is significant due to the high-profile nature of the targeted organizations.

Critical vulnerability alert in VMware Aria Operations Networks, risk of remote attack. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 396/66 (IT) Thursday, August 31, 2023. VMware has released software updates to address two security vulnerabilities in Aria Operations for Networks that could be exploited to bypass authentication and allow remote code execution. The most severe vulnerability, CVE-2023-34039 (CVSS score: 9.8), is an authentication bypass vulnerability that allows attackers with network access to Aria Operations for Networks to bypass SSH authentication to access the Aria Operations for Networks CLI. The vulnerability was reported by researchers Harsh Jaiswal and Rahul Maini, who are credited with its discovery. The second vulnerability, CVE-2023-20890 (CVSS score: 7.2), is an arbitrary file write vulnerability affecting Aria Operations for Networks. It could be exploited by attackers with admin privileges to write files to arbitrary locations and achieve remote code execution. The vulnerability was reported by Sina Kheirkhah of the Summoning team. These vulnerabilities affect VMware Aria Operations Networks versions 6.2, 6.3, 6.4, 6.5.1, 6.6, 6.7, 6.8, 6.9, and 6.10. They have been addressed in VMware version 6.11.0, which fixes both vulnerabilities.

Somalia orders internet providers to block Telegram and TikTok. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 395/66 (IT) Thursday, August 31, 2023. Recently, the Somali government announced plans to shut down access to certain social media platforms, including TikTok and Telegram. Minister of Communications and Technology, Jama Hassan Khalif, announced via his Twitter account that the main purpose of blocking access to these social media platforms is to protect the morals and culture of the country's society. The order was issued on Sunday, August 20th. Internet service providers in the country have until Thursday, August 24th to comply with the order. Somalia has terrorist and extremist groups within the country that use Telegram for communication and to spread inappropriate content and misinformation to the public. The Minister stated that the ban was due to the platforms' harmful effects on youth and their misuse to harm many individuals. In recent years, statistics show that 8% of Telegram users are in the Middle East and North Africa, with 700 million users worldwide, which equates to more than half a million users. The TikTok platform has also been banned in several countries for moral reasons as well.

Attackers can obtain IP ADDRESSes by sending links via the mobile SKYPE application. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 393/66 (IT) Wednesday, August 30, 2023. Security researcher Yossi found that it is possible to discover the IP ADDRESS of a target by sending a link through the mobile Skype application. The researcher pointed out that the attack method only requires the target to open the message. This attack method can only be performed on the mobile Skype app. Obtaining the target's IP ADDRESS allows malicious actors to locate their physical location or residence, posing a privacy risk. This attack could pose a serious risk to activists, political dissidents, journalists, or those targeted by cybercriminals, and many others. According to a report by 404 Media, Yossi reported the issue to Microsoft earlier this month, but the company seemed to initially overlook the problem and did not indicate plans to fix the flaw. However, after 404 Media contacted Microsoft for information, the company announced plans to address the issue in the next application update. 404 Media only revealed that the issue can be exploited by manipulating certain parameters related to the link, but has not disclosed details of the attack since the vulnerability has not yet been patched.

Rhysida claims responsibility for the ransomware attack on Prospect Medical and threatens to sell data. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 392/66 (IT) Tuesday, August 29, 2023. The Rhysida ransomware group has claimed responsibility for the cyberattack on Prospect Medical Holdings, claiming to have stolen social security numbers, company documents, and records of 500,000 patients. The incident occurred on August 3rd when company employees found a ransom note on their screens stating that the network had been hacked and devices encrypted. Prospect Medical Holdings (PMH) is a US healthcare company with 16 hospitals in California, Connecticut, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, and 166 clinics and outpatient centers. The cyberattack resulted in hospitals shutting down their IT networks to prevent the spread of the attack. The Rhysida ransomware group claimed responsibility for the attack on Prospect Medical Holdings, threatening to sell the company's data for 50 Bitcoins (worth $1.3 million USD). The group claims to have stolen 1 TB of documents and a 1.3 TB SQL database containing 500,000 social security numbers, passports, driver's licenses, company documents, and patients' medical information. BleepingComputer has attempted to contact PMH for information about the attack but has not received a response at this time.

KmsdBot malware targets IoT devices with enhanced capabilities. The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 391/66 (IT) on Tuesday, August 29, 2023, reported that an updated version of the KmsdBot botnet malware is targeting Internet of Things (IoT) devices. KmsdBot was first documented by a security company in November 2022. It was designed to target private servers and cloud hosting providers. The malware is designed to scan random IP addresses for open SSH ports and brute-force the systems with a list of passwords downloaded from attacker-controlled servers. This new update has the capability to scan Telnet and supports more architectures found in IoT devices. The Telnet attacks are carried out by downloading a text file (telnet.txt) containing a list of weak, commonly used passwords and combinations for various applications. It exploits the fact that many IoT devices still have default credentials and have not been changed.

A hosting company says it lost all customer data after a ransomware attack. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 388/66 (IT) on Thursday, August 24, 2023, reported that two Danish hosting companies suffered a ransomware attack, resulting in the loss of most customer data. This forced the hosting providers to shut down all systems, including customer websites and emails. Both Hosting CloudNordic and AzeroCloud brands belong to the same company. The attack occurred last Friday night, and the company stated it would not pay the ransom. The company is cooperating with security experts and has reported the incident to the police. Due to the situation, both hosting providers recommend heavily impacted customers migrate to other providers, such as Powernet and Nordicway. Danish media reported that the attack affected hundreds of Danish companies, which lost data stored in the cloud, including websites, email inboxes, and documents. Targeting hosting providers is a tactic used by ransomware groups in the past, as it causes significant damage and allows them to attack many victims in a single attack. This incident has resulted in numerous victims, putting immense pressure on the providers to pay the ransom to restore operations and avoid lawsuits from customers who lost data.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation has released information about digital wallets linked to North Korean hackers. The FBI said it is holding approximately 1,580 Bitcoin that may be related to the recent theft of hundreds of millions of dollars worth of digital assets. The FBI has been tracking the stolen digital currency by the TraderTraitor group (also known as Lazarus Group and APT38) of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK), which is believed to be attempting to cash out the Bitcoin for more than $40 million. According to the information, the TraderTraitor-affiliated hacker group stole $60 million and $37 million from Alphapo and CoinsPaid in July, and $100 million from Atomic Wallet in June. CISA warns of exploitable Adobe ColdFusion vulnerability. The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 386/66 (IT) on Wednesday, August 23, 2023, reported that the US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has warned organizations that a patched Adobe ColdFusion vulnerability from earlier this year, tracked as CVE-2023-26359, may be exploited in attacks. CISA added the vulnerability to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog on Monday. Adobe addressed the vulnerability with its March 2023 Patch Tuesday updates, describing CVE-2023-26359 as a critical deserialization issue that can be exploited for arbitrary code execution. CISA has ordered federal civilian agencies to patch the vulnerability by September 11. Federal agencies are required to fix vulnerabilities added to the catalog under Binding Operational Directive (BOD) 22-01 to mitigate risks posed by the flaws. CISA's KEV catalog currently lists 12 ColdFusion vulnerabilities, including four flaws discovered this year. While there is no information available at this time regarding attacks exploiting CVE-2023-26359, Adobe ColdFusion vulnerabilities can be exploited by various threat actors in their operations.

WinRAR Vulnerability Allows Arbitrary Remote Code Execution Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 382/66 (IT) Monday, August 21, 2023. WinRAR, a file compression and archiving utility for Windows operating systems, was affected by a high-severity vulnerability, now patched, designated CVE-2023-40477 (CVSS score 7.8). This vulnerability could allow remote code execution on a computer by opening a specially crafted RAR archive. The vulnerability was reported to RARLAB by Zero Day Initiative researcher "goodbyeselene" on June 8, 2023, and could allow a remote attacker to execute arbitrary code on a RARLAB WinRAR installation. User interaction is required for exploitation. Targets may be tricked into visiting malicious websites or opening malicious files. The vulnerability is due to a lack of validation of user-supplied data, which can result in out-of-bounds memory access. This allows attackers to execute code by exploiting this vulnerability. WinRAR addressed the vulnerability with the release of version 6.23. Users are advised to update their WinRAR installations before attackers can exploit the vulnerability.

A large-scale phishing campaign using QR codes is targeting the energy sector. The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 379/66 (IT) reported on Friday, August 18, 2023, that cybersecurity firm Cofense has discovered a QR code phishing campaign targeting leading energy companies in the United States to steal users' Microsoft credentials across multiple industries. Most links included in the phishing messages contain Bing redirect URLs. Other prominent domains include krxd[.]com (linked to Salesforce applications) and cf-ipfs[.]com (Cloudflare's Web3 service). Using QR codes offers advantages over embedding phishing links directly in emails, most importantly the ability to bypass anti-phishing solutions, as the phishing link is hidden within the QR code image. Researchers observed a monthly growth percentage for this campaign exceeding 270%. The overall campaign has grown by more than 2,400% since May 2023. Researchers say this is the largest campaign ever using QR codes observed by Cofense, a situation suggesting that attackers are testing the effectiveness of QR codes. The phishing messages used in this campaign contain a PNG image file or a PDF file with a QR code. The message content attempts to trick recipients into scanning the code to verify their account. The email message urges recipients to complete the process within 2-3 days. Experts warn that the energy sector is the main focus of this campaign, followed by the manufacturing and insurance sectors.

Vulnerabilities in Iagona Scrutis website could allow ATMs to be hacked remotely. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 374/66 (IT) on Tuesday, August 15, 2023, reported that multiple vulnerabilities found in the ScrutisWeb ATM monitoring software, produced by the French company Iagona, could be exploited to remotely compromise ATM systems. These vulnerabilities were discovered by Synack Red Team researchers. ScrutisWeb allows organizations to monitor bank or retail ATMs from a web browser, enabling quick responses to issues. Synack researchers identified four vulnerabilities: CVE-2023-33871, CVE-2023-38257, CVE-2023-35763, and CVE-2023-35189. The vulnerabilities include authorization bypass, hardcoded cryptographic key, and arbitrary file upload, which could be exploited by remote, unauthenticated attackers. Attackers can exploit the vulnerabilities to obtain information from the server (configuration, logs, and databases) and execute arbitrary commands. Researchers said attackers could leverage these vulnerabilities to log into the ScrutisWeb management console as an administrator, monitor the activity of connected ATMs, enable management mode on the devices, upload files, and reboot or shut down the machines. The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has published an advisory to inform organizations about the vulnerabilities. According to CISA, affected products are used worldwide. Cumbria Constabulary accidentally leaked officer data online. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 373/66 (IT) Tuesday, August 15, 2023: Cumbria Constabulary, a territorial police force in England, unintentionally published the names and salaries of all its officers and staff online. This is the second UK agency in two weeks to admit to a data breach involving employee personal information. In this incident, Cumbria Police admitted that the names, salaries, and allowances of officers were indeed published on its website due to an unintentional human error. The information was removed immediately after the accidental publication, but the police did not specify how long the data was online before the error was discovered. Cumbria Constabulary stated it had immediately contacted all affected officers to inform them of the minor impact and outline the measures being taken to manage the leak and prevent recurrence. The incident was reported to the Information Commissioner’s Office (ICO – the UK's data regulator), which reportedly stated that no further action was needed beyond advice and guidance. The ICO was reportedly satisfied with the Constabulary's actions and the stringent steps taken to prevent further data breaches. However, it is reported that Chief Constable Simon Byrne will be investigated by the watchdog and may face penalties.

Multiple vulnerabilities in CODESYS V3 SDK can be exploited for RCE or DoS. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 16/66 (OT) Tuesday, August 15, 2023. Microsoft Threat Intelligence researchers have discovered 16 high-severity vulnerabilities, dubbed CoDe16, in the CODESYS V3 Software Development Kit (SDK). These vulnerabilities allow attackers to perform remote code execution and denial-of-service attacks, compromising operational technology (OT). Vulnerability CVE-2022-47391 has a severity score of 7.5. Successful exploitation affects all CODESYS V3 versions prior to 3.5.19.0 and could expose operational technology (OT) infrastructure to attacks such as remote code execution (RCE) and denial of service (DoS). Recommendations from Microsoft: – Patch affected devices and update device firmware to version 3.5.19.0 or higher. – Check all critical devices such as PLCs, routers, PCs, etc., and disconnect them from the internet, regardless of whether they are running CODESYS. – Restrict access to CODESYS devices to authorized components only.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 361/66 (IT) on Thursday, July 27, 2023, reported a severe privilege escalation issue affecting MikroTik RouterOS. Attackers can remotely exploit this vulnerability to execute arbitrary code and take complete control of vulnerable devices. A report released Tuesday revealed the vulnerability, CVE-2023-30799 (CVSS score: 9.1), affects approximately 500,000 RouterOS systems, making them susceptible to attacks via the web or Winbox interface. VulnCheck notes that CVE-2023-30799 was initially disclosed by Margin Research as an exploit called FOISted (without a CVE identifier). This vulnerability in Mikrotik routers was exploited to incorporate devices into denial-of-service (DDoS) botnets. Users are strongly advised to patch the vulnerability by updating to the latest version (6.49.8 or 7.x) as soon as possible. Mitigation recommendations include removing the MikroTik administrative interface from the internet, blocking administrator login IP addresses, disabling Winbox and the web interface, and configuring SSH to use public/private keys and disable passwords.

12 Norwegian ministries were hit by a cyberattack exploiting a zero-day vulnerability. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 359/66 (IT) on Wednesday, July 26, 2023, reported that malicious actors exploited a zero-day vulnerability in supplier software to attack the ICT platforms of 12 Norwegian ministries. Local authorities launched an investigation into the attack, which was reported by the Norwegian National Security and Service Organization (DSS) to the National Security Authority (NSM). The DSS established a crisis response team to investigate the incident in conjunction with the NSM and other security agencies. The Prime Minister's Office, the Ministry of Defence, the Ministry of Justice, and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs were not affected by the attack as they do not use the targeted platform. The DSS also notified the Norwegian Data Protection Authority of indications that the attackers may have stolen data from the affected government ICT platforms. In response to the incident, the DSS implemented security measures that prevented employees in the affected ministries from accessing DSS mobile services. However, they were still able to work normally using office or home computers. The zero-day vulnerability has been patched, but the Norwegian government has not yet released details about the attack.

Multiple DDoS Botnets Targeting Zyxel Devices Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 358/66 (IT) Monday, July 24, 2023. Fortinet FortiGuard Labs researchers warn that several DDoS Botnets are exploiting vulnerabilities affecting several Zyxel firewalls. The vulnerability, CVE-2023-28771 (CVSS score: 9.8), is a command injection issue allowing unauthorized execution of arbitrary code on vulnerable devices. Zyxel patched this vulnerability in late April and advised customers to apply the patch. The U.S. CISA has also added the vulnerability to its Known Exploited Vulnerability Catalog. In June, Rapid7 researchers confirmed they were tracking exploitation of CVE-2023-28771 by Mirai-like botnets. Now, Fortinet experts have observed attacks occurring across multiple regions, noting that attackers specifically target the command injection vulnerability in Internet Key Exchange (IKE) packets sent over UDP on Zyxel devices. This campaign uses multiple servers to launch attacks, and reports indicate the malware updates itself every two to three days to maintain compromise on Zyxel devices.

Adobe releases new patches for exploited ColdFusion vulnerabilities. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 356/66 (IT) Friday, July 21, 2023. Adobe has released new updates to address recently disclosed ColdFusion vulnerabilities that have been actively exploited. A critical vulnerability, designated CVE-2023-38205 (CVSS score: 7.5), is described as improper access control that could lead to security bypass. It affects the following versions: – ColdFusion 2023 (Update 2 and earlier versions) – ColdFusion 2021 (Update 8 and earlier versions) – ColdFusion 2018 (Update 18 and earlier versions). Adobe states that CVE-2023-38205 is being actively exploited in limited attacks targeting Adobe ColdFusion. Two other important deserialization vulnerabilities were also addressed: CVE-2023-38204 (CVSS score: 9.8), which could lead to remote code execution, and CVE-2023-38206 (CVSS score: 5.3), an improper access control vulnerability that could lead to security bypass. The disclosure comes as Rapid7 warned that the fix for CVE-2023-29298, an access control bypass vulnerability, was incomplete and could be bypassed by attackers. The company continues to recommend that Adobe ColdFusion users update their installations to the latest versions to mitigate potential threats.

Ukrainian cyber police have dismantled a large bot farm operated by a gang of over 100 people. The gang created fake social media accounts to spread propaganda, distort information, and conduct psychological operations related to the invasion of Ukraine, in support of the Russian government. The gang used the large bot farm to spread illegal content, Ukrainian citizens’ personal data, and conduct various types of fraud. Cyber police discovered that the group used special equipment and software to register over a thousand bot accounts on various social media networks. Police seized more than 250 computers, mobile phones, and GSM gateways, along with approximately 150,000 SIM cards from various mobile operators.

Virustotal data leak exposes data of some registered users, including intelligence agency members. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 353/66 (IT) Thursday, July 20, 2023. German newspapers Der Spiegel and Der Standard report that the online malware scanning website VirusTotal suffered a data leak that exposed data of some registered customers. The leaked file is 313 kilobytes in size and contains a list of 5,600 names, including data related to employees of the NSA, U.S. Secret Service, U.S. cyber agencies, and German intelligence services who have registered with the Google-owned VirusTotal website. Der Spiegel points out that the leaked data reveals who is involved in IT and malware security in affected companies and government organizations. Malicious actors could use this information to target these officials with spear-phishing attacks. The exposed records include customer names and email addresses. The data was exposed after an employee accidentally uploaded it to VirusTotal. Once Google became aware of the leak, the data was removed within an hour of the upload.

Adobe issued a warning to customers about a critical remote code execution vulnerability in ColdFusion, tracked as CVE-2023-29300 (CVSS score: 9.8), which is being actively exploited. Unauthenticated attackers can exploit this vulnerability to remotely execute commands on vulnerable Coldfusion 2018, 2021, and 2023 servers. Adobe has not disclosed technical details of the vulnerability but has addressed three vulnerabilities in ColdFusion: 1. CVE-2023-29298 (CVSS score: 7.5) Improper Access Control 2. BreachForums website owner pleads guilty. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 350/66 (IT) Tuesday, July 18, 2023: The owner of the notorious website BreachForums has pleaded guilty in a US court to conspiracy to commit access device fraud, access device fraud, and possession of child pornography. The man, Conor Brian Fitzpatrick, 21, of Peekskill, New York, was arrested on March 15, 2023. Fitzpatrick, known online as ‘Pompompurin,’ admitted to authorities that he was the owner and administrator of BreachForums, which launched in 2022 as an alternative to RaidForums, a cybercrime marketplace. BreachForums, located on the Surface Web, was easily accessible to anyone. With over 340,000 members, it was shut down following Fitzpatrick's arrest. BreachForums had become a top hacker marketplace at the time, facilitating the trade of hacked or stolen data, including bank account details, social security numbers, personal information, online account credentials, and hacking services for hire. Fitzpatrick's guilty plea carries a maximum penalty of 10 years in prison for conspiracy to commit access device fraud, a 10-year prison sentence for access device fraud, and a maximum of 20 years for possession of child pornography. The maximum penalties for each count, as well as a $250,000 fine and supervised release, are applicable.

New PyLoose Linux malware mines crypto directly from memory. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 345/66 (IT) Friday, July 14, 2023. A new fileless malware called PyLoose is targeting cloud workloads to hijack computing resources to mine Monero cryptocurrency. PyLoose is a relatively simple Python script with a compiled, base64-encoded XMRig miner, an open-source tool that leverages CPU power to solve complex algorithms necessary for the cryptocurrency. Researchers from Wiz stated that PyLoose’s direct execution from memory makes detection by security tools difficult. Fileless malware doesn’t leave traces on the system’s drive, making it hard to detect. It typically leverages legitimate system tools to inject malicious code into legitimate processes. Wiz security researchers first detected the PyLoose attacks on June 22, 2023, and have since confirmed over 200 instances. Researchers haven't been able to attribute the PyLoose attacks to a specific threat actor, as the attackers didn't leave any clues behind. They recommend that cloud instance administrators avoid publicly exposing services vulnerable to code execution, utilize strong passwords and multi-factor authentication to protect access to these services, and implement system command execution restrictions.

HCA Healthcare data breach affects 11 million patients. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 344/66 (IT) Thursday, July 13, 2023. HCA Healthcare has been attacked. The data breach exposed the personal information of approximately 11 million patients. The agency discovered the breach on July 5th after the attacker posted information on an underground forum claiming to have stolen data from HCA Healthcare. The attacker posted details of sample patient data such as name, address, date of birth, gender, phone number, email address, service dates, and appointment dates. HCA Healthcare stated that the following information was not stolen in the attack: – Clinical information such as treatments, diagnoses, or conditions – Payment information such as credit card or account numbers – Sensitive information such as passwords, driver's licenses, or social security numbers. HCA Healthcare has conducted an investigation into the security breach with the assistance of forensic and threat consultants. HCA Healthcare has also notified law enforcement of the incident and plans to contact affected individuals. In response to the incident, HCA Healthcare has disabled user access to the impacted data storage location.

Revolut was hit by a cyberattack exploiting a vulnerability in its payment system, resulting in a loss of US$20 million. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 342/66 (IT) Wednesday, July 12, 2023. In early 2022, attackers exploited a zero-day vulnerability in Revolut's payment system to steal over $20 million, according to the Financial Times, citing multiple sources. The breach was not publicly disclosed. The issue stemmed from a flaw in Revolut's system in America and Europe, causing some transactions to be declined. The company would then refund the accounts using its own funds. The problem was first discovered in late 2022, with reports indicating that attackers exploited the vulnerability by attempting to purchase expensive items that would be declined. The refunded amounts were then withdrawn from ATMs. Technical details of the vulnerability remain unclear. Approximately $23 million was stolen, with a portion recovered by tracking down those who withdrew the cash. The massive fraud resulted in the neobank and fintech company incurring a net loss of around $20 million. The disclosure comes less than a week after Interpol announced the arrest of suspected members of a French hacker group dubbed OPERA1ER, linked to attacks targeting financial institutions and mobile banking services with malware, large-scale phishing campaigns, and business email compromise (BEC) scams.

VMware notified customers about the availability of exploit code for a critical RCE vulnerability, CVE-2023-20864, in VMware Aria Operations for Logs (formerly vRealize Log Insight). VMware Aria Operations for Networks (formerly vRealize Network Insight) is a network monitoring tool that helps organizations build optimized, highly available, and secure network infrastructure. In April, the virtualization giant released security updates to address two critical vulnerabilities, CVE-2023-20864 and CVE-2023-20865, affecting Aria Operations for Logs (formerly vRealize Log Insight). The company has now updated its original security advisory to confirm the availability of exploit code for the aforementioned issue. The company is urging customers to patch the vulnerability immediately. In June, the company warned customers that another critical remote code execution vulnerability in Aria Operations for Networks, CVE-2023-20887, was being actively exploited.

Japan's Nagoya Port suspends cargo operations after Ransomware attack. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 336/66 (IT) Friday, July 7, 2023. Nagoya Port is the largest trading port in Japan, accounting for approximately 10% of Japan's total trade value. In particular, this port is the largest exporter of automobiles in Japan and is the port where Toyota Motor Corporation exports most of its vehicles, including goods such as food and household appliances. On Wednesday morning, the Nagoya Harbour Transportation Authority announced that cargo operations had been suspended following a cyberattack that affected the Nagoya United Terminal System (NUTS), the computer system used in the operation of the port's 5 cargo terminals. All cargo operations have been suspended since July 4th. The attack resulted in temporary traffic jams of transport vehicles at the port. Nagoya Port predicted that the system would be back online and cargo operations would resume on the morning of July 6th. The group claiming responsibility for the attack is the LockBit 3.0 ransomware group.
